别问我为什么，因为我是帝国时代的死忠粉脑残粉，没有个几百上千个小时的游戏时间怎么对得起这款经典神作！

"You'll take my life, but I'll take yours too
You'll fire your musket, but I'll run you through
So when you're waiting for the next attack
You'd better stand, there's no turning back
The bugle sounds, the charge begins
But on this battlefield, no one wins
The smell of acrid smoke and horses' breath
As I plunge on into certain death.

The horse, he sweats with fear, we break to run
The mighty roar of the Russian guns
And as we race towards the human wall
The screams of pain as my comrades fall
We hurdle bodies that lay on the ground
And the Russians fire another round
We get so near, yet so far away
We were meant to fight another day.

We get so close, near enough to fight
When a Russian gets me in his sights
He pulls the trigger and I feel the blow
A burst of rounds take my horse below
And as I lay there gazing at the sky
My body's numb and my throat is dry
And as I lay forgotten and alone
Without a tear, I draw my parting groan."
---------The Trooper - IRON MAIDEN.

AOE3 was my favorite strategy game I ever played. AOE DE adds some cool features like a graphics, cards, and reworks. I'm not a fan of every change, but I realize that changes were probably made to make the game more balanced. The new DLC civilizations are not OP nor under powered. What an amazing game. Fun game. I don't like to compare it too much to the other Age of Empires games because it's a different formula than the others. That said, go in with zero expectations and enjoy the timeline and strategy based game. 

I will say, though I have a neutral opinion on the current Campaigns. One thing Age 3 DE needs to capitalize on is expanding its "Historical Battles" and recreate so many iconic moments in history to be playable for the AOE player. There is a missed opportunity in the vast array of quantity and quality that would add to this game, if only Historical battles and new Historical Campaigns were to be added in that would tell history while giving the civs a new light. Without arguing about the current fictional campaigns intertwined with a splash of historical setting. Having a more Historical fact based campaign per civilization would be a great thing of this game (In my opinion). Say a few scenarios per Campaign for a Civilization.

Age of Empires is a timeless strategy game that combines historical authenticity with engaging gameplay. With meticulous attention to detail, diverse civilizations to choose from, and deep strategic depth, it offers an immersive experience that captivates players of all ages. Despite its age, Age of Empires remains a masterpiece in the world of strategy gaming, proving that great gameplay never goes out of style

This game sets the gold standard for a remaster, and vastly improves the experience from the original.

With the addition of many new Civs, units, cards, and maps, this really is the definitive experience of Age of Empires III.
In addition to the re-balances, and graphical enhancements, this game is now also free to play, with many civs being on rotation. Each of the new civs bring something new to the game, while at first many of these changes weren't balanced correctly, over time the developers have addressed many of these issues.

I mainly play this game for matches vs the AI. And my major beef is the AI Cheats in almost every game mode. I am to the point where I have perfected the best open that should out pace the AI to the first age by about 8 to 10 minutes based on my early learning games. 

My score is about double the AI and yet it is able to keep pace with my perfect open where I capture all trading posts. Once the AI reaches the 2nd Age it really starts to cheat excessively. Sometimes building units it does not even have the building type for that unit. But in most cases it will have double and sometimes triple the players army size. 

It defies logic if they just spent the resources to age up and most of these units cost gold too. The only exception to this is home city resources however the only way the AI could possibly keep pace with me is if they are spending home city points on wood. As wood is critical in the first ages. And if the AI does not have a single trading post because I have captured all of them that means I am outpacing home city resources by a lot.

The games tend to always play out the same way. Even though the AI cheats itself a big army it's tactics always fail against me. I always protect the trading posts with a tower and have my age 2 army closest to the most likely trading post to get attacked first. It's always a mistake to rush the enemy after the 2nd age because the AI will trash the players army with numbers. Predictably the AI army hits a trading post and with a tower and a smaller army in place you can always pick off the entire enemy force. 

At this point you can go win the game or just toy with the AI until you have fully upgraded. The AI will continue to try and amass a big army from this point but if you rush in and thin out the villagers and stay on top of military units produced and destroy the military buildings the AI will usually just surrender. If you manage to take out all the villagers the game is over. The only danger at this point is the town center and you don't want to let the AI pick off too many of your units.

My biggest complaint is because the AI cheats even on normal difficulty it cheapens the experience knowing the AI does not play by the same rules and instead of playing counter tactics against me. The AI just uses a basic formula that bigger is better. So what should the AI be doing? Well it needs to turtle a little more and get something to deal with my towers. The AI needs to try and stop me from taking all the trading posts. As I view the trading posts to be the primary path to victory. This however would require the AI to quickly change tactics which at the moment it can not do. 

However what would make angry is if they just cheated the AI more wood and the starting villagers just took all the trading posts without earning the resources. That is the kind of thing I would expect instead of making a more tactics viable AI opponent.

I just think it would be nice to have a bit more push and pull without the AI cheating. It would be more fun for the game to play out differently every time based on player actions and aggressiveness. Perhaps I'm asking the impossible.

Age of Empires III: DE is one of the best, if not the best, age instalments from Microsoft ever released. You have everything from massive frigates to booming artillery that can help you change the tide of a battle. There are many possible strategies depending on what civilisation you choose or what cards you choose; this allows you to determine if you want to play a fast game by rushing your opponent or a slower-paced and eco-based game where you boom. People interested in the series should try it; the game had a bit of a faulty launch, which contributed to most people sticking to AoE2 instead.

This review used to be negative because the game was off to a rocky start with lots of bugs and crashes, but the devs have been releasing updates every week or two to fix issues. 

There are still many fixes needed- scenarios/custom maps still aren't fully functional.

I will continue to keep my review positive as long as devs continue updating the game.

Edit: Years later, this game only gets better and better. Tons of new civs, maps, etc. This is the best Age of Empires game there is, and you can even try it for free.

[h1]Rule And Pillage The Lands[/h1]
Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition offers players a trial of this historical single & multiplayer RTS experience. Enjoy diverse civilizations, co-op historical battles, stunning 4K Ultra HD graphics and modernized gameplay. For more ongoing fun, content unlocks will rotate monthly, which includes rotating civilizations, Hero Cosmetics and events - so come play often! Jump into the robust community – and invite a friend to play today!

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]As this is basically a remaster, the visuals have had a good boost. Also some new features have been added to improve the experience. The ability to zoom in is a wonderful addition. Being able to zoom in the battles and experience the chaos is a huge plus. The character models have been updated and the environments have seen a great increase in density and foliage. The vivid artstyle also helps this game stand out and pop. The visuals are really good and a great improvement from the original. The factions do feel quite unique from each other. This adds an extra layer of depth and challenge. Speaking of layers, many of the factions have a unique visual style. I really like this as it adds immersion, and a feel of realism. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]As a RTS game, this will require quick thinking and strategy. The gameplay mechanics offer an easy to learn, hard to master feeling to it. Unit formations do play a role and many factions play as that have a different feel to them which is great to see. I do feel like the unit is pretty small even for a remaster. Only 50 units feels like a letdown. The AI does feel pretty weak even on hard difficulty. I wish the AI had some tweaking but since this game is pretty old I don’t think updates will be coming. The in-game maps are procedurally generated and look really good! There is a huge diversity in terms of landscape. Ranging from forest, desert, some snow, etc. You also can create your own deck for your factions. Deck cards crant you free units, resources, and upgrades of your choosing. You can create your own cards and save them for certain builds. This gives an extra layer of replayability and strategy that I personally really enjoyed.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎭Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]Multiplayer is actually really fun here. The game is split between rank and unranked. I prefer this as it separates the more competitive and the casual players (well as best as it can). The ranked matches do feel pretty unbalanced because you cannot even out civ choices or teams before the match. This may be nitpicky, but worth noting for anyone into playing ranked online. Overall it’s pretty fun. Playing against friends was a joy and has issues with connection or network.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]You can add many hours into this game. You have a healthy amount of replayability in terms of the deck card system, procedure generated maps, many factions, etc. I placed around 80+ hours and can see myself adding more.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is pretty good. The in-game music is pretty mediocre though. At Least the sounds of the weapons, cannons, and overall combat is pretty sharp and a good improvement.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]Bugs haven’t really been an issue for me here. The game is pretty optimized in terms of bugs. You should encounter very little amount of bugs here (well from my experience).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]Performance is pretty good for the most part. The only issue I had was putting foliage on max settings (switched it to medium). For some reason the specific settings really tanks my frame rate. Besides the complaint the game runs really well once you put the foliage on medium settings. I gotten a solid 60 FPS, no stutters and crashes.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Card deck system
[*]Diverse set of units
[*]Many amazing factions
[*]Great remastered visuals
[*]Can now play in four teams
[*]Procedurally generated maps
[*]Some new amazing game modes
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Poor GPU optimization
[*]Maximum unit selection is still 50
[*]AI feel too easy even on Hard mode
[*]Ranked matches don't feel balanced
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]7.5/10
Buy this game on sale for around 50% off if you plan on buying the Complete History Edition.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition adds a lot to the table when it comes to a RTS game. The deck building system, many cool factions, and the amazing battles you can create are truly an addictive experience. This may not be the top tier RTS game, but I feel that it does a fantastic job for what it is. Of course this game is gonna have some issues, but if you are looking for a RTS game with a huge diverse set of factions and that is pretty beginner friendly, then give this one a shot.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

Age of Empires 3 is a controversial title on itself. I can say that I actually did enjoy the old one to a good degree. This one however, feels kinda like changing better graphics and (I dobut) better AI, in exchange for less freedom and less replayability.
While Im still enjoy the core mechanics of the game, the lack of workshop, or any meaningful way to add maps and content to the title, the rushed (wich I dont enjoy) in the skrimish and the focus on competitive (Wich... Im not) make this feel like a downgrade of some sort. I dont want to go back at the old one. This has sooo much things I like. The new civs, the ost, the graphics and several improvements in UI and development. But I cannot stay on this, as every game feel so rush and there is no actual strategy as you dont even have a time to prepare an attack OR if you have the time, you can win with just a few riders and some cheap cannons.
Treaty would be a good adding to the game. bigger maps or an AI that allows you to enjoy your town just a little. But, I admit I get why nobody is asking for those things too. 
A workshop would be wonderfull enough.

As a longtime fan of the Age of Empires series, diving into Age of Empires III felt like embarking on a grand historical adventure. The game, released in [year], exceeded my expectations and proved to be a strategic masterpiece that effortlessly blended the classic charm of the franchise with innovative gameplay elements.

From the moment I launched the game, the visuals captivated me. The attention to detail in the graphics is astounding, creating immersive landscapes that transport players to different corners of history. Whether I was exploring dense jungles, navigating bustling cities, or engaging in epic battles, the visual fidelity added a new level of enjoyment to the gaming experience.

The introduction of the Home City system was a game-changer. It added a strategic layer that allowed me to tailor my playstyle and adapt to various challenges. Customizing my Home City and unlocking unique shipments became a crucial aspect of my overall strategy. This dynamic element injected freshness into each match, as I experimented with different approaches to find the most effective combination for victory.

The single-player campaigns were a standout feature for me. The engaging storylines, spanning different historical epochs, kept me hooked from start to finish. Each campaign presented unique challenges and showcased the game's versatility in portraying diverse civilizations. It wasn't just about conquering territories; it was about experiencing history through the lens of compelling narratives.

In multiplayer, Age of Empires III truly shines. The matchmaking system ensured fair and competitive matchups, and the variety of civilizations and strategies kept every game unpredictable. The addition of new units and technologies for each civilization provided endless possibilities for experimentation. The multiplayer community is vibrant, and engaging in epic battles with other players around the world was a thrilling experience.

The soundtrack deserves its own applause. The music perfectly complemented the game, creating an emotional backdrop that heightened the intensity of battles and the satisfaction of achieving strategic milestones. The sound design overall was top-notch, adding another layer to the immersive experience.

While no game is without flaws, Age of Empires III comes remarkably close to perfection. The balance between tradition and innovation is masterfully executed, making it a must-play for both series veterans and newcomers to real-time strategy. Whether you're a history enthusiast or a strategy game aficionado, Age of Empires III delivers a rich and enjoyable gaming experience that will undoubtedly stand the test of time.

As an owner of the old style gold edition of AOE3, I have to say that the new deck builder is a f&^@$*g joke. It is simply a mess. Please, give a choice between the two - new and old. There is no information on what age the card is available to use, also using the slider to switch between builds is unintuitive. Old style leveling up was better, it forced to master nation! Don't touch things that worked great. In addition, there are many bugs, one of them: Act 2 of the campaign - The leader of the tribe is called Nathaniel Black(even Nathaniel B. is another NPC here). NPCs on island maps sucks so bad, they can't play these maps. I also have the impression that the game is poorly optimized, consuming much more PC resources, even if there is no significant graphics improvement(subjective feeling, don't tread on me). After some time I realized that game ignores deafults set by NVIDIA Control Panel - This game is forcing me to use integrated graphics card in my dual GPU notebook, and there is no remedy to force it to use NVIDIA GPU! AWFULLLLL

Third chapter in the saga, covering a timespan of roughly 300 years (from the 16th to the 19th century).
The gameplay is the same as in the two previous titles: units gather resources to construct new buildings, research technologies and train more units.
The biggest difference is the experience value granted by every succesful action, which allows to play cards from a deck, granting various perks. The building of said deck is a vital part of the strategy in the preparation of a match.

The biggest flaws are a certain artificial stupidity (enemies aren't effective on water maps) and the lack of actual historical campaigns: one above all the Napoleonic Wars.

That said, it's still a wonderful historical RTS, supported by a solid research. If you liked the first two, don't miss this.

I got Age of Empires 3 in December 2006 as a Christmas gift. This was after War Chiefs expansion but before the Asian Dynasties. I kept an old dell working for over 15 years just to keep playing it. When AOE3 DE came out I pre-ordered it, something I hadn't done for a game in decades. And I fell in love all over again. I love playing with the Asian civs and the new civs that have been added on DE. I love switching from Germany to Mexico to India depending on if I'm playing by myself or on multi-player with my now adult kids who grew up watching me play this game. Though AOE3 gets a bad rap in the community for being less in depth and nuanced than other entries in the series, do not sleep on this game, I garunte you will have fun in it regardless of if your new or old to the franchise. Games can run anywhere from 15 minutes to 2-3 hours depending on play style and game settings. This game is definitely an easy to play hard to master kind of game, but it makes for great LAN parties. While it is true there is less nuance especially in microing in combat by comparison to AOE2, I find that due to systems such as shipments which make every nation hugely customization, most games still feel difficult and interesting! Defenitely grab it if its on sale, but its even a good deal for retail price.

A lot more arcade-like than AoE 2, but still a lot of fun.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

First things first , this game is very fun, it has excellent replay-ability and is extremely dynamic with your preferred play style.
You like playing as a colonising power? There is a home city card for that, you like making Turkish noises when you play as the ottomans, you can do that. This game like almost all the games in the AOE franchise is unique in the fact that every game is different, not a single time will a game repeat itself when you play it the way it did previously something always changes, the game can be a little sweaty what with learning all the build orders,the hotkeys but there is an option for you to play in a non sweaty way and still have fun, Multiplayer is where this game really shines, its excellent and deeply enjoyable playing with your friends, the multiplayer is stable and rarely crashes and there are multiple servers from different regions of the world depending on where you are at, it provides for a very smooth experience and you will rarely have issues playing the game, the optimisation is also good but not great, in short its an improvement on the original AOE 3.

New players in particular need to be aware that you need a solid 20 hours before you have a solid grasp on the game, it isnt too steep AOE 3 is noticeably a bit simpler than AOE 2.

[h1][b]Content[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 20/20[/b]

Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition offers a variety of game modes, ensuring there's something for every type of player. From the classic skirmish battles against AI or human opponents to historical campaigns, the game caters to competitive and narrative-driven players. The new Historical Battles mode provides a refreshing challenge, offering unique scenarios based on actual historical events. The game also includes all the campaigns, each offering a unique historical perspective. Expect 30-40 hours of playtime across all the campaigns. Playtime for other game modes depends on the player's interest.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 18/20[/b]

The core gameplay mechanics of Age of Empires 3 remain intact, staying true to the original's foundation. Players still engage in resource gathering, base building, and strategic warfare, but the Definitive Edition refines and balances these elements. The developers have addressed some of the gameplay issues from the original, resulting in a smoother and more enjoyable experience. Unit pathfinding has improved, and various balance tweaks further improve the overall gameplay flow. Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition introduces two new civilizations – the Swedes and the Incas. These additions bring fresh strategic options to the game and showcase the developers' commitment to expanding the content. Each civilization offers unique units, buildings, and technologies, adding depth and variety to the gameplay.

The multiplayer experience has improved, offering better matchmaking, improved lobby functionality, and reduced latency. The dedicated servers contribute to a more stable online experience, addressing some of the connectivity issues present in the original release. Additionally, quality-of-life improvements, such as a modernized user interface and hotkey customization, make the game more accessible and user-friendly. Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition embraces the modding community by providing robust tools and support. One aspect I'll miss from the original release is the unlockable deck cards made the game, in the beginning, more of a challenge. In Definitive Edition, all the cards are available from the get-go, which might be too much to take away. The biggest drawback is that the scenario editor didn't get any improvements.

[h1][b]Presentation[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 18/20[/b]

The visual overhaul in Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition is spectacular. Every aspect, from the units to the landscapes, has been reimagined with attention to detail. The game offers improved textures, dynamic lighting, and rich particle effects that breathe life into the colonial-era setting. The attention to historical accuracy is admirable, with each civilization's architecture, units, and environments reflecting the time period with realism. The upgraded visuals are not only cosmetic but enhance the overall gaming experience, making battles more immersive and civilizations more charming.

The audio design in Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition is a symphony that complements the visual feast. The revamped sound effects and music contribute significantly to the game's atmosphere, immersing players in diverse cultures and intense battles. The music captures the heart of the times and dynamically adjusts to the flow of the gameplay. The enhanced graphics and sound collectively create an audio-visual experience that resounds with the brilliance of history. Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition is not just a simple facelift; it's a complete package that brings a wealth of content to veterans and newcomers. The Definitive Edition includes all the expansions from the original game, introducing new civilizations, campaigns, and game modes.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 17/20[/b]

The single-player offers captivating campaigns that span different ages and civilizations, from the discovery of the New World to the Industrial Age. Each campaign tells a unique and historically inspired tale. The campaigns are not just a series of battles but immersive journeys that introduce players to the complexities of each civilization's history, adding an educational element to the gaming experience. One notable improvement in the Definitive Edition is the enhanced AI, which provides a more challenging and dynamic single-player experience.

The AI adapts to your strategies, keeping you on your toes and forcing you to develop new tactics in the heat of battle. This adds replayability and ensures that each skirmish feels fresh and unpredictable. Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition's single-player offering is a triumph, successfully blending historical authenticity, stunning visuals, and refined gameplay. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer eager to explore the history through strategic warfare, this edition delivers an engaging and satisfying experience that stands as a testament to the lasting legacy of the Age of Empires franchise.

[h1][b]Technicalities[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 15/20[/b]

Overall, the game is running smoothly and playing well. However, there are occasional FPS drops during intense on-screen action with many units displayed. While this issue existed in the original game and has carried over, it's safe to say that it's the CPU limitations playing their role. It's not overly distracting or bothersome but might be more severe on a weaker CPU. The periodical FPS drops are noticeable but don't detract from the gameplay. I applaud the developers for addressing and fixing the major performance issues when the game was released, even though it took about six months. A turnaround like this isn't often seen in modern PC releases and is worth complimenting, as they actually dedicated the time to polish the game. While the game was initially incomplete and broken, with the improvements made over time, I can confirm that it is stable and polished to the highest degree possible.

[h1][b]Final Verdict[/b][/h1]
[b]Rating: 88/100[/b]

In conclusion, Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition emerges as a complete package, successfully revitalizing the classic while introducing meaningful enhancements. With its rich content, refined gameplay, captivating presentation, and commitment to ongoing support for the game, it stands as a must-play for franchise veterans, seasoned fans of RTS games, and newcomers to the RTS genre and Age of Empires series.

AoE 3 DE (and even AoE 3 itself) is a very underrated game both in its series and its genre. Between the diverse civilizations, the units, resources, maps, and cards, you're truly in for hundreds of hours of pure, unparalleled fun.

The upgrades and cards unique to their respective civilizations also parallel real-world events and realities, adding a layer of conceptual depth that gives the game more substance, going beyond surface-level design.

While I don't know if this was intentional or not, the units have memorable voice lines that sort of stick with you after a while. There's only so much a voice actor can do with the few words they are given, and here, most of the units are brought to life with a handful of phrases.

There's also a lot of strategic depth to it made possible by the card and XP system, allowing for a wide range of playstyles. In a similar vein, the natives and revolutions open up a lot of possibilities and keep the game fresh even if you restrict yourself to a few teams.

We may not be living in the golden age of RTS games, but considering how AoE 3 DE is still being updated, it's a blessing.

It is a decent remaster, the network component of the game is infinitely better than the laggy experience of the original, the Swedish and Incas are a fun addition and the changes to the previous civilizations were smartly implemented.

My biggest pet peeve right now is the UX design of the multiplayer, you can't whisper or invite anyone from inside the game (unless you are in a chat channel with them or in their clan), you need to communicate with them outside of the game (Steam, Discord, etc.)
I hope it will get redesigned and this was just a barebones implementation. The original game has a vastly superior online experience, thanks to the UI!

All in all, it is quite a decent game, let's hope they fix more bugs and crashes and improve the menues ingame so the game's online population can strive and become larger.
As I believe that the remaining bugs and grievances will be ironed out soon, I will give the game a positive review.. for now.
If my expectations don't come through come early next year, I will edit this review appropriately.

A handy guide to deciding whether this is the game for you, since reviews and several forums are being raided.

As you can probably see, a lot of reviews and forum posts are popping up about changes that have been invented by their respective OOPs, are complaining about random changes actually requested by the community, or are filled by flaming from members of a few different groups that decided that this game should be review bombed due to political reasons, or because they think it's a waste of time since they prefer AoE2.
So, here is a short summary of actual, concrete pros and cons, as well as a short debunking of the most common made up arguments. Let's have a short FAQ about the misinformation being distributed as a part of the raids at the moment.

Q: Did the devs actually increase the amount of black people spawning for European civs?
A: No. It's the same as it was 15 years a go.

Q: Did the devs change the art style?
A: No. The art style is the same, the models are just more detailed. Some people are experiencing weird blurriness that will cause the game to look more foggy and "cartoony" as some people have put it, but there are a few workarounds (or you can refund and wait until they fix it) if that occurs for you.

Q: Did the devs remove the ability to name and customize your own home city?
A: No. This was an invented flaw, based on the fact that you get stock-home cities instead of having to make a separate one if you want to play a faction. You're able to name your city and explorer, and customize it just as you can in the original release of the game.

Q: Did the devs remove the ability to see units through trees, and see how many home shipments you have available?
A: No. This has to be the most awkward fallacious argument, since the UI elements and unit rendering through trees are there pretty much just as they were with the original release.

Q: I'm seeing some really random reviews complaining about the lack of progression. Why?
A: The "no progression" argument was picked up and hijacked by raiders after (valid) complaints were made by the singleplayer skirmish community about the changes to singleplayer progression. Basically what happened was that they made it so you could play any faction in multiplayer without being handicapped for up to hundreds of games, without grinding first. This was one of the most requested changes, since the existence of the home-city card unlocking mechanic was one of the biggest things that pushed people away from multiplayer when the game first launched. Several good arguments have been made to why the old progression system should be implemented into singleplayer, so we'll have to hope the devs will add that in the future. The singleplayer community's arguments are good, and it's sad that their gripes were hijacked and mangled by raiders and review bombers.

Q: Is this a heavily politicized release, run over by SJWs?
A: There have been some minor changes as well as some clear mistakes from the devs part regarding this topic, but the short answer is no, and this whole topic has been blown out of proportions. The devs basically ordered a short list of things to change from Native American consultants, as well as thought of some changes by themselves. They basically changed a few words in a few text files, and made a few mechanical changes (that were luckily good, as the things that affected game balance were mainly buffs to underpowered things, so the effects of this to multiplayer were mainly positive.) It has to be said, though, there is also a big downside to what they did, in terms of what they didn’t do at the same time. Basically, the changes they made were really lacking, and they didn't follow through with making all of the changes that should have logically been made according to the principles that were used to justify the changes they made. Several really weird things were left unchanged with the natives, and the Asian civs were left in a really janky state in terms of historical representation and accuracy. Several members of the games Chinese and Indian communities have already been vocal about this, so if you're interested in what went wrong with the India and China civs, there are plenty of posts around detailing the flaws there.
Regardless of your political stance, the changes don't really affect the game since the changes being referred to in "OMG THE DEVS ARE SJWs" posts are a few changes to text strings, and if they bothered you there's been a mod that reverts them since day one.

Q: Is this just a bad game?
A: Some people like it, some people don't. If you're seeing pages upon pages of copypasted "AoE2 is the best AoE3 is for retards" threads somewhere, you've just seen an ongoing raid. It's a cringy sight, I know.

Q: Why didn't they increase the unit cap?
A: Because, unlike other AoE games, III is heavily balanced around population costs and AoE damage, meaning that it becomes completely unbalanced and unplayable with a higher unit cap. It probably would have been nicer to have a setting to have it higher in custom games, but it's more of a small oversight that could have been nice for a few people, rather than a big flaw or something highly requested that was left out. This release is extremely multiplayer focused, and a higher unit cap setting wasn't a priority for competitive multiplayer play. If that was something you were looking forward to and won’t buy the game because of this, that’s understandable as well.

Actual pros and cons:
To be fair, let's go through the cons first:
- Some people are experiencing severe game breaking bugs, as well as other visual bugs. Be prepared to wait or refund if you're experiencing these. These include bugs that stop you from progressing in the campaign, connecting to people or seeing multiplayer lobbies.
- No singleplayer skirmish progression, if you're interested in that.
- If you didn't like AoE3 before, you'll most likely not like it now, except if the home city unlocking was your only gripe.
- The game runs very poorly on some systems, so you'll have to try your luck with the games graphical performance quirks.
- The clan and replay functionalities don't work properly all the time at the moment.
- Chinese voicelines and localisation is bad, and in some cases buggy as well.
- Several other localizations are buggy too.

Neutral:
- No public ELO in casual games, so no easy way to filter through casual games based on ELO, but also no ELO sniping either. Some people are really pissed about this, but it also fixed a few large problems with the original release. If this is an issue for you, you'll need to wait and see if the devs implement something to let high-ELO people avoid low-ELO casual games and vice versa.
- As stated earlier, some names have been changed here and there. If this bothers you, there is a mod that will revert the name changes back.

Pros:
- Tons and tons of new content, for both European and Native civs. Also, the Chinese can now use more than one army type. This includes new politicians, a few new mechanics, and an expanded new revolution system.
- Dedication to competitive multiplayer, in terms of both gameplay improvements as well as balance changes. One of the new civs is seen as a bit overpowered still and there are a few kinks left here and there, but if the devs development cycle is anything near to AoE2:DE (which everything seems to be pointing to), the game will be patched regularly. If you'd rather wait and see, that's completely understandable too.
- If you're not one of the unlucky people that have game breaking bugs, the server infrastructure is actually really solid. Cross-continent play is (when not bugging) surprisingly lag free. For example, Europeans can play on the Korean server without practically any gamebreaking lag, which is really nice.
- Fluid, competent and modern UI.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
½ teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Quick advice: for starters, the game needs at least 16GB of RAM and a SSD drive. Close your game completely after a treaty match (especially a long one), or keep monitoring your RAM usage, people with not enough RAM get tired of the HEAVY lags and resigns prematurely. Also keep an eye on GPU usage, the lags are also caused by the GPU dropping to 0% use.

Update III: Even though they tried to address the torps "aura" not being visible on certain terrains the bug is still present, in some maps the aura is not visible at all.
Matchmaking takes a long time to find players and the service fails when it does.


Update: Age of Disaster Part II.
They fixed the cav box, and the BASIC shift+click on banner to select all unoccupied settlers however they ruined all legacy hotkeys, WHAT A MESS.
They added "Ranks" on custom games (kinda), however it shows stats from Ranked games, if you have never played ranked your stats are 0.
And now the disconnection problems seem to be more frequent. This is really an early access game.

Age of Disaster Part I:
Quick Resume: AOE 3 Definitive Edition is worse than many early access indie games on steam.
Please note that my review is focused on Treaty game mode of the game.

I will be listing first the "improvements" over the legacy AOE 3.
+Updated graphics
+Ranked matchmaking for treaty.
and... that's it.

Now let's start with the extensive list of bugs, design flaws and how Microsoft can ruin an old game that only cheaters made look bad.

-How the system makes the teams in ranked matches is awful. I have seen the Top 20 players in the same team and 2 totally new players in the other with awful decks, basically you are condemned to 40 minutes of waiting to a painful 2-3 minutes defeat.

To make the issue even worse, you can invite a partner before looking for a game, the bad part is when the TOP 10 players invite each other and are in the same team. No chance of winning or having fun. It is just NOOB-BASHING.

The game should force Split players based on winning % and rank, and allow them to play 2v2, 3v3 or 4v4 only with other premade teams of similar rank. Using legacy aoe 3 ranks as template, right now the game is letting 2 brigadiers noob bash 2 corporals.

-You can't check other players deck before starting a game, making worse the point above.

-In some maps you can build walls over the water/rivers.

-The game is a bug fest. One team gets to make natives and upgrades while the other not. One team gets to make docks and go fishing/whales and the other team doesn't. Which is a HUGE game changer, especially for Portuguese civ.

-There should be a healthy limit on fishing boats, unlimited fishing boats when only a team can make docks is just unintelligent. A civ shouldn’t surpass 80/99/120 population either with fishing boats or settlers.

-Warships going on land due to bugs

-Legacy AOE3 had a bug were settlers got stuck on mills/plantations. now the bugs are even worse. The Hero/Explorer gets stuck in native trade posts, ARMY get stuck INSIDE mills/plantations, army in general gets stuck in walls (there are gates in front of them and they just stand still), settlers get stuck in trade routes while making walls/trade posts etc.

-Memory leaks all over the place. After each match RAM usage gets incremented by 2GB, until it starts to show heavy stutters until you end up in the "AOE3DE.EXE" is not responding screen. After the last patch, the game uses up to 8GB of ram itself after loading the map.

-Out of sync errors, and teammates getting kicked out 15-20 minutes in-game, sometimes even after loading the map.

And that’s it, we can say the game is pretty much a disaster. UPD for Badge :P

There was a time not that long ago when this game would have been a thumbs up for me. That time has passed and for no good reason. It is as if each update specifically targets something to make it worse.

This game seems to just get more and more unstable as time goes on. The last time I tried to play it crashed twice in a row. I've since uninstalled the game. Likewise, the game now constantly starts "off center" forcing me to "alt+enter" to leave and reenter fullscreen to fix. Why? It literally didn't do this a few months ago.

Alright, you say, graphics and stability are poor, but surely the game is fine? Once, yes. When I started I had a reasonable challenge from the hard A.I. Then they changed it so that hard blatantly gets free stuff to a stupid degree. It has an army twice the size of mine, can replenish that army almost instantly, continue base expansion and age up...with less than half the villagers I have? Yeah. Okay. And moderate AI barely even tries to fight back so fun factor is just completely destroyed.

Graphics, performance and gameplay were all good when I started. Then they broke it and have made no attempt to fix it. Of course I wouldn't recommend this to anyone! 37 hours be damned, I want my money back.

Edit as of 19NOV2023-

Have I put in additional hours? Absolutely. I loved Age of Empires 3 when it came out. I want to love this "Definitive Edition" as well.

Some of my criticisms stand to be modified since this was originally posted. Graphically, the game seems to be fixed and is much more stable. I would wholeheartedly recommend that you make use of the preloader mechanic to load assets before a match starts. It seems to help a lot.

However, I can't truly credit the game and its developers, since graphical stability wasn't even an issue when I first played the game. I stand by my red thumbs down because issues easily could get put in again...

Likewise, difficulty? Hard A.I. still gets magical free resources. They still can fly past me in Ages, tech up, expand their base, deploy an army 2-3 times the size of mine and near instantaneously replace losses to that army...all with far fewer villagers than I possess. It is physically impossible for me to be that incompetent and still possess functional hands.

I still would not recommend this. They fixed the graphics, sure, but they screwed them up in the first place so I'm not giving them credit for taking nearly a year to wipe their bumsies. Likewise, the game really isn't a challenge at Moderate difficulty and it blatantly cheats at Hard.

The additional time reflects periodically returning to the game. It takes about 30-45 minutes to complete a typical skirmish game, so that adds up, but I need to do it to see if the game still has the problems I observed when I was compelled to make this review in the first place.

I stand by what I said. I wouldn't recommend this game...but since I already spent money on it I may as well see if they fixed their product.

I've spent a lot of time playing this RTS in its original CD format. It's a fun Colonial RTS where all the empires of the world try to be the best settlers in the New World. This involves battling other empires for regional dominance. The single player was enthralling as a kid and still hopefully would hold up as a worthwhile time investment for an adult. Multiplayer is where this game gets its longevity. Whether it is the laser shooting flying pigs or the close 2v2 empire vs empire matches the game is a fun one. The home city development and calling cards add depth that isn't too complicated. You can call for units or building upgrades, resources etc. What the card says it does it does and they're separated by Age. There's many DLCs that they are still releasing to this day which is nice. Gotta have good macro to be the best in multiplayer so good luck developing affinity for shortcut button combinations.

Age of Empires III, or as I like to call it, "The Hilarious History Lesson," is like a Monty Python sketch meets a historical reenactment - it's history, but with a side of laughter.

From the moment you embark on your colonial escapade, you'll realize this game is as historically accurate as a time-traveling penguin. But who cares about historical accuracy when you can send armies of flaming sheep into battle?

The graphics are like a Renaissance painting... with a silly hat. Sure, you've got musketeers and cannons, but you've also got monkeys riding elephants and pirates in poofy shirts. It's like watching a period drama where everyone's overdressed for the occasion.

Gameplay is where Age of Empires III truly shines as a comedy. You'll gather resources faster than a squirrel hoarding acorns for winter, and you'll train armies with a speed that defies all logic. It's like running a colony with the efficiency of a caffeinated squirrel on roller skates.

The civilizations are as quirky as your neighbor's lawn gnome collection. Whether you're commanding the French, the Germans, or the Dutch, each civilization is like a box of chocolates - you never know what odd surprise you'll get. And don't even get me started on the unique units; war elephants, pirates, and cows with flaming arrows - it's like a Renaissance fair gone wild.

The campaigns are like comedy shows with historical settings. You'll be part of epic tales that feel more like Shakespearean farces, complete with over-the-top characters, dramatic twists, and the occasional chicken attack. It's like being in a historical sitcom, where you're the bumbling hero who somehow saves the day.

The community is a gathering of history buffs with a humorous twist. Whether you're sharing tales of your ridiculous in-game exploits, discussing the absurdity of some of the unit animations, or competing for the title of the silliest civilization, Age of Empires III players know how to laugh while conquering.

In conclusion, Age of Empires III is not just a game; it's a historical comedy show that parodies the past with a wink and a nod. It's a chance to rewrite history with your own zany spin, to command armies of ridiculous units, and to create your unique brand of historical humor. So, if you've ever dreamt of leading a cavalry of clowns into battle or using flaming sheep as your secret weapon, Age of Empires III is the comedy history lesson you've been waiting for. It's time to don your silly hat, lead your quirky army, and conquer the ages with laughter. To history and hilarity!

Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is a lovingly crafted remaster of a classic real-time strategy game. It features stunning 4K Ultra HD graphics, a completely remastered soundtrack, and all of the original expansions and updates.

The game is set in the Age of Discovery and Colonialism, and players can choose from one of eight European civilizations to expand their empire across the Americas. Each civilization has its own unique strengths and weaknesses, and players must carefully manage their resources and build up their armies in order to defeat their enemies.

One of the things that sets Age of Empires III apart from other RTS games is its focus on civilization development. Players must gather resources, build buildings, and research new technologies in order to advance through the ages. This adds a layer of depth and complexity to the game, and it allows players to develop their own unique strategies.

Another unique feature of Age of Empires III is its home city system. Players can build and upgrade their home city in order to unlock new units, technologies, and cards. The home city system also allows players to send shipments of resources and units to their colonies in the Americas.

Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is a great game for both new and experienced RTS players. It is easy to learn but difficult to master, and it offers a wide variety of content to keep players engaged.

Here are some of the things that I love about Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition:

The graphics are stunning. The game has been completely remastered, and it looks better than ever.
The soundtrack is fantastic. The original soundtrack has been remastered, and new music has been added.
The gameplay is addictive. The game is easy to learn but difficult to master, and it offers a wide variety of strategies to choose from.
The home city system is a great addition. It adds a layer of depth and complexity to the game.
The game is well-balanced. All of the civilizations are viable, and there is no clear "best" civilization.
The game has a large and active community. There are always people to play against online, and there are also many mods and custom maps available.
Overall, Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is a great real-time strategy game. It is a must-play for fans of the RTS genre, and it is also a great game for newcomers to the series.

For me this game was the best of the entire saga, nothing takes away from 2 but for me it was the best for the style of play it has. I was hoping for a modernization of the product with more features, features taken from the eso platform and starcraft2 (RTS made of gold in comparison), an even nicer chat and friends list system than Eso, impeccable balance, detailed (but not invasive) and user friendly, a professional observer screen like starcraft2 or age of empires 2 DE but all this did not happen, none of these points happened, despite the criticisms and advice, the lists written by the players and sent by pro players (especially the balanced of game) the Devs repealed every list every time, they just decided to add useless things, to solve some bugs as it should be but at the same time to make money through Pay to Win DLC where they forced you to buy it if you wanted to play tournaments or competitive (this really sucks). 

The quality of the product that was just released was practically in beta and has been for the whole year including the beginning of 2021. Afterwards, with the various updates they made it a playable game and little by little they fixed or added other useful but also useless things as DLC to buy new civilizations and make easy money while the game didn't even have 1 point mentioned on it, the game started to become more and more complex for new players and for old players who also had to learn the new useless civs with terrible RTS design (including many resources were reused from aoe2 and the wars of liberty mod so they didn't spend almost 1 penny to make these DLCs, including maps taken from the ESOC fan patch and only changed in name).

For me it is not a worthy product, many points are missing to make it finished and competitive but also for those who want to play it for fun, only of the idea that I have to use a third party program to play with a friend of mine because I don't even know when he is online in the I play and I can't search for players because there isn't a mechanism, I don't know if my mate is playing except if I write to him on discord, it's 2023 and there aren't even these mechanisms that the game had in 2005, I would say a bad step backwards with the quality, performance, interface and functionality of the product.

If you liked the Classic Age of Empires 3, you will love DE, in short it has more quality of life improvements and contents, albeit this last part is also a bit of a downer, since it raises the skill ceiling to play it effectively: if there is twice the amount of content, then it means that you would need to learn twice as many things as before! 
This also ensues hundreds of hours spent on the game on the discovery of the various potentials of 22 civs, perfect for those who are curious to explore and have the creativity to develop strategies that this game offers, and this game will never feel dull, because as I stated in the beginning, the devs are still working on this game, every so often they release a patch to shake up some things in the meta!

This has become my favorite Age of Empires game, which I've been playing since the original Age of Empires came out, loved Age of Mythology, and loved and sunk a ton of time on Age 2. But Age 3 has become the one I always come back to.
For RTS Fans unfamiliar or unversed with AoE games:
---
Overall, I'd recommend this game to anyone interested in historical themes (not immensely educational) based in the Age of Exploration of the New World up to the Industrial Revolution, and enjoy relatively fast paced RTS where you can build settlements and engage in combat in the same match space. Its a relatively casual, fun balance of resource management/production, with live time unit based battles in the same space. Everything is self contained in a match, unlike anything akin to a grand strategy or Total War game etc.  

For Age of Empires fans:
I think the main reasons I continue playing and returning to this one are:
+ Having a Persistent Home City to Level Up, Customize, etc (Gives a sense of purpose, albeit relatively shallow, to engage in battles)
+ The variety of the civilizations and how they function mechanically so differently but remain fairly balanced. (I typically only play on Single player, Hard or higher if I'm feeling serious)
+ Having the Deck Builder, I admittedly loathed this feature when Age 3 originally came out, but I've come to love it, because it can give even more variety to civs you enjoy playing with and makes you focus more on specific things or strategies based on your assembled deck.

Like in other Age games, technologies are unlocked as you choose to advance an age (Exploration, Commerce, Fortress, Industrial, Imperial) which can be invested in at a certain resource point during a match. Except in this game (at least for the European/Colonial civilizations), you can choose to Revolt at the 4th to 5th age-up interval as various factions based on your primary civ- many of these factions are not main civs you can choose to start as.

Gaining general XP from units produced, units/buildings destroyed, resource gathering goes toward a Home City shipment counter, each time you hit an XP threshold you gain 1 shipment, which you then choose from your home city deck of your choosing (you can save several loadouts to choose from, however once you confirm which deck you'll use during the match, you're locked into that deck for the duration of the match [unless you choose to Revolt at the 4th to 5th age-up interval, then you are granted a default deck of the faction you've revolted as, which is often not a Main Civilization you can choose])

Units are generally broken up into Melee and Ranged variants of:
- Non Military (Civilians/Settlers/Villagers, Monks/Priests/Surgeons, etc)
- Explorer / Warchief / Heroes (Explorers you start with that have special abilities, and/or area buffs)
- Infantry, Heavy Infantry
- Cavalry, Heavy Cavalry
- Artillery
- Naval
and special units/mercenaries.

Trading posts are present on most maps, which you can build on designated plots, with non-interactable travelling merchants passing periodically. Holding a trade post will grant you XP checks as the merchants pass, later on you can opt out of the XP bonus for specific resources instead. Similarly, there are Native Settlements present on many maps, these also have designated plots for a trading post. Building a post at a settlement grants you an alliance with a gaia faction of the settlement, which grants you the ability to hire a limited number of units (outside your pop limit), as well as various technologies or resource/unit buffs which vary dependent on the faction.

And much more...

[DLW RATED 8.6 of 10 (7=passing)] Age of Empires III, like I and II, is a Real-Time Strategy game, a classic standard of the genre. It's much like StarCraft or Warcraft and numerous others, where you rush about, trying to out-resource collect, out-build, out-technology, out army and finally out-combat your opponent in real-time. I was quite good at AOE 1 and 2, but either I've gotten older, the game has gotten harder or perhaps I've just realized the game and it's AI deal with us humans in a very straight-forward, single formula sort of way, and all we can do to make it more interesting is change the map or, essentially, is change one of it's many difficulty facets, including the one named "difficulty" itself. Maybe a bit of each. The game is colorful, but inevitably it will become the same exercise, again and again, ending when you finally reach a difficulty level that just makes you throw in the towel, for the AI is relentless only mitigated by the speed at which it levels up it's "civilization", and the number of opponents it's against. In the end, larger and larger groups of the enemy visit until, finally, a sizable army that can wipe you out does or doesn't. Survive it.. and the next one, and you know you're probably doing something right, which hopefully includes taking your army on the attack soon. Whether you manage to win 1v1 on Moderate, Hard, etc... will come down to your machine mimicking mind and an obsessiveness that allows you to ignore the relative DOWNSIDE repetition. I could see more fun in these games a decade or so back, but real-time stress makes a turn based game seem very attractive, being more the relaxed experience we associate with the word Game. --- However, playing multiplayer may be just the UPSIDE that makes it all worth it! Good luck and enjoy!

Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition (2020)

I got the original Age of Empires III back on disc when it first released but I never got the game's two dlcs. I was happy to see this updated edition of the game comes with all the old dlcs so after all these years I could finally play them. Age of Empires III changes a lot of things to the gameplay style of the previous titles. You gain experience from playing games and you can upgrade and change the appearance of your Home City of the civilization you played as. You gain these cards you can use during gameplay to send supplies, unites or upgrades as you play a match to benefit you.

The story of all three campaigns was fun and it will keep you busy, it can take a while to complete. Because this is the upgraded definitive edition, they added new expansion packs to buy that allows you to play as new factions never available to the old version of the game. I do not have these expansions but I plan to buy them in the future. If you enjoy Age of Empires, you will enjoy number three. It's a bit different compared to the older games, but it plays extremely well and the graphics is beautiful.

The Graphics are once again, a great upgrade, as is the zoom in ability, it has also improved and the sounds as well.
The biggest improvement for me is the Naval battles and fighting, much more realistic with great animations and sounds.
However, the gameplay is a let down on land in terms of building, resource gathering, repairing and fighting, aside from some formation options.
The UI is also much worse then game 1 & 2 as is some other abilities and options.
For me personnaly i find AoE 2 DE, better, i would even say that AoE 2 DE is better. You can also still play these online so.
Aside from my opinion or facts, its not a bad game so you might like it. however i do not enjoy this gameplay in terms of resource gathering, building, upgrading, repairing, limitations and the UI to control and overview everything.
To give you some examples: You now have tower number limitations, the way you upgrade towers is just not logical, they removed a lot of buildings compared to AoE1&2, you dont need resource gathering buildings, you cant seem to repair boats and other things, you have a worker limitations when it comes to speeding up construction ect ect.
The graphics, sounds and specifically naval battles and also the zoom in has improved a lot but since i could not even enjoy a play through with cheats, i can't recommand this one, based on my great experiences of AoE DE 1 & 2 i really need to make a stand when developers go downhill when calling a game the same but changing the entire game.
They ruined Command&Conquer titles like this, and it feels with this one, they are going down that path with AoE as well.

Like AoE2, AoE3 is for me another classic RTS game. And Definitive edition makes this game much better, than the old game was.

Many great quality of life changes and improvements over AoE II, Including simplifying resource gathering, no longer requiring mines, mills, or lumber yards, which does make gathering resources a little too easy. Base defenses are more limited than 2, but are slightly more effective. Also, unit building is quicker as well. Overall, its a different flavor than 2, since its simplified in so many categories, but its still an enjoyable experience.

My review will obviously be biased as I always loved AoE 3 more than second installment but still, I want to share my thoughts. 

For players that played original version: It's everything you know but more and better. Stable connections, polished graphics, more nations, customization and whatever you want. 

For new/returning players: Game introduces few controversial mechanics when compared to AoE 2 like card system. Basically every nation has a certain customization level in form of cards that you may "send" to your game. Some are upgrades, some are packs of units if you are in dire situation or want to rush enemy. 
But besides that, it's still old schools RTS that relies on micro and macro management. 

For me, this is the perfect RTS experience, slow enough to enjoy it, but fast enough to test your skills. Almost every nations is very different to each other (No more cookie cutter like in AoE 2), cards bring  a ton of replaybality to your nations and each town can be visualy customized. DLC nations are fun but not super OP so we can't talk about pay to win. Music is absolute bop and there is a ton of single player content: 3 long campaings with full voice over, historical battles and challenges. 
Almost every RTS enjoyer should find AoE3 fun and interesting. If you get it at a discount, it's absolutely worht your money and now with free version you may check it for yourself, it literally costs no money for few hours of gameplay.

I had a very negative review of this game originally.  Its launch was absolutely horrendous, and the changes they made were haphazard at best, feeling more like wokewashing than actually intending to do right by the marginalized communities some of the game's factions represent.

They've since fixed a lot of it (still no Nahuatl, though) and even added some excellent and very cool and interesting content with the African expansion.  I can now safely recommend this game and will not be going back to the old AoE3; this continues to be my favourite installment in the franchise.

New "Celebration" patch is absolutely broken.  Unit icons not displaying, reliably crashes, cards broken removing units you can create rather than giving you the new ones the card promises.  If Microsoft wanted to celebrate a broken game, they did a good job.

As a newcomer to the world of real-time strategy (RTS) games, Age of Empires III was my first foray into this captivating genre. With its rich historical setting, engaging game play mechanics, and stunning visuals, this game provided an immersive and enjoyable experience for a beginner like me.

One of the first things that caught my attention was the game's historical backdrop. The setting spans the early modern period, allowing players to take control of one of several European civilizations as they embark on a journey of exploration, colonization, and empire-building. Each civilization comes with its unique strengths and units, adding depth and diversity to the gameplay.

The initial learning curve was a bit steep for me, but thankfully, the game offers an extensive tutorial that guides newcomers step-by-step through the basics. Learning how to manage resources, construct buildings, and assemble armies took some time, but the rewarding feeling of progress kept me motivated.

The graphics and visuals in Age of Empires III are simply breathtaking. The attention to detail in the environments, structures, and units enhanced my overall experience. Whether I was exploring uncharted territories, building bustling cities, or leading my troops into battle, the game never failed to impress me with its aesthetics.

The single-player campaign provided an enjoyable way to hone my skills and experience various historical events. It was both entertaining and educational, showcasing the richness of the time period and the significance of different civilizations' contributions.

However, as a beginner, I sometimes found the pace of game play to be quite fast and overwhelming. Managing multiple tasks simultaneously and coordinating my units during intense battles was a challenge. I would have appreciated a more gradual difficulty curve in the campaign or additional guidance in managing my empire more efficiently.

Despite the occasional challenges, I found myself hooked on the multiplayer mode. Teaming up with friends or competing against other players from around the world added a whole new dimension of excitement to the game. The thrill of facing off against real opponents was both nerve-wracking and exhilarating.

In conclusion, Age of Empires III is an outstanding game for beginners eager to explore the RTS genre. Its historical setting, immersive graphics, and engaging game play offer a compelling experience. While the learning curve may be steep at first, the tutorial and single-player campaign will help you develop the necessary skills to succeed. Prepare to embark on an epic journey through history, and get ready to build your empire to greatness!

I've always liked Age of Empires 3 since its original years ago, but the Definitive Edition not only updates the visuals, it also introduces a whole plethora of new content. A large selection of maps and modes, historical battles and more. Despite my play time I would consider myself a more casual player as I don't engage in competitive online or any meta, but play with friends against the AI. Despite this, I feel all the civilisations are quite balanced at the moment, and more importantly they are all fun to play, with a lot of replay ability being driven from this games deck system (which is not locked behind levels like the original game). 

If you like RTS games I'd definitely give it a go, but just keep in mind if you come from age of empires 2 or 4 that it can play quite differently (no resource drop off point, shipments etc.). Overall though I think the game is great and definitely gets my recommendation :)

Great classic game

it looks better and plays better than the original; has new content in the form of new civs, new balance, new historical battles/art of war tutorials to give people a better sense of their skill before being annihilated in multiplayer.

grinding no longer required for powerful cards, meaning it's suddenly possible to introduce friends to the game without them immediately quitting because they dont want to play for 20 hours before becoming competitive

it's definitely buggy (moreso in lobbies/menus than in game) and crashes occasionally, but I think people who complain about this a lot forget that the original had similar/worse lobby glitches, and a far higher incidence of lag in games, making the new one strictly an improvement. sure, complain that the improvement isn't enough for your standards, but like with aoe2 DE they're still working on it and it will improve over time. and it's a $20 game.

Edit: the lobby bugs and crashes were pretty much all fixed :) at least I haven't had one in like a year

the only people for whom DE isn't a significant upgrade are people who want to grind for card unlocks more than they want new civs, new graphics, and new content. at least they can still grind for cosmetic upgrades to the original 8 home cities like old times.

my primary criticisms are just the performance issues and I think keeping the old visual card-selection trees might've been useful for making it clear to players when some cards are just more powerful versions of others. but these are minor complaints.

overall this game has me enjoying aoe3 more than I even did when it first came out 15 years ago. playing with friends in multiplayer is better than it's ever been, with slowdowns/lag being rarer, slightly less trouble getting into lobbies together, more friends willing to play since they dont have to grind, and balance changes that make a lot of annoying behaviors less-so (such as nerfs to walls).

so easily a strong positive view from me. it's a good buy if you like good RTS.

I like to play this game with friends against AI mostly although I've tried a couple matches against real players.

To keep it short:
-AI isn't great, not even extreme AI. Most of the difficulty comes from the AI just cheating (more resources, faster building etc). Often the AI gets stuck doing absolutely nothing and wakes up only if you attack it. The way AI builds its base is pretty much how the AI built bases in an early 2000 game, c&c red alert 2. There's no sense in anything; there's just towers and castles placed around randomly without utilizing any walls. It's easy to exploit the AI and it gets very repetitive to play against it with its repetitive tactics and issues.

-G-sync doesn't work.

-The game suffers from performance issues especially if there's loads going on. For reference I have an rtx 3080, Ryzen 5800X, 32GB ram and the game is on an nvme ssd. This at 1440p and maxed out graphics. I don't view 60 fps as smooth anymore. 60 is minimum for average fps. Short random dips below aren't too bad but this game seems to never feel smooth. Maybe it's the lack of any sync in combination with mediocre fps.

-About half year from the game's release both me and one of my friends (not all) began to get an issue that sometimes the game wouldn't start at all. Verifying the game's files, restarting PC and trying again the next day didn't work. Then suddenly few days later it again worked and then it didn't. This continued for a long time and I gave up as the game stopped starting at all. Now after maybe 2 years later the game works again. I tried googling around on numerous occasions and couldn't find a solution.

Still, I like to play the game very casually with some friends every once in a while. It's quite fun but as an against AI player I wish the AI was much better, diverse and adapted to different situations. 2vs3 extreme AIs with 80% handicap felt easy the other day even though hadn't played the game for over a year at all and we never were RTS pros - we're casuals.


EDIT: I checked my fps and the game can't even maintain 60 fps most of the time on my PC. It's pretty bad and with 7 AIs and 2 human players the game just breaks in to unplayable stuttering and constant lag spikes.

Age of Empires III Definitive Edition is an exceptional game that truly captures the essence of the original Age of Empires III while enhancing it with stunning graphics and improved gameplay. The attention to detail in this remastered edition is truly impressive, bringing the game to life in a whole new way.

The updated visuals are absolutely breathtaking, with beautifully rendered environments and intricately designed units. The level of immersion is unparalleled, making you feel like you're truly commanding an empire in the colonial era. The improved audio also adds to the overall experience, creating a rich and immersive atmosphere.

One of the standout features of Age of Empires III Definitive Edition is the enhanced gameplay. The developers have taken great care to balance and refine the mechanics, resulting in a more strategic and engaging experience. The addition of new civilizations and campaigns adds even more depth and variety to the game, ensuring that each playthrough feels fresh and exciting.

Furthermore, the multiplayer aspect of the game is robust and well-implemented. Whether you prefer cooperative or competitive gameplay, there are plenty of options to suit your preferences. The matchmaking system works smoothly, allowing you to easily find opponents of similar skill levels for challenging and enjoyable matches.

Overall, Age of Empires III Definitive Edition is a fantastic game that successfully revitalizes a beloved classic. With its stunning visuals, improved gameplay, and extensive content, it offers hours of entertainment for both new players and longtime fans of the series. I highly recommend giving it a try and immersing yourself in the world of Age of Empires once again.
