This review has been written entirely by an AI !

Ah, Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition – where you can rewrite history, one funny mishap at a time! It's like playing with a bunch of tiny, pixelated civilization dolls, and trust me, they have a mind of their own!

First things first, let's talk about the settlers. These guys are the unsung heroes of the game, building houses and gathering resources like they're in a frantic episode of Extreme Makeover: Colony Edition. They're like, "Oh, you want us to build a town center in the middle of a dense forest? Sure, we'll just karate-chop those trees into submission!"

But beware, those settlers can be a bit forgetful too. You tell them to build a farm, and they wander off to the opposite corner of the map like they're on an all-you-can-explore vacation. "Oops, sorry! I thought you said farm, not 'arm and leg' day at the gym!"

Now, let's talk about the combat. It's like a medieval rock-paper-scissors game, but with cannons, muskets, and cavalry. Your troops are the ultimate multitaskers – they'll fight, shoot, and die with the efficiency of an overworked office drone. "I am a fearless musketeer! I shall... oh, never mind, I've been turned into Swiss cheese."

But you can't have an Age of Empires game without some good old-fashioned sieges. Witness the magnificent sight of villagers armed with tiny hammers, taking on massive stone walls like they're in a David vs. Goliath contest. It's like watching an ant trying to knock down a skyscraper with a toothpick!

And don't even get me started on the wonders you can build. Who needs a history museum when you can construct the Taj Mahal in the middle of a chaotic battlefield? It's like your civilization is saying, "While our villages are being pillaged and our people are dying, let's build a fancy tourist attraction!"

But the real entertainment comes from the diplomacy system. You can form alliances with other players, but we all know those promises are as sturdy as a sandcastle during high tide. "Sure, we'll be allies forever!" – Five minutes later – "Betrayal! They're attacking us!" It's like playing a game of "Who can stab each other in the back first?"

But you know what? Despite all the hilarious chaos and wonky mechanics, Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is a classic that's stood the test of time. It's like a nostalgic trip back to the days when conquering the world was as easy as clicking a few buttons. So, gather your settlers, prepare your armies, and let the historical comedy unfold in the most entertaining way possible. Happy conquering, mighty conquerors!

As far as Age of Empires games go, the original release of Age of Empires III was my least favourite title, but remained a solid entry to the RTS series. 15 years later, we get the Definitive Edition, a remaster of the original, including the War Chiefs and Asian Dynasties expansions, with new free civilisations and even more content added through various DLC drops. The final result is an expansive RTS with massive potential for replayability, with many civilisations to test and adapt strategies with.

The lacklustre campaigns from the original game return in this edition, alongside some challenging historical battles which have been included in DLC, but the skirmish and multiplayer modes are where the game truly finds its feet. The home cities mechanic introduced in the original Age of Empires III also returns, which allows you to request help from your empire in battle. It adds an extra dynamic to games, bringing more unpredictability and helps to avoid the repetitive nature which can emerge from RTS titles.

I'd strongly recommend this title and the available DLC to any RTS fan looking to expand their collection.

My favorite in the AoE series. I have a little bit of bias since I love the gunpowder era in world history.

Graphics - holds up real good

Sound - excellent sound design. Cannon fire is always great! Just found some dialogue to be quite jarring (ex. when you select a villager unit from the US faction they'll say "lumberjack", "fisherman", or whatever it is they currently do.)

Gameplay - always fantastic and derives from the AoE formula although there are a few changes which may/may not be to your taste (removal of resource drop-off points and deck-building among others). The AI could feel quite dumb at times though, still, they provide a decent challenge.

And just gotta say, the large variety of units available is very welcome. The European civs may seem a bit same-y (but by no fault of their own - they are almost identical in terms of history) but the other civs really feel unique. For a history buff, that's a positive in my book.

9/10

Performance was utterly terrible when it was first released and while there've been some fixes and improvements since then, in the end, trying to play with 7 ai on large map, with PC better than recommended and with no settings higher than "medium", results in game staying in 10-15 fps range for most of the time.

AI tends to be quite dumb. I had a game where their army entered my city through unfinished walls, and after I finished the walls while fighting them, they decided to retreat - only to reach the wall and just stand there while my soldiers slaughtered what was left, not even fighting back or attacking the wall.


Also it has a really really bad mod browser. You literally have to keep spamming "load more" to see all the mods, otherwise sorting by best will only apply to the first batch that's already loaded. I'm surprised there are thing such as rating the mods or setting their load order, but that's kinda all features there are. 
There's also no proper support for custom scenarios and you will have to manually move the file to proper directory.

The best of the three Definitive Editions right now and if you always overlooked AoE3 (as I have for many years), do yourself a favour and try it now. Everything here has just been expanded and improved in the best way, and under the surface of fun and spectacular home city cards and big cannons making big boom, this is probably actually the most *STRATEGIC* AoE game - mashing buttons doesn't matter here nearly as much as having a good overall strategy and using your brain (!!!), there are so many options and counters to everything that you can experiment forever and it never gets repetitive, and games can have lots of awesome twists and turns. Plus, the game's design just does a great job at preventing all kinds of lazy, annoying "tactics" and enabling actually fun gameplay and epic battles.

This has always been a really good and overlooked game, but this DE has really made it awesome and frankly, I have a lot more fun playing it now than I do AoE2 (which had always been my favourite). There's LOTS to play with now, the new civs are a lot of fun, there are TONS of really cool maps that keep surprising me with how good they all are, everything here just works and it feels like everything here was designed to be enjoyable first and foremost, regardless of playstyle and how chill or serious you want to play, including single player.

Oh, and the AI is also actually enjoyable and interesting to play against, unlike in *certain other AoE "Definitive Edition"*.

Bu oyun benim ömrümü tüketti. Her oynadığımda yeni stratejiler keşfetmek ve bir önceki oyunda öğrendiklerimi uygulamaya çalışmaktan beyin kaslarıma kramp girdi. AOE2DE ve AOE3DE en sevdiğim gerçek zamanlı strateji oyunlarıdır. İkinci oyuna kıyasla daha fazla aktif oyuncusu olduğu için ve daha güncel stratejilerden haberdar olabildiğiniz için oyun size çok güzel bir öğrenme ortamı sunuyor. Oyunu alacaksanız ve imkanınız varsa ek paketleri de satın alabilirsiniz. Birbirinden farklı özellikleri olan birçok medeniyet ekliyorlar. Oyunu belli bir müddet oynadıktan sonra (Elde olan medeniyetlerin hepsini deneyimledikten sonra) ve Karşı rakiplerin oynadığı medeniyetlere hayranlık duymaya başladığınızda ileride DLC almak isteyebilirsiniz. Ben en başta satın alınması taraftarıyım çünkü daha büyük bir seçenek havuzuyla başlamak farklı rakiplere karşı farklı stratejiler geliştirmenize ve yenildikçe sıkılmamanıza katkı sağlıyor.

I never played the original aoe3 but I loved aoe2 and other RTS titles such as Blizzard's Craft games. 
I was, however, let down by aoe4 and I cannot recommend that game to anyone. I heard lots of people say that aoe3 is the "black sheep" of the franchise so I avoided it for the longest time. 

I played aoe4 for like ~10 hours and uninstalled it (it was laggy, boring, ugly and didn't seem to have that much polish)... I played aoe3 de for ~8 hours and I'm loving every second of it! I even bought all of the DLCs pretty much instantly. 

So my take is: Even if you'd have disliked aoe4, do give aoe3 a shot. Don't mind all the negative stuff online. Some people don't like the Home City / Card system or the lack of resource drop-off points. Those never bothered me in this game. The campaign/story is way more interesting than in aoe4 and I think aoe3's story might even be better than aoe2's and that's saying something. 

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Age of Empires III is an absolute blast for any strategy game lover like myself. As a long-time fan of the series, I was thrilled to dive into this installment and I was not disappointed. From the moment I started playing, it was evident that the developers had put a lot of effort into creating an immersive and historically accurate experience.

The attention to detail in Age of Empires III is remarkable. The game takes you on an incredible journey through different eras, allowing you to build and expand your civilization from the ground up. The unique units, structures, and technologies for each civilization make every playthrough feel fresh and exciting. Whether I was commanding a fearsome European army or leading a native tribe to victory, the gameplay diversity was truly impressive.

Visually, Age of Empires III is a treat for the eyes. The graphics have received a significant upgrade compared to the previous games in the series. The environments are beautifully designed, and the animations are fluid and realistic. It's a joy to watch battles unfold and witness the intricate details of the game world. The developers really went above and beyond to create an immersive and visually stunning experience.

The gameplay mechanics are classic Age of Empires, but with some clever additions. The Home City system adds a new layer of depth and strategy. Being able to request shipments from your home country provides a sense of progression and allows for unique tactics. Managing your Home City development while simultaneously building your empire creates a compelling and strategic gameplay loop.

While the single-player campaign may not have the same depth as its predecessor, it still offers plenty of exciting scenarios and challenges. However, where Age of Empires III truly shines is in multiplayer. Engaging in epic battles with friends or other players around the world is incredibly satisfying. The online community is active, and the variety of game modes and ranking system keep the multiplayer experience fresh and addictive.

Although the AI opponents are generally competent, there are instances where their behavior can be a bit quirky. It's not a major issue, but it can be frustrating at times. Nonetheless, the overall enjoyment of the game far outweighs any minor AI quirks.

In conclusion, Age of Empires III is a fantastic addition to the series. It successfully captures the essence of what makes the franchise so beloved, while also introducing new elements to keep things exciting. The historical accuracy, improved visuals, and strategic depth make it a must-play for any fan of real-time strategy games. Whether you're building a powerful empire or engaging in intense multiplayer battles, Age of Empires III offers an exhilarating and immersive gaming experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

What I didn't like was the small maps and the very dumb troop AI that takes about 30 seconds before it will do what it was told to due to it readjusting it's position multiple times. The campaign was also very boring and didn't make much sense half the time, with the exception of the Japanese story.

Overall, AoE 3: DE is not the best RTS I've played but it can be fun and so I'd recommend it to those who enjoy these kinds of games.

I’ve preferred AOE3 TAD over AOE2 back in 2008 and I prefer AOE3 DE over AOE4 in 2023 all the way. Such a well preserved Gem from RTS.

AOE3 DE has great fast paced multiplayer (for strategy game, you know) that focused more on the battles than building eco. Fantastic variety of strategies you can try with using different card decks. Game still keeps updating with content and balancing patches. ATM there are 22 civs that really differs from each other (European civs are more similar though). Unit roster with mercenaries and natives is incredible wide and at the same time you don’t have to learn all of the unit names cause counter system is clear and simple (ROUGHLY: light inf > heavy inf and ranged cav, heavy inf > light cav and ranged cav, light cav > light inf and artillery, ranged cav > light cav and artillery, artillery > light inf and heavy inf).

What I think was better in original AOE3 is the ranking system with titles like sergant, master sergeant, 2nd Lieutenant, etc. I don’t clearly understand what ELO numbers mean without it in AOE3 DE. For newcomers I would highly recommend to learn build orders first for each civ before go into multiplayer. You might start with Otto (free autocreating vills) or French (vills has high HP that help against cav raids a lot). You know, AOE3 community is not very big, but very cohesive… It could seems even a bit toxic at first look, but also enjoyable if you stay in the game.
Lots of mechanics and things in game were revamped/updated in DE; the game is solid and worth playing if you like Age of Empires.

Where to even begin...

I have hundreds of hours into this title, here are some comparisons from the original to the definitive edition.

They have sacrificed core mechanics of the game in favor of historical accuracy despite never being a historically accurate game in the first place. The native civs can no longer tame animals, which was one of their coolest features, and the North American natives can no longer mine and are required to construct an additional building to be able to acquire coin. Changing things in the game to be more accurate and considerate towards people who were presented in the game in a way that was ignorant or even disrespectful is fine, great even, such as changing the names of the civs to what they actually call themselves, but changing core mechanics and lazily introducing them is not. This is an absurd and unnecessary change that is an insult to veteran players.

A major pet peeve of mine is the change from colonial era to commerce era. Are you trying to tell me that a game, that is built around the theme of colonialism, around the era of colonialism and who's entire game play is based around building a colony can't have the colonial era in it because it is too offensive?

 Was colonization an awful thing for many people, YES, absolutely, but it happened and its what the game is based around, the game isn't making it out to be some glorious thing. This change of course does nothing to the actual game play so I'm not going to give up on the game just because of that but it is extremely idiotic and useless.

Home city progression has been almost completely removed. You can still level up your home city, however, it only unlocks the customization options for the visual appearance of your home city and no longer unlocks shipment cards, as you now start with all of them. While this works great for multiplayer as you no longer have to grind of out matches to get the cards you need to stay competitive, it is awful for single player. There is no more sense of progress or goals to work towards and the main replayability of single player is simply gone. This is the change that makes me just not want to play the game, I used to love unlocking and experimenting with different makeshift shipment decks as I worked my way up to the more powerful ones, but that is no more.

The UI is a complete and utter joke. The visual design of it looks as though someone made a bunch of text boxes in Microsoft Word and copied and pasted them onto the edges of the screen. The original AoE III had a UI design that was full of character and had amazing satisfying sounds to match. The definitive edition UI is completely soulless and had ear-piercing horrendous sounds mixed in with some rehashed sounds from the original version that somehow sound worse. To add on to this, the deck editing menu is nigh unusable, its essentially just a massive blob of the possible shipments you can use with very little sorting options. 

The original deck editor showed you what building the card type, what era you could get the shipments in and the progression trees all at the same time, allowing for easy location and identification of each card. In the definitive deck editor you can sort by age or by card type that's it, enjoy, and the cards are in a seemingly random order with no visual separation making it a long unsorted messy list of shipments that fit said categories.

I've heard many other people mention how poorly optimized the game is, but I have had no issues with performance as of yet, so be cautious in checking if your computer can actually run the game. 

One last thing I'll mention about the censorship of history because that is what really makes me nearly down vote this game is that every time one tries to censor what happened in the past to protect the present, what you end up doing is denying the victims their right to have it known that trauma happened to them. There's that old quote that everyone knows, the one that goes "Those who forget their history are doomed to repeat it." Well...

Bad actions by developers should not be rewarded with your money.

The first thing you should know about this is it's a politically correct whitewashing of previous editions of the game. (For some of you, that alone is boycott material.) Personally I'm on the fence about it. Removing the racist tropes and aggressions is one thing. Expecting your "loyal" customers to finance that effort is another thing entirely. In previous editions, there were definitely cringey aspects that would make misc. people uncomfortable, and removing/correcting those to make the game more inclusive is fine. But expecting fans to pay to own the game again -- to literally pay to correct BHG/MS's mistakes -- uh...............

I mean, if you're going to try to be ethical, then why not tone down the predatory capitalism while we're at it?

Which leads me to the selectivity of the revisions...

As a cynic, and a purist, I also have a problem with where to draw the line on the whitewarshing. i.e. not all of the offensive things have been changed/removed. (YMMV and I'm intentionally not going into detail, for brevity and because I'm sure it's well documented on misc. wikis.)

There is perhaps a case to made that "historically accuracy" vs. "artistic license" separates things which remained, vs. were edited, but ... Trying to rewrite history of course you eventually run into the whole collision (no pun) of things like ... y'know ... trying to remove "race-ism" from the game when, in fact, that's pretty much the primary driver of any colonialism, ever. And overall trying to hide barbaric acts of oppression upon perceived "weaker" people in the course of those conquests when it's undoubtedly more historically accurate to surmise that such offenses were plentiful to the extent of being "normal". The whole game is pretty awkward if u think about it that way, right?

That time EA took the blood out of MoH comes to mind. Yikes.

Anyway..............

Overall, I liked the cards & trading posts mechanics and I thought this game was a great evolution of AoE when it first came out.

So at this point, I've paid these guys at least 3 times for it on different media and platforms. ("Check this box if you've paid for this product 3 times over." :P) I'm not happy about that. [i]And[/i] I missed the one on GFWL when it was $0.10. That will haunt me to my grave. I gave in and bought this one on sale of course.

The "definitive" edition isn't anything to write home about in terms of "HD" upgrades. (um... are there any? Looks/sounds the same to me. I really think such claimed upgrades were just a red herring for the political correctness changes -- which, I don't believe are mentioned on the store page. :P) Nothing is really jumping out at me except maybe the wide-angle zoom-out. Something so simple should have been a patch for ppl who owned the game already.

Also they should have upgraded the AI more (allied AI, that is). It seems like they made it worse. Age 1 heroes trying to attack Age 4 treasure guardians (and of course being immediately slaughtered), allies building houses around my Karni Mata (structure that increases gather rate in a radius, which of course you want to build your farms and estates around), dominating all trading posts, never offering tribute even though they ask for it shamelessly, allies with a max-pop army idling half a screen away while my base gets raided, and ignoring my flares, etc.

Queued commands are bugged, attack-move is bugged (the old bug where it wouldn't show the cursor until you pressed the button twice, plus a [i]new[/i] bug, where, it doesn't even attack-move properly!); overall just a half-assed reissue.

Leveling and upgrading your home cities was a fun part of the game -- not only did i buy it 3 times but maxxed most cities 3x, too! -- but this was practically removed. Why?! Not to mention, if u didn't feel like leveling, you could easily do so by playing modded maps, or just editing the .ini!

Then comes all the the DLC add-on civs. And other microtransactions. Yeah. So much for it being "definitive". (It's also been brought to my attention that the free promotions which were frequent when the game first came out have been removed.)

Won't be surprised when they release the "refinitive, definitive" edition in another few years. Will we all be vegan and atheist by then, so hunting, fishing, whaling, priests, churches, religious ceremonies and other references etc. all have to be removed? Of course we'll be pacifist, too, so ... bye bye combat. We'll just build villagers and econ buildings. GG.

AOE III has everything you'd expect from the series and all the usual elements combining managing your settlements resources and waging war on your enemies.
A few quirks added with the trade route and "treasure" replacing relics.
This edition has 3 main story lines to follow with the third Asian Dynasties containing three smaller series of campaign levels. I must say the campaigns did feel quite short and some scenarios felt a little pointless and far too easy and quick.
Personally I prefer AOE II or AOE IV to this edition, partly for the lack of game play compared to AOEII, I hope there will be more DLC campaigns added in the future to bring me back to the game.

You can build your own maps, and do one of multiplayer, so has play ability in that sense, but I'm a fan of the campaigns myself.

All in all a game worth playing.

Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is an exceptional strategy game that successfully brings together historical accuracy and engaging gameplay. The new features in the enhanced edition such as graphics and sound, the additional civilizations, the campaigns and the quality-of-life improvements make for an impressive gaming experience that exceeds expectations. The multiplayer component is also incredibly fun, with plenty of replay value and a strong online community. There are a variety of multiplayer options, allowing players to challenge friends or team up against others in epic battles. Gameplay is smooth and intuitive. There is an impressive amount of detail and for a lack of a better word ‘charm’. The gameplay mechanics are refined making it easy for newcomers to learn the ropes, while also providing plenty of depth for seasoned veterans. Overall, Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is a must-play for any strategy gaming enthusiast, and a testament to the timeless appeal of the Age of Empires franchise.

As someone who has put in 250 hours into Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition, I can say without a doubt that this game is a must-play for fans of the RTS genre. The definitive edition of the game brings updated graphics, improved gameplay mechanics, and a wealth of new content to the table.

The gameplay in Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is incredibly engaging, with a wide variety of units, civilizations, and strategies to choose from. Whether you prefer to rush your opponents with a swarm of soldiers or build up a massive economy and overwhelm them with advanced technologies, there's something for everyone in this game.

One of the things I appreciate most about this game is the attention to detail that the developers have put into it. From the unique strengths and weaknesses of each civilization to the historical accuracy of the units and buildings, it's clear that a lot of thought went into every aspect of the game.

Of course, no game is perfect, and Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition does have its flaws. Some players may find the pacing of the game a bit slow, especially in the early stages. Additionally, the game can be quite challenging, and players who are new to the RTS genre may struggle to keep up with the fast-paced gameplay.

Overall, I highly recommend Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition to anyone who is a fan of RTS games. With its engaging gameplay, attention to detail, and wealth of content, this game is sure to provide hours of entertainment for both casual and hardcore gamers alike.

Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is a wonderful real-time strategy game that takes you on a journey through different civilizations and historical periods. As an AI language model, I am unable to experience the game myself, but based on my vast knowledge of the gaming world and reviews from players, it is an outstanding game.

The game has stunning graphics, detailed environments, and a great attention to historical accuracy. The game offers a variety of modes, including a campaign mode that immerses players in a series of historically accurate scenarios. Additionally, players can compete against each other online or engage in co-op missions with friends.

The game is very engaging, and it has been praised for its challenging gameplay that requires players to balance their resources, build and maintain their armies, and expand their territories. The game's mechanics are easy to understand, and it offers a great tutorial system to help new players get started.

Another great feature of Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is its soundtrack, which immerses players in different cultures and eras with its well-composed music. The voice acting is also excellent, with each civilization having its own unique voice.

Overall, Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition is a fantastic game that offers a rich, immersive experience for players. Its attention to detail, engaging gameplay, and stunning visuals make it a must-play for fans of the real-time strategy genre.

If you liked Age of Empires III gameplay, you'll like this. Fair warning, you are basically paying for a slightly better looking AoE3 with two new civs. Now mind you, if this was any other game you'd probably be ok paying $15 for two new factions, or rather you wouldn't be ok with it but you would do it anyway. Consider that, and consider that you also get a discount on this if you own Age III.

A note on Historical Revisionism:

As someone with a BA in History, and who understands the current political climate, I understand and support why you changed the names of the Sioux and Iroquois to their preferred name. That doesn't bother me in the slightest, and it really has only positives for people of those backgrounds and cultures to support their representation. However, I find it problematic that you are attempting to erase the word Colony/Colonial from a game that is about the whole colonial system. You guys felt the need to apologize for creating this game in a climate that generally had no issue with these words, and you changed them to appeal to changing political climates. What you fail to understand, is that at least your campaign does a good job of explaining the brutal and unjust nature of imperialism and colonialism. The whole India campaign is an amazing scorch of British imperialism, as the Warchief section is a scathing and honest representation of US imperialism.

By changing terms and pretending this game is something it's not, all you're doing is attempting to conceal history. Terminology matters when discussing history, changing terms makes no sense. In the academic community, we don't alter colonialism from our terminology, rather, we acknowledge it for what it is/was and write or study it. Also, be mindful this game greatly exaggerates all societies and communities, and while some portrayals can be considered unsavory in our 2020 world, just note that the European communities represented are also stereotypes. Why is this important? Because it's a VIDEO GAME!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

So I've been playing the Age of Empires series since the very first game was released so many years ago. I spent many hours at LAN parties playing it with friends and family.  AoE3:DE is better in every way than the original. To be fair, i don't play multiplayer anymore, my gaming circle rarely plays RTS games together, and when we do, its usually Starcraft 1 in memory of an old friend.  But single player is more solid than the original.At first, I was worried that with making all cards unlocked at the start there would be no reason to bother leveling up home cities, but thankfully they've added customization options to each civ that makes it more fun to level each of them up.Gameplay wise, they've tightened up many areas, improved balance, and made the AI less stupid, but still not smart. Now, on island levels, I no longer find them unable to cope with the concept and stuck on their island.  They now send troops to other islands and the mainland... but they usually never send workers, so they get hamstrung by a lack of resources and building space eventually.  But its a definite improvement over of the standard edition where island levels were a gimmie.  I actually love the fact they tried to make the Native North American civs more true to the culture of the tribes they're based on.  I usually roll my eyes at pandering in games, but this actually feels right.  Trying to be more accurate to history and the cultures in question.  But i do miss their ability to tame any treasure guardian.  It was fun.  Revolution mechanics have been improved and made useful.  I love the added options this gives me to make games different.The expansions since release have been fun, I particularly enjoy Ethiopia and the Italians.  I hope that they add an Oceania expansion, giving us maps in the Pacific Islands, Australia, and one or two civs, like maybe the Maori and the Hawaiians.  Even if they only do one, there's potential there.

+++Fun multiplayer

Critics that say that AOE3 was always the worst of the 3 Age of Empires games must have never played AOE1. 

AOE3 is back, and this isn't a Definitive Edition like Warcraft 3 Reforged. This is a finished product. Buy it. The critics that put this in the 8.5/10 range had it correct.

Update 2-4-21: The last 2 patches have fixed the vast majority of multiplayer bugs that I'm aware of. They also have been proactive on the balancing different civs. In the latest 2 patches they have adjusted the Swedes by nerfing then slightly buffing, nerfing the Incas, and buffing the Chinese.  Player population levels are around 2500-5000 at any given time, and it's fairly easy to find a multiplayer ranked game. 

I think more AOE2 players need to give this a shot. Each civ is far more unique than in AOE2, between your card desks which includes unique cards, units, and resource bonuses. 

Developers need to keep it up.

Update 4-13-21: Developers have kept it up. They've added more bug fixes, optimizations, balance tweaks, maps, features, and now a new civ (The Americans). They still need to keep the bug fixes and optimizations up to polish it even further.  The African expansion is coming out  later this year. I'm having an absolute blast. Balance right now is better than it ever was with the original version of the game.

Updated 3-21-23: New civs, cards, maps, and balance. Far zoom out has been added! AOE4, take note!

This isn't a review of the game's multiplayer. 
When it comes to RTS games, I'm a filthy casual. No fancy shortcuts, no grand strategy... 
I'm really just in it for the resources hoarding, the upgrades and the attention to detail with things that honestly really don't need it.

Ever since my first playthrough of AoE 1 all those years ago, I've always been about meticulously building my "city", landscaping it, and seeing what lies at the end of the tech tree. It's always been very satisfying.

One thing I always loved about the AoE games was their diversity. 
Lots of civilisations, lots of unique buildings, lots of unique destinations, and the history lessons.

AoE 3 was always lacking in the latter, but this re-release sought to correct the record. And I love it for it!
Where AoE 3 shined in my opinion was the sheer variety...

You have Civs that can break into other civs mid-game with their own advantages and drawbacks, a mountain of unique troops that can vary depending on which map you're playing... VISUAL TRANSFORMATION OF UPGRADED TROOPS!!! I always loved that one.

So yeah, I won't tell you about the merits of X strategy vs Y, about how falconets are OP or how this civ gets cumstered by others. I know nothing about that and frankly don't care.
But I WILL tell you about how this game looks great for its age, and how diverse it is!

I got into Age of Empires 3 through a close friend, when I was 12. This game ticked all the boxes for me, from the get go: history, battles, a great campaign. But I had no idea how much this game would consume my life for the next two years or so.  It was a gateway into history from other parts of the world, into battle dioramas, maybe even into writing! It set my imagination free. And for that, I loved it.

Fast forward to 2023. I'm currently finishing my master's degree, I'm working full time, and so life is not quite as bright and carefree as it was, 10 years ago. But for the 50 hours that I played this game (campaign, historical battles and a few skirmishes), I was a 12 year old again.

Age of Empires 3: Definitive Edition is a game that has disappointed many fans of the franchise. Despite being marketed as an improved version of the original game, the optimization is poor, and the graphics are even worse. The game struggles to run smoothly, and the visual upgrades do little to enhance the overall experience.

One of the major problems with the Definitive Edition is the lack of improvement to the gameplay. The new AI is a far cry from the old one, and often freezes or fails to react appropriately. This can be frustrating for players who are used to the smooth and seamless gameplay of the original game.

Another issue with the game is its pay-to-win mechanics. The introduction of new factions and the ability to purchase upgrades has changed the game's dynamic, making it less enjoyable for those who prefer a more balanced experience.

Additionally, the timeline in the game is broken, and the inclusion of the USA in the timeline makes little sense. The Ottoman Empire, in particular, is stuck in the 16th century, and requires a new age with new types of units. The current system of cards is not enough to sustain late-game play, and the lack of a proper rework for both the German and Ottoman factions is disappointing.

In conclusion, AOE III: Definitive Edition is a disappointing cash grab that fails to live up to its name. The optimization and graphics are poor, the new AI is frustrating, and the pay-to-win mechanics are a major drawback. The broken timeline and lack of proper rework for the factions make it a game that is best avoided by fans of the franchise and strategy games in general.

Age of Empires III Definitive Edition - Review.

Bugs/Glitches/Lag.
Sometimes during big battles (200 or more Units) the game lags a little, not a lot but it still lessens the experience overall.

Graphics.
The Graphics are superb compared to the original in fact its down right beautiful in my opinion, the units and maps are wonderfully built and modeled.

Why my Review is Negative.
Let me start this off by stating that I loved the original Age of Empires III, the Campaign was amazing and I still remember a great deal of it even now many years later.
People have pointed out that you are given every Nations Cards right at the start rather then earning them as you level up your Nations while yes for online play this is more then fair, in single player mode I would have liked to earn the Cards like in the old version made you do and this lessened the game for me if only slightly.
So why the Negative Review then, the changing of Character names is alright with me I don't mind it that much at all and if it is based on real historical accuracy then why not in my opinion.
So you ask "what made this Review Negative then?" well here it is... the fact that the games Campaign was changed to the point that I did not recognize the 5th Act at all is enough for my Negative Review, but what angered me to the point of wishing that not only had I never played this almost sacrilegious version of the game I found myself wishing they had not made this version at all and they had simply ported the old game over to Steam as it was, My hate of this "re-imagined" game is so great that I found myself wishing that I had never even played the Original version of the game at all so that my childhood was not attacked so violently, the new "voice acting" was so bad it felt like a MOD made by 8 year old's and the "dialogue" was such that I found myself regretting being born with ears at all, the Snowflake language and apologies at the start, the $hlt dialogue, the changing of stories to be more "modern" and "progressive" has made me hate what was once a great game, "but Arch ask for a Refund" no I will never ever ask for a refund every time I open Steam I want to see this game I want to never ever lose the feeling of betrayal and hate that I feel now for this version and for the Snowflakes that made it, shame on you all for doing this to such an amazing game and story.

In closing if they give you this game for FREE with a $5.000 Steam Gift Card thrown in don't take it it's a trap go find the Original and play that version, don't ever pay them for this game they need to know that what they did was wrong and unforgivable.

I grew up with Age of Empires. I played all of them from the beginning.
I love them all (Age of Mythologie included, that's the second best in my opinion) but I have to say that AoE3 is absolutely my favorite.
I just adore the different playstyles every single Civ offers and that every one of them can also be played in different ways thanks to the Homeshipment system.
Every Civ feels so unique, especially since every one of them has multiple different special units (and a lot of times: buildings) exclusive to them.
And I'm so happy that until today, they still create new and exciting content to expand on this with new Civs and updates for the old ones.
Don't get me wrong, I love AoE2 (the "best" Age for most people) a lot, especially because I'm an absolute nerd about everything medieval.
But gameplay wise and because of the huge playstyle variety, AoE3 just outperforms all other Age titles, in my opinion.

The game centers on unit combat, since everything else is pretty bar-bones. Base development, setting up defences, technology progression - all feels shallow. So, is comabt good enough to carry the game?

No. Unit pathing is horrible. Ships bounce off each other like low-weight bumper cars. Health bars are barely visible for most colors. Targeting specific enemy units is a gamble. Models are generic and hard to differentiate. The AI is a joke: It often does not change its unit pathing when coming across your units, leading to a turkey shoot where the turkey doesn't even have to good sense to react and run away. 

The deckbuilding and home city system is just another tech tree, adding no interesting new systems and complexities. Just filler.

AoE 3 is an absolutely unappreciated game. If you hear and read about the game these days, it is usually referred to as the "worst part of the Age series" and the "black sheep", even though the game received very good reviews when it was released.
I wonder, why is that? Is it because it is really bad? Or rather because it is overshadowed by AoE 2?

Either way, AoE 3 is an absolutely fun game. Time wise, it takes place directly after AoE 2 in the early 16th century and goes on until about the end of the 19th century. Where knights and swordsmen used to dominate the battlefields, muskets and artillery are now to be seen.

As someone who grew up with AoE 2 and first tried the game 10 years ago, I downright hated AoE 3 because it was too different for me. As I've looked more into the game with the DE now, I've realised how good the game is when you don't look at it through the partially nostalgia-soaked AoE 2 glasses. The game has many ideas that can now be found in AoE 4 (e.g. the Ottoman vizier system, which is very similar to the home city system) and are celebrated by players there.

Speaking of the home city: as an AoE 2 player you have to think of it like freely choosable civ bonuses. You put together a deck with up to 25 cards for the first four Ages that grant you various bonuses, e.g. settlers, units or resources.

The maps themselves are a little more lively and interactive due to the collectable treasures. These are RNG-based and offer various bonuses, such as resources, units or permanently additional HP for buildings. There are also native settlements on the maps that provide units and technologies, as well as trade routes that grant experience or one of the three resources.

Something I still can't stand, though, is the snaring mechanic. This temporarily slows down units that were hit from behind, which makes the controls a bit inaccurate for me.

As an AoE 2 main, I can recommend AoE 3, as well as the rest of the series, to everyone. If you were turned off by the game back then, give it another chance with DE.

Age of Empires III is good but it doesn't take much playtime to see that it was made to compete more directly in a high-level competitive/e-sport context and as such, it feels rather limited in scope and mechanically limits players who have no interest in high-level competitive/e-sport style play. 

  So since this is a review of the definitive edition and all three of the classic Age of Empires titles have been out for a long time now, it is pretty much impossible to review this one without comparing it very directly to the prior releases. As a whole, AoE and AoEII are much more open, much more versatile experiences that can give just about any kind of RTS player something to enjoy. In comparison, AoEIII has much, much smaller maps, oppressive feeling unit/structure caps, and very simplified mechanics. It isn't bad but in comparison to the others, it isn't nearly as good. 

 There are going to be players that want a very tight, very focused competitive friendly experience and in that capacity, the game is pretty decent. For those that want something that hearkens back to the older titles, it will be a constant struggle to deal with the restrictions placed in your way. Matches don't really get any room to open up and breath. Nothing feels very epic in scale. 

  Again. It isn't a bad game. It is good at what it is trying to do. It is just a shame that they tried to shoehorn competitive style mechanics into a franchise that doesn't really needed it.

My favorite time period and thus my favorite AoE. Yep I like it better than 2, Mythology, 4, and of course 1 lol. Own them all and play them all and this one is just the best. The music. The atmosphere. The units. People gave this one so much shit when it originally came out for no good reason. If you enjoy Age games, RTS games, and/or the Enlightenment time period then get this one. You can play as filthy natives, you can play as Euros, whatever you like. Cannon spam is fun and the physics are funny. Cannon send ppl flying. 

It's just an HD update, adds a few civs and maps, and before you complain about the UI you can change it to the original. Looks great, but still should run on most potatoes.

I'd say this was worth it if you were particularly interested in multiplayer meta, new civs or ui improvements, or if it's on sale- but otherwise just stick with the original. The original holds up fine looks wise, runs better and doesn't have a bunch of DLC fluff or sanitised name changes.

Nothing like AOE2, so if you only like that style of RTS, avoid this. In a vacuum though, this game is quite fun, and the time period is fun as well. The unit counters are quite a bit more complicated than AOE2 though, so don't come into this game thinking it's easier.

AOE3 vs AOE2

UNIT COUNTERS are much harder in AOE3 compared to AOE2.

CIVS are much more varied in AOE3 compared to AOE2. In AOE2 you can play most civs without fully understanding them as they all are very similar. In AOE3, each civ is almost entirely different, so you have to commit more to learning each civs playstyle.

ECO is MUCH easier in AOE3 compared to AOE2. Very little micromanaging in comparison. If you hated AOE2's eco management, this might be the game for you.

A glitched mess of a game, map generation errors, somehow worse AI, awful performance for graphics that *feel* marginally better than the old game, and completely out of theme new additions to the game like New World early XIX civilizations in a game that is largely set in the XV-XVIII centuries.

Possibly my worst gripe of them all is how the interface is even worse than the original game, ugly and out of place... And how all the annoyances that made AOE3 less good such as all ranged units attacking the same target, taking forever to pick a new target, and generally acting dumb are still here and worse than ever... This is not an upgrade that we saw in AOE2 DE, this is not the same work of love meticulously put together with care to make the true definitive version, I cannot recommend it.

As a remaster / modernized version, the game good. All the textures, vfx, etc. is updated yet remains extremely close to the original. The new UI is there for more modern standards but you can restore the original one and even mix-and-match parts of both (and the original of course supports all kinds of resolutions, just like the rest of the game up to 4K). 

I never bought this to play multiplayer so I cannot say how fun that might be, I'll just say that the game recieved a LOT multiplayer balance updates and even new nations in form of paid DLCs (which could be earned for free around release with grinding games). 

I however, sadly experienced a lot instability and crashing without and error message during the campaigns which was not present on release, only after many patches, however ultimately made me quit playing because they were so frequent, and customer support just vanished in the middle of our conversation after I provided them everything they asked for. Gave it another chance another year later and now I can play it again without any crashses, so who knows? It might be perfectly stable for me now, it might not remain so. Fair warning. 

If you want to play multiplayer I'd strongly advise to pick up AoE4 instead, however if you are in for the nostalgia and leveling up cities and such, AoE3DE is just as good as the original AoE3 was, except more content rich, updated to modern standards, and could be a bit unstable depending on the patch version.

To preface I only bought this game to play the campaigns. This review does not factor in how the multiplayer is as well. 

This game absolutely sucks. I played a lot of this game as a kid and I may be blinded by nostalgia, but it was infinitely better when on a disk. Firstly, the pathfinding is still god-awful. In some of the areas the ai just refuses to go in an area, despite it being a totally valid spot for them to go. I've lost armies in missions and had to restart because I tell them to go somewhere and they, simply, don't. Secondly, the AI on hard (which is all i've played on) is just pathetic. It's a 50/50 with what you'll get whenever you load into a campaign game. You might get an AI that actually pressures you, albeit with their starting troops, or you'll get an AI that shits the bed, doesn't build any troops, and sits in its base until you complete whatever horrible objective is designed for this mission. Oh wow can't wait to have to build up 6 arty pieces and go destroy a fort again. Can't wait to have to do that for every single mission. It's just boring and recycled gameplay. And come on, in game cutscenes STILL? It is literally 2022. The view actual cutscenes in this game look amazing but they're tainted by the in-game cutscenes' mere existence. They're just ugly and the studio is obviously capable of making real cutscenes, but they just don't want to.

Edit: Also unit and building caps? Are you joking? What is even the point? What a lazy and shit way to balance your game.

The somewhat maligned successor to Age of Empires II (AoEII), Age of Empires III brings several innovations and challenges over its well-regard predecessor. The main innovations/challenges are (i) the fast pace of the game and (ii) the highly-differentiated nature of the factions. This makes makes the learning curve steeper for beginners especially compared to AoEII.

Fortunately, in the Definitive Edition, there are now learning scenarios ("the Art of War") geared to helping newcomers master basics for single-player as well as multiplayer. There is also a plethora of good-quality videos created by aficionados on YouTube. These tutorial videos are also helpful in understanding the roles and strengths and weaknesses of the different units (e.g. musketeer vs skirmisher, culverin vs falconnet)

Moreover, the strong differences between factions makes for a very unique playing experience each time, not only between the major faction "families" (African, Indigenous American, Revolutionary American, Asian and European), but also within these families (e.g. Dutch vs French, Ethiopian vs Hausa, Mexico vs United States).

This game is very much alive, with many free comprehensive updates/balance changes released by the developers, a strong multiplayer scene and high-quality DLCs (especially the Knights of the Mediterranean, but the African Kingdoms was also innovative). Personally, I would like more historical scenarios to allow me to get to grips with the factions in the same way that AoEII did. However, I can only commend that time that the developers are devoting to develop new fully fleshed-out factions (e,g. Ethiopia, Italy, Hausa, Malta, Mexico) and new maps/game modes (e.g. Tycoon). Besides, there is already so much content in the game that one can acquire the DLCs (or not) when one is ready to try out new factions: no need to buy them all at the start to enjoy the "complete" experience.

All in all a thoroughly enjoyable experience if you are willing to invest the time to understand the game.

Let's get this out of the way first: yeah, they altered the Iroquois and Lakota campaigns, the latter even more so than the former, to put the afromentioned indigenious in a better light, despite the original campaigns already making this point clear. Also there was some renaming on some terms, which you can reverse using mods.

Now on the positive points, starting with the mods: there is full Mod integration and no unfair contract clauses (like a certain other company tried to do); at launch, the game was rough when it comes to optimization, but constant updates sorted that out; Two (also Italy with the DLC) Civilizations that were originally cut from the original release, many new maps, being introduced constantly, the old Italians 'rescued' from early development as well as completely NEW Civs in DLCs introducing African and full-ledge Revolutionary American Civs; speaking of which, the old Revolution option is still there for Europeans and has been expanded to include more nations; new single and multiplayer modes; events with rewards that can earned by just playing the game; new customization for Home Cities that didn't had it; the entire card progression is unlocked from the start, the levels only unlock said customizations; and much more being worked on by the developer.

This game received a unlikely second chance and it's using it well, standing it's ground despite the domination of II and now IV.

No. Just no. 
I have played age of empires since the 2nd one was released in the late 90's. I also played age of empires 3 before the remaster. This will mostly concern my experiences with online-play. Having now played over 700+ hours of this since it's release i have come to a definitive conclusion. It's garbage. And i don't say that lightly. Mind you, if you are looking for a casual "strategy"-based game (i say "strategy" because i don't think the game involves much strategy anymore, more on that below...) then you might give this a go. But for someone like me who has been a big age of empires fan for most of my life, this game makes me both sad and angry. Of course, here are of some good aspects of this game, but most of that is down to the previous work done by Ensemble Studios. And while the new team has taken to improve certain aspects and mechanics that the original had problems with (such as out-of-sync errors) one should not ignore the massive steps (in the wrong direction) that have been taken when introducing DLC or when the game is being patched. To list all the issues i have - and there are MANY - would take a long time, so think it will suffice to say that whereas there was once numerous ways of winning a match, and the game was more reliant on the concept of 'rock-paper-scissor' when fighting with units. This sense of balance is now of course history, and with each new (ridiculous pay2win) DLC or even with major patches and updates, the game moves further away from skill-based game play. Instead, one is able to win easily by just using one type of unit no matter what your opponent uses against it. With every new patch a new feature is introduced that ends up being ripe for abuse, and there is almost always a guarantee of there being a bug or glitch added in the process that ends up having to be patched a week or two later. It reeks of incompetence and ignorance of how or even why some mechanics existed in the first place - and that's not even mentioning the DLC's that have been added since its release that ads yet another stupidly designed nation (enter Sweden, USA and Mexico) that is almost a guaranteed win if you know the basics. This has damaged me to the point that sometimes i eve take to removing players from the matches i host just because they play as a certain civilization. There is no balance or even understanding of the word. But i get it. of course they have to make every DLC attractive, which sadly involves the practices stated above. In a perfect world, one would hope that no developer sacrifices balance in favor of the promise of fat green stacks of money. For those of us who wish for a skill-based strategy game, one should definitely look elsewhere. This game is not for you, at least its not for me.

While it may always live in the shadow of Age of Empires 2, Age 3 has always been a great game, and this Definitive Edition makes it something truly special, worth a purchase by any fan of real-time strategy.

The thing that makes this game great is that every expansion and every refinement of existing mechanics has been done based on community feedback. The Forgotten Empires team obviously pays close attention to what the players would like to see and do, which is critical to keeping an old game like this feeling fresh and relevant. They've also done an excellent job at expanding the game to include interesting new civilizations and maps the fans have always wanted to see, like the United States, Africa, and most recently, Europe. Yet even without any of the DLC's, the base game still includes the original 2 expansions (The War Chiefs & The Asian Dynasties), which is a great deal by any metric.

I happily recommend this game, especially for fans of the interesting time period.
This game is hard to put down. And it's worth buying all the DLC.

[h1]A beloved franchise that has tried to be better in the past. They've taken a step back because of the new route they've chosen.[/h1]
　Despite that I have played hundreds of hours in the original CD version in the past, Age of Empires 3 DE introduces a significant change that STILL won't be able to alter people's opinions of the third entry in the Age of Empires franchise.

[H3]Review :[/h3]
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]　　About[/th]
        [th]　　Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Art/Graphic[/td]
        [td]　
　It's great to see classic games being updated or remastered to meet modern gaming standards. There are many visual improvements in Age of Empires III over its predecessor. The high resolution of the new texture is very pleasing to the eye. The story character now looks sharper than ever. Physic is now kind of different, and building or ship destruction has more particles. The quality of the effects is also better than ever. Overall, it looks great.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay[/td]
        [td]　
　Here's the problem with AOE III. Many people still hate the original because the gameplay is so different from AOE II. Back in fort units while gathering is removed, the rock or stone resource is gone, and AOE III does feel faster than the successful previous game.

　Here the things I remember I enjoyed AOE III when it first time release even many people hate it, it has it's own gameplay, it's own visual, and the gameplay was quietly kinda new for me at the time. when the definitive edition has been announced. I'm really excited to see AOE III in its new look. But when I played AOE III, DE, I don't even know why it felt more frustrating than I remembered. Many civs, including their own playstyle, have been updated, and the changes are significant. Consider AOE II, where almost all of the civs have the same gameplay mechanics as the base, and the difference is in the bonuses each civ provides. But in AOE III, DE, it's not just a bonus that's changed, but their main gameplay mechanics have also changed.

　I don't mind about the Asian mechanic to build a wonder to progress to the next age. But the thing I really hated about the DE was how we produced villager. I don't remember all civs having a different way to produce villager. Well, I know a civ that allowed us to produce multiple villagers at once, but in the DE, many of them got changes of each civ. That stuff added extra time to learn, the card system still exists, I know it was balanced enough. But the DE feel like we need more micromanagement, For example, native Civs that need a building to collect coins. Wow, that's kind of adding more clicks, isn't it? Different Civ, various things. I don't say the DE gameplay was shit, but for me it was sluggish and felt weird.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]　
　Played multiplayer and was rushed by a pro-enemy 10/10, I would not play online again.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Control[/td]
        [td]　
　No issues using the mouse and keyboard.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Music or Sound[/td]
        [td]　
　It's a little disappointing that they haven't created as many new songs as they did for AOE II.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Playtime[/td]
        [td]　
　18 to 62 hours Playtime may increase if they decide to add new civilizations or DLC in the future.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Story[/td]
        [td]　
　I enjoyed AOE III's story mode the most. Unlike the previous game, which only used voice, the characters in this one have animation. I don't believe I have many criticisms of the storyline. I'm not sure. Western history was never taught in school. Even today, I don't think Majapahit existed because I've come to realize that many schools in my nation still teach out-of-date material that won't prepare students for success in real life. Here, money always makes people successful, and I had to learn that the hard way. Welcome to the modern Age!
　[/td]

I am utterly amazed by this. I loved the original but this is where it's at. There's some bad but mainly good to say about this. First of all they have kept all the core game mechanics the same, but the game looks stunning. It totally brings it up to par with modern RTS releases, making it a very worthwhile addition to any strategists' game library. The combat and gameplay is still as funny, vibrant and challenging as I remember it. I have a few minor critique points:

1. Political correctness
It really is not a big deal, but PC (it is of course circumstancial) bothers me at times. In this game they have renamed the natives from the original into more political correct names, for example the Iroqouis is now Haudenousaeunee (I did not misspell it on purpose but damn, what a name). I understand where they are coming from but come on, Iroqouis is how it's commonly known in English....

2. New civilizations (are great! ADD MORE!)
They have added new civs with DLCs at a reasonable price (coming from an EU4 player hahahah). I love the new civs especially Mexico, Malta and Italy, and also the Swedish added to the DE. But come on! Add some more. I have a few suggestions that I think would be really cool additions to the game:

Polish (Poland-Lithuanian Commonwealth)
Danish (Denmark-Norway / Danish Colonial Empire)
Persians (Persian Empire had many conflicts with the Ottomans)
Koreans (Well I just want more Asian factions...)
And an additional Native American faction, possibly the Cherokee or Comanche would be cool.
Additionally another African nation such as say the Songhai would be awesome! But for me I find Poland and Denmark to be the top priority given the game's setting.

Super underrated game!

This was the second game that was rated above E that I ever played from back in the day (first being Age of Mythology). I was happy to get a version with improved graphics, but I forgot just how incredible this game is.

PROS
+First things first, many of the cons I've previously listed in this review have been removed because the developers are constantly updating and improving the game. Major props for doing that!!!!
+At the core, this game is still a quality RTS, with all of the checkboxes to make one.
+Three different resources (Food/Wood/Coin) with a fair balance between resource acquisition and spending.
+Solid combat triangles (Infantry>Cavalry>Artillery>Infantry). Pretty reminiscent of other RTSs and Age of Empires games.
+Greater levels of variety between the factions at launch than the previous Age of Empires games (except for Age of Mythology). Instead of only having one unique Castle unit, each European faction has two (or more) unique units and a variety of factors to set them apart (e.g building a British House grants a free Settler, Russians train units in blocks instead of individually, Portuguese get a free Town Center with each age-up, etc.)
+The system for Aging Up is revamped to offer new decisions, too! Instead of merely moving to the next age, you have to pick one of a selection of options (Politicians for Europeans, Council Members for Native Americans, Wonders for Asians). Each option offers a different benefit to strengthen or incentivize different playstyles (e.g crates of 500 food that can be immediately used or two cows that, if you spend time fattening, are together worth 1000 food).
+In addition to villagers, each player starts the game with a unique character unit with special abilities (Europeans have Explorers, Native Americans have War Chiefs, Asians have Monks). These units offer a better starting unit to explore the map in the early game, and can be improved with upgrades at various buildings to make them strong units in the late game.
+Going on with the Exploration themes of the era this game takes place in, each map has a number of treasures that can be claimed by your Hero unit. These are usually guarded by neutral guardians (animals,  bandits, etc.) that must be killed (your hero will have an ability to make this easier) in order to be claimed. Once claimed, you will receive a small to moderate amount of resources, a unit (or more), or another bonus to help you in your early game.
+There are trading post sites on most maps that offer advantages. Some are next to local villages that will offer unique units and upgrades for you. Others have a trade route to grant extra resources to give you a small edge in the game.
+With the trading posts is a new Trade Monopoly victory condition. Instead of building a single Wonder and building excessive amounts of walls for ten minutes, you capture a majority of the trading posts, spend a moderate amount of resources, and hold those posts for five minutes to win. Can make for some exciting plays in multiplayer.
+Introduction of the Home City system. Each player has a deck of shipments that can be sent from their mother nation to their in-game colony that offer different bonuses, like resources, units, buildings, or upgrades. Sending a shipment a requires a player to acquire experience which can be gained through building units and buildings, killing enemy units and buildings, gathering resources, capturing trading post sites, choosing XP at a captured trade route, and taking treasures.
+Each Home City is customizable. You can have a wide array of characters like preachers, performers, and thugs walk the streets between buildings that you color! You can put your Aztec city in a solar eclipse, your Indian city in the Holi festival at sunset, or your Russian city in a cold night with a full moon!
+An incredibly functional scenario editor on par with the one from Age of Mythology!
+An excellent series of campaigns with memorable events! The base campaign (Blood, Ice, and Steel) tells the story of the fictional Black Family and their generational enemies, using it as a method to introduce the player to the aging system and the time periods that these ages coincide with!
+The expansion campaigns (Fire and Shadow and The Asian Dynasties) likewise do a great job on placing players in historical events without disrupting history! Cross the Delaware with Washington, fight Custer at Little Big Horn, help Tokugawa solidify his control over Japan, and rise up in India against the East India Company!
+Normally, I'm greatly opposed to "fourth resources" in games (e.g Stone in Age of Empires I and II), but the Export resource is handled excellently for the Asian factions, and the Influence resource is similar, but different in good ways for the African factions.
+The developers for the Definitive Edition added customization options to the Native American and Asian factions that weren't in the base game, so props for that!
+When remastering this for rerelease, the developers reached out to representatives of the Haudenosaunee and Lakota to ensure that their representation ingame was on point, even getting a Lakota person to rework part of the second campaign's second act (Shadow) to this end.
+Addition of two new factions in the base game: the Swedes and the Inca. Both have solid mechanics to make them stand out from the other European/Native American factions, and are fun to play in different ways!
+Also added are new Native American tribes to ally with, new outlaws to hire at your mercenary locations, and new South American maps to play on!
+Addition of Historical Battles, which are more reminiscent of the classic Age of Empires I and II campaigns, just scenarios instead of campaigns.
+Addition of The Art of War, a campaign designed to teach players how to play well on Multiplayer. It's an excellent tutorial that improved my RTS playing across the board, not just for this game!
+New different UI options that are easier to use for players used to more recent RTS games (like Company of Heroes or Dawn of War).
+DLC: New factions, including the United States, Mexico, Ethiopia, the Hausa, the Knights of St. John, and Italy!
+DLC: New African maps with the African DLC pack and Europeans with the European DLC pack! Now we just need the Middle East and Australia!

CONS
-Graphics are solidly comparable to a game from 2010 or 2012. Personally, I liked them, just don't expect Total War: Warhammer levels of fidelity.
-Unfortunately, Act 2 of the base campaign (Ice) is rather lacking, and makes exactly zero sense. Act 2 of the Asian Dynasties campaign (China) is also on the weaker side, but still worth playing.
-Getting people who speak the language to voice the Native American factions is the right call, especially for the Age of Empires series. However, some of the voices are soft or poorly acted. I understand how difficult it must be to get fluent speakers for these languages, but it's a bit jarring to go from a hero character that speaks strongly to a generic fighting unit that speaks so soft that it's hard to hear.
-Likewise, the Aztecs in the game do not speak Classical Nahuatl. As with above, I'm sure it's difficult to find people who could speak the language fluently, let alone get them into a recording studio, it's just a minor disappointment.
-DLC: The African factions are currently overpowered (free unit upgrades each Age-Up without it costing extra to Age-Up).In addition, while Influence is spent at reasonable rates, it's gained at unreasonably high rates when compared to Export (at least as of the last time I played as an African nation). Not a problem against AI, but it's a big problem in Multiplayer.

Before, I would always point to Company of Heroes II, Dawn of War 1, or Age of Mythology as my go-to for introducing players to the RTS genre. Now, I think Age of Empires III Definitive Edition is the perfect introduction for the franchise and the genre!

I bought this game because I really love the AoE series. AoE 3:DE has improved the original game so much I really don't know where to begin! All but one of the changes to the original game has been excellent (I wish they would have left the home city card buying in because it takes away from grinding for all the cards.) I always play with large maps, and now the entire map can be large maps! If you are a fan of the series, you will love this game!!!

This review deserves a revision and a flip to yes. I believe most of the things I disliked previously have been addressed successfully enough. At one point my friends and I did switch back to playing this version of the game exclusively, so I think that warrants a positive review. :) Thank you for all the love and hard work, devs!!

PREVIOUS REVIEW:
As a big AoE fan, I really want to like this game, but the fact is that despite several patches and hotfixes since release, the game is still riddled with many of the most game-breaking bugs (AI, UI, pathfinding, input, mechanics, you name it). My experience has not improved in any meaningful way since the game's release, and at this rate I don't see that changing any time soon. The new features, civs, and quality of life improvements are great, but not at the expense of stability and playability. I'm going back to the 2007 complete edition with ESOC patch. DE is not worth the frustration right now. Will revisit in the future.

They made the multiplayer chat basically unusable, everything and i mean everything even stuff that isnt even remotely close to being profanity is censored. it doesnt just censor the word either it censors the whole sentence. No interacting with other humans apparently...
The Social interface of the game is also entirely broken, the friends list, block list, and recently played all don't work whatsoever and neither does the ranked leader board. If you do manage to get someone you want to block to show up on your recently played you can click the block button but it doesnt actually block them even if it says it did. 
why would you want to block someone? Well because for whatever reason they decided to completely change numerous cards, units, and entire civs from AoE3 2007 and in doing so created numerous truly game breaking bugs/exploits that result in 9/10 games being basically a race to broken units/upgrade cards and in most higher rated games (at least according to the broken and frozen leaderboard/ladder) 9/10 players will turtle the entire game until they get their broken card or unit and then finally push annihilating the enemy player no matter how good, bad, or prepared they are. They will try to justify this and pretend its not broken while they play with one hand and beat themselves off with the other but many of these exploits result in troops that are nearly invincible and can 1 shot all of your troops, even troops that are supposed to counter the broken units they're using. This makes for games that aren't very fun as it basically removes the entire Rock, paper, scissors mechanic that AoE is designed around. This was a problem as well back in AoE3 2007 however there were very very few truly game breaking strategies. The only that really come to mind are instant french cav and aztec water boom with 15 wood fishing boats, the exploits in this game dont even compare to those strategies. For france you had to build a strong economy and stack numerous cards to achieve the instant cav, and aztec were the strongest water civ by far but could still be beaten. Compare that to India with 20 Gurkas at age 3 that could individually 1 shot any unit (meaning it took 1 gurka 1 shot to kill any unit) even mercenaries or cav, or infinite mamalukes with 1740 hp, or Portugal with market upgrades just being able to gather 40-60% faster from all sources, or Inca being able to be inside your base with 15-20 troops before the 5 minute mark and the list goes on. 
Thankfully the Gurkas were hotfixed however i doubt they would've been hotfixed as quickly if pros werent going 42 and 0 in ranked using them however all the other broken bs i listed remains.

In summation, the game was released with broken incomplete graphics options, countless game breaking exploits and bugs that even the worst players found ways to abuse within a couple games. The Social and Multiplayer Menu's are all broken and terribly designed even if they were working as intended. 11/4/22 Edit: Campaigns + historic battles probably have a good 100-200 Hours of fun gameplay in there, DLC are pretty much a waste of money as they are all pretty much designed  for the multiplayer which has not improved all that much since this initial review around launch. 
Can only can recommend for the campaign but honestly the 2007 version of the game is just as good if not better for that.

AoE 3: Definitive Edition is a good game, although not without flaws.

For one, the game has a pretty steep learning curve as soon as you switch to hard or higher difficulties. Unlike AoE 2, AoE 3 has very specific units to each faction, so there is a lot to learn in between light and heavy, infantry, chivalry, artillery and their counterparts. Not knowing your units very well will result in you getting rushed and completely annihilated by AI within 10-15 minutes since you won't be playing properly grouped units combined with a proper deck of cards. Oh yeah, cards... unlike in original AoE 3, you don't unlock them here by grinding up your home town level - you can build the full deck with all cards available from level 1 on which makes deck building so much more accessable. Town level in AoE 3 DE is only for town cosmetics. Good one.

I still find the title "Definitive Edition" a bit misleading in terms of DLC content as you still have to buy extra if you want to side with the Americans, Mexicans and a few others. But let's not trick ourselves here - today's video game industry is a pile of hot garbage and whenever a chance arises to milk some extra pennies out of their customers then OF COURSE they will sell additional DLC content for a 17 years old game... if anyone's still surprised by this business behaviour then they must be hopelessly delusional or living under a rock for the last 5 years.

At a 20 bucks price tag there isn't much to argue whether the game is worth it or not. You'll get a great amount of content to play through with endless replayability in skirmish and multiplayer modes. If you can get this during a sale - I just got this for 7,99 during Halloween - go grab it and just enjoy this RTS cult classic game.
