Age of Empires is one of those franchises that's you just can't ignore. I got this right away so that I could relive some of those childhood moments of playing this and boy did I miss this. 

I will say some of the new content is really unbalanced or dull but other parts offer nice historical insight and extra content. I'm not a fan of all this cosmetic and DLC nonsense and events though. Its just really unnecessary and the game should have honestly been left alone and just updated with more cool scenarios and maps. I feel like all these new civilizations would have fit better in a new game with proper dedicated support from the start. 

My one big gripe is the game's optimization which is atrocious. There's no reason for stuttering on a 32GB 3600CL16 DDR4 system with a 11700k and a 1660Ti (parent's system). There's no reason for it on a system with 16GB 3000CL15 DDR4 system with a 9700k and 3060ti (yes I'm upgrading my system to fit my GPU in a few days from writing this). These are within spec and despite bottlenecks they should both easily hold a constant smooth 60fps at 1440p. For crying out loud a 1660 can do AC Odyssey at 60fps on high at 1080p, thats not even the Ti model. There's a lot to be said for how Age of Empires III uses your hardware.

Outside of this, the game is still a classic must play even if just for the original story. Overall for original content 9/10. Overall for Definitive Edition content 7/10.

If you want the definitive version of AoE III, play the original. While the new version does have some QoL life changes that are beneficial, it is too frustrating a game to truly recommend compared to the game it is remaking.

This includes little changes, like the 'decolonising' of certain aspects of the game despite the fact it's a colonial game with a colonial setting, taking a fundamentally European approach to Empire and what it means to be victorious; to bigger things, like the new civilisations being locked away from you unless you pay for them; to the biggest things, namely that it is unfun to play. The AI has been designed in such a way that games can be a chore to complete, with my last match taking literally hours longer than it should've, without them ever seemingly to be playing a smart match. They can be efficient, yet completely unable to use their efficiency. The balancing of the nations is not great. There are still noticeable bugs in game, which is especially galling given how little there is to quibble with in the original in that regard.

Worst of all, neither the sound nor the graphics seem a step up from the original (which was admittedly a game with great design for the time, and still looks and sounds good even today).

All in all, despite the QoL changes that I'd have liked in the original, I can't recommend the remake in its stead.

The bugs and gameplay issues have now been fixed. The PC police renaming is unfortunately still in the game, but there is also a lot of great new content that overshadows it.

This was my favourite game of all time. The older version had some issues with low player counts making it very difficult to play multiplayer so I was really looking forward to a new game bringing it back into popularity. I was hoping the DE would fix that, but they shit the bed in just about every aspect of the game. It's so much less reliable and buggy months after their bungled release which is the first offence but there's so much more to be disappointed by. There are major flaws present in the base game like the attack move not functioning have still not been addressed. They tried to be woke in the laziest and most offensive way. They censored every instance of the word colony and things like plantation in a game about colonialism. Their attempt to make the natives more historically accurate expended less effort than their message patting themselves on the back for it. Instead of a unique and interesting fur trade mechanic we got people loitering around an outhouse next to a mine to get their gold. Instead of replacing the fire pit with something sensible like a temple or sweat lodge, it's now a llama dance pit where villagers stand idle. 

Overall:

Pros:
They stole the maps made by fans so there are more and better balanced maps which is great.
The historical battles are really cool and what the campaign should have been in the first place.
Two new nations is nice but Inca is pretty anachronistic and there were many better choices.
Revolutionary nations have much better options even if most of them aren't too viable. 
Home city cards no longer need to be unlocked and are better balanced.
Nicer flags.

Cons:
Unbelievably buggy in multiplayer even after months for them to fix it.
Incredibly lazy revisionist history.
Major gameplay issues like attack move still not working.
Shorter game play than AOE 2, but fun and graphics are great.
Brings back a lot of nostalgia.  Forgot how enjoyable this series was.

I've played this since the original: thousands of hours in total. Very good game, but way too cannon-centric. Most competitive strats are essentially a (semi)FF to get falconets. Games that run short/medium/late are typically won by the player or team that deploys more cannons. Their disproportionate efficacy against infantry is neither fun nor historically accurate. An non-upgraded falconet deals 100x3 dmg to infantry in a range and can one-shot a whole clump of skirmisher units every several seconds. Falconets for example, have a 75% dmg resist from ranged units. The intended counterplay (obviously) is culverins or heavy cavalry that can make quick work of cannons. However, because most talented players can either micro their anti-cav to defend their cannons, or position their cannons in a choke point created either from the natural terrain or walls, the only valid counter to cannons is culverins (which is an anti-cannon cannon that outranges other cannons). And so many games that run late can be won by simply spamming cannons (normal cannons combined with culverins to counter the opponents cannons), with a small amount of anti-cavalry units to defend them. Back in the olden days, many players would play "no cannons" multiplayer lobbies because our computers couldn't handle the lag of all the cannons and associated physics, which had the side-effect of games being more enjoyable because of the lack of cannon-spam. But nowadays, because everyone is playing on a supercomputer, cannon spam is a regular and unsavory reality of the meta.

My personal pick for the best RTS game of all time, no question. So many strategic angles, each civ is pretty much entirely unique, absolutely stellar voice actors for the revamped Native civs, African civs, and new Mexican and Italian/Maltan civs.

Significantly more forgiving micro than the rest of the AOE collection, and with no requirement for resource drop sites, all units training in (minimum) blocks of 5 save for some Russian units and villagers, Ensembles AOE3 provides not only the best entry level "Age of" style RTS game but in my hundreds of hours of experience in the genre, the best of the series.

Also check out Age of Mythology, Age of Empires 4 for those who miss how Age of Empires II played.

Age of Empires III DE is a worthy conclusion to the remastered trilogy and as such offers no surprises. It is questionable whether such a game has something to offer today's modern gamer, but Microsoft doesn't have to think much about that. It's enough that they think of us, the veterans who played Age of Empires at the time of its release.

If you want to play a classic RTS, this trilogy is one of the best options. A huge amount of content, sensitive and well-thought-out changes and, on top of that, nicely polished graphics – all of this also applies to the current trio, even if it is the black sheep of the whole family. And even if I prefer to recommend you the practically perfect definitive edition of Age of Empires II, it does not change the fact that the definitive edition of the third part is a fun historical strategy with sophisticated systems and a decent portion of content.

In the end, this is a solid remaster and update of a good strategy, whose biggest problem is that it will forever remain in the shadow of its legendary predecessor. [b] 55% [/b]

Since my original review, the game has aged very well. Fixing most of the issues I noted before, and with new content drops, it has a healthy life cycle ahead. 

Optimisation has improved considerably. Options allow you to reduce foliage, and thus improve visibility on many maps. Sound has been improved, with very few bad or off putting sound. AI in the campaigns are still a little off, with behaviour oscillating between challenging and dead. Pathfinding has been improved considerably, with the old stuck on tradepost bug all but gone. Naval pathfinding remains a little broken when there are many ships moving at a time.

Campaign cutscenes are remastered, but some changes are for the worse, placement of models are out of place, cut audios sound strange, its a bit of a hashed up job. The strangest thing is the Chayton Black campaign. What was once a more or less neutral story pointing out the evil and good of both the US and the Amerindians suddenly portrays only the Amerindians as good, and the US as evil. The nuance of the campaign is completely gone, Chayton's change of heart makes no sense anymore.

Destruction physics has improved, as has the music looping bug. In all, the music is still the same as the original, with no remastered tracks or new ones (except for the riffs related to the European Houses).

I can understand the changes to the Amerindian nations, and finally, the voice acting has been updated. It no longer sounds like they had the voice actors phone into the studio. Now just waiting for Akbar to stop sounding so patronising.

The homecity cards are just stacked into each other, with barely any differentiation like the old game. They did make upgrade cards more transparent though. And with new cards being added ever so often, it shakes up the meta and makes older civs more relevant relative to the new civs being added. Speaking of the new civs, they are amazing. New mechanics, new variations on maps, and interesting game modes. The only qualm I have is there are no new campaigns.

The game does look a lot better, with models having less pixelly a quality to them, the UI changes are interesting, but they do give you the option to change around based on what you are comfortable with. But even so, the UI feels very hollow, and lacks a certain personality. I don't understand why modern UI design is going into this minimalist approach, but it just feels disconnected. 

Overall, with the consistent updates adding new civs and maps, the game continues to evolve and stay relevant.

AOE 3 Definitive edition is a great expansion of the original game. It includes many new units, factions, maps, abilities and cards. Many of the DLC factions are also good as well (I have yet to try the African nations). The graphical updates are great compared to the now dated original game. The added and sometimes changed music is well done and lore friendly. New cards make every faction feel much more unique than before and now there is much more of a learning curve when changing from faction to faction. Updates to the AI makes it much more challenging at higher difficulties and keeps me engaged when playing against AI.

I wish I could recommend it. The main issue i got with it is that for a "definitive edition" the multiplayer servers are atrociously bad, especially in games of more than 4 people. In absolute majority of the games that I had the chance to play like 80%-90% ended prematurely, or rather have been made conclusive prematurely by somebody randomly crashing or DCing. Few CTDs happened to me too while playing multiplayer and no unfortunately you cannot reconnect into an ongoing game, which means once you CTD, you are out forever and the game is most likely decided. This unfortunately means outcome of most team deathmatch games are completely arbitrary, which is rather unfortunate because it also means everything you do prior to somebody disconnecting is made retroactively irrelevant. Yes if you are good at the game you can win a 2v3 for example, but more often than not, once a player disconnects from a team, others are soon to follow, because the effort, time and patience that is required to pull it off is for majority of the players not worth it and frankly I don't blame them.

I played Age of Empires 3 for the first time in 2005. My machine at the time was not powerful enough to handle this game, so I went back to AOE II. 17 years later, I picked up this game on Steam.

I paid $5.99 for the definitive edition, which includes Warchiefs and Asian Dynasties. I also purchased the United States Civilization for $2.49. I am yet to play any skirmish matches with United States Civilization. I played all the story missions including the expansions. 

I am by no means a strategy games expert. I do not play PvP. I wanted to play all the campaign missions, and because the game was on sale, I decided to take a chance. 

I am glad I did because I thoroughly enjoyed my time with the game. The main campaign missions are quite well done. The story begins during the early settlement of the new world, and goes all the way to the founding of America. There are some very interesting missions here. 

The expansions are also quite well done for the most part. The highlight of the expansions for me were the Japanese missions.There is something aesthetically pleasing about the Japanese setting. I liked the Chinese missions the least. There is nothing particularly wrong with them, I just did not find them very interesting. The Indian missions are quite good too, but the story is rather comical. They made The East India Company the cartoon villain and whether there is any truth to this, I am not sure. It did not stop me from having a decent time with the missions. 

Graphics in the game are excellent. The snow covered landscape of New England, desert canyons of the south west, tropical jungles of South America, the visuals are very striking. I do not know if this is because of HD textures that were added in the modern edition or if they always looked this good. Explosions, water effects, and physics in game are all very well done. 

In addition to excellent graphics it also works great at ultra wide resolution. I played this game at 3440x1440 resolution, and it ran perfectly fine. I also occasionally played it at 1080p in windowed mode. I was very pleased with the graphics and gameplay options. I wish all PC games implemented options like this. 

Gameplay is much the same as the previous versions. There are certain choices that focus on efficiency, which may not be well liked by veterans. I am ambivalent to this change. Logging camps and mining camps are no longer needed to collect resources.

In fact resource gathering is far more rudimentary now than it was in AOE II. There are only 3 resources to gather - food, wood and gold. Other than wood, there are infinite options for both food and gold. In Asian Dynasties, rice paddy can be used to farm food and gold. It's rather bizarre, but it's not game breaking or anything. There are some odd choices made with unit production. Indian villagers require wood instead of food. Seems rather arbitrary. 

Naval combat in this game is very underwhelming. The scale of the map does not allow for large- scale naval battles. AOE II did this a lot better. The map scale is smaller than AOE II. Certain AOE II maps are absolutely massive such as Bukhara and Dos Pilas. No such maps exist in AOE III. It's not a deal breaker, but the advance in technology did not bring us bigger, better maps. 

It took well over 60 hours for me to get through the entire campaign (including the expansions). I totally got my money’s worth. In hindsight, I should not have purchased the DLC for it. I don't see myself going back to playing skirmish matches. I am currently playing AOE2 Definitive Edition. I think overall, I enjoy AOE2 more than AOE3, but you can't go wrong for the price. 

I look forward to playing AOE I and AOE IV some day. 

For the price I paid for it, I recommend this game. 

+ Visuals
+ Graphics & gameplay options
+ Interesting main campaign
+ Expansions

- Smaller scale maps
- Naval combat
- Arbitrary choices for resource requirement

[strike]Played a bit at launch. So far, the original version is better.[/strike]
Edit: Having played more, far later on, I can confirm that they did eventually pull their thumbs out of their butts and accomplish a mostly faithful and in some places improved recreation of a beloved game. They took their time about it, though, and the launch was embarrassingly bad, so the thumbs down stays. You don't get to serve paying customers a substandard meal and then complain about bad reviews because you actually learned to cook two years later.

Irks so far:
[list][*] [strike]You want bugs? We got bugs. Unstable music volume...[/strike] - Music volume wobbling due to failtastic mastering of great music tracks into game-playable format, seems to have been fixed. Only took 'em two years or so... [strike]Broken keyboard remapping (can't bind scrolling to WASD)...[/strike] - Key binding is still a total mess to accomplish thanks to the confusing decision to bind all the letter keys to the bottom-right command icons, but you can accomplish tolerable keybinds with enough time and effort.
[*] If you want to report a bug, please go to our private web site so we can screen and, if necessary, silence you in our little corporate safe space. This is such a great idea, you guys.
[*] Weird stripes on buildings, weird paint all over privateer vessels (i.e. pirate ships, i.e. "we don't want people knowing who just plundered their ship")...
[*] Less visually appealing shipment cards and card picking interface... the game's unique awesome feature, made worse.
[*] [strike]Messed up visual city customization. Patriotic bunting hanging in the air ten feet out from the building it's "attached to".[/strike] - They actually added some new customization stuff, including nice scene/light/season changes, to the home cities of native american and asian factions. This was an unironically awesome change that gives you an excuse to play lots of skirmishes (or multiplayer, if you're utterly mad) and unlock them, along with some other neat decorative stuff. Good job there!
[*] If you have to tell each and every building to do it individually, each time, and it deactivates itself after the task has been done once, it is not "auto-repair". It's just repair. Just as if you have to grind the coffee by hand, it's not an automatic coffee grinder. See?
[*] Pretending colonization didn't happen is not the same as acknowledging it was wrong. It's also not a real option in a game that is literally all colonization during the historical colonial age. Also, the term "Commercial Age" is baloney. Every age after the invention of exchanging things for other things, is commercial.
[*] The game is still plenty insensitive to sundry tribes and ethnic groups. Ottomans, for one. But hey, hard not to be, it's a game about people killing more than half the people they meet in order to take their land (while pressing the rest into servitude). Pretty horrible when you think about it... me, I mostly just like building pretty towns. No, really, that part isn't sarcasm, that's what I'm in this for. That and revenge against attackers.[/list]

In summary: Pretty to look at, [strike]but that's about it. In its current state, not recommended. But please, by all means, change my mind, developers.[/strike] - You kind of did change my mind, developers. Nice one. Took you long enough, but yeah. I'm honestly considering buying some DLC at this point, and one could do worse than buying this - if you buy it now, long after they first sold a far more unfinished and flawed product at full price.

Definitely not bad, but not great.
--50GB(!) of hard disc space eaten up and yet textures still manage to look more cartoony and somewhat muddier than the original 3GB 2005 version. Similarly, majority of the art has been redrawn and looks objectively worse than the originals.
--Hangups, crashes and connectivity issues in multiplayer are still often enough to be annoying.
--New civs are generally really interesting and well rounded, but tend to have balance issues. That said, the new mechanics added mix things up.
--Of the two new modes, one is basically a mix of tutorial/skill building (art of war) that feels more like a minigame. The second (historical battles) is really well made and reminiscent of classic aoe campaigns, wish there were more of them because the detail and historical accuracy are great.
--All cards are unlocked by default, on one hand it makes multiplayer more based on skill, thus friendlier for new/intermittent players. On the other, it makes gaining experience a bit pointless and levelling up your cities purely cosmetic. Missed opportunity to rework game features rather than just disabling them so everyone is always at the same level.

Despite the poor launch, right now it's more or less stable, online has a steady population and it's still the core aoe3 experience, just not necessarily better. If you've never played aoe3 but want to, this will be the version to get.

DE is a well-deserved glow up that makes AOE3 the best of the series yes yes torches and pitchforks on your right. 
AOE3 DE offers a bunch of factions with decent to huge differences among each other, and a versatile card deck system that lets you customize your gameplay and experiment. The updated graphics are sweet and the game received a lot of stability, QOL and balance improvements. Also, entirely new and fun factions that escape the old paradigms quite a bit.

If you enjoyed the vanilla edition, definitely grab DE.
If you play AOE, definitely grab it.
If you play RTS, do it anyway.

A few issues still remaining:
- Balance can still be wonky at times, my major complaints still being on the Asian factions, and there are clear winners/losers among cards.
- At the time of writing, some old civs still need a revamp, for example France or Germany.
- In terms of UX/readability, it can be a bit robotic and hostile to new players, who need to read stuff carefully.
- Some pathfinding/LOS issues still persist.
The latter two issues probably purely depend on the fact that the game stonebed is ancient at this point.

I'd like to recommend this game, but I can't.
To be fair, the remake is fine if you have a newer computer, with plenty of hard drive space, and you never liked the leveling system of the old version of the game.
But I can't in good faith recommend a game that lags this badly on a computer that played the original just fine.
The remake is a whopping 10x larger than the original too. 50 GB vs the original 5 GB. Just because computers are more powerful these days doesn't mean you need to waste all that space, and render it unusable on slower machines.
I enjoyed the leveling system of the old game and "earning" cards. But I can understand removing that, and I won't fault them on that alone.
But the cards have also lost their "tree" structure. Even though they're all available from the beginning now, they could've at least grouped related cards together, because now finding the cards I want is a pain.
The UI is a lot less intuitive than the original too, and despite having multiple options for UI, none of them match the original. Not even "classic"
So, sadly, I can't recommend this remake, as much as I wish I could due to its proton stability over the old one.

Very poor AI. Boring gameplay.

Here's a few examples of the AI lacking basic coding:

The AI will not attack you, unless by sheer badluck, that is, that its units happen to stumble upon your base, even if they do, the AI will not try to attack again, it's as if it forgot where your base was.

The AI will not defend itself in several situations. For example, an AI ship, like a fishing boat or a cavalier, won't flee or defend itself, if you attack it while it is fishing.

If you attack an AI base, the AI will only react with nearby units, but will not change its survival strategy in any way.

A quick glance at Civilization franchise's AI will prove that a better AI is possible.


And what's up with the deck system anyways? Glad the got rid of it in the 4th.

I can remember playing my first AOE game it was the original AOE (1997) good times.

This game is still a masterpiece. I have been playing AOE III since it originally came out and I was a kid, and the Definitive Edition is all around an upgrade and just builds upon the already great foundation that was the original. After playing AOE IV for a bit I still came back to this game just because of how unique it is, with Home City shipments, customizing your home cities (limited but cool), all the unique faction units and strengths and weaknesses. This game just seems endlessly replayable. 

Pros:

- The amount of factions to choose from 
- Unique Units
- A massive selection of maps
- Well designed AI (Making playing offline just as fun as online)
- Home City Shipments (Unique only to this AOE game)
- Customizable Home City (Unique only to this AOE game)
- Gameplay is very balanced 
- Interesting Faction Strengths and Weaknesses
- Fantastic DLC Factions

Cons:

- Unit pathing can sometimes be wonky
- Villagers will sometimes go idle after chopping trees, even though there is another tree right next to them
- Walls sometimes will not connect correctly to the environment, leaving gaps in your defense

The cons are just a bit nitpicky because I honestly cannot think of any glaring major issues with the game. One thing you should know before picking this game up is that if you like Age of Empires II then you likely will not like this game. The play style and game pace is just so different, not to mention its set in a later time period. I personally love II but I love III more just because of in my opinion, the better gameplay. AOE IV is a mix of II and III so if you like IV then you may like III, either way if you are thinking about playing the game, I would say pick it up when you can because you will not have a bad experience. 

P.S. Just like with most strategy games, the campaign is lackluster, so I would not pick it up for that. It is long and tells good stories, but its simply a bit dull to play through.
More campaign should be added other than those three. AOE III is not like AOE iV or II so update should come regularly. As a long time, AOE player I love this game more than any other game.

I strongly advise against buying this game. There are several things that makes this a frustrating game to play and it feels like the company designed the game with the goal to waste as much player time as possible, instead of trying to make this a good player experience.

First, there isn't a proper guide to the different units (no database with all the stats, no tutorial). So you can't really develop any real strategies without wasting hours researching all of the basics yourself, where all it needs is for the company to release a tabulated database.

Second, you have to do a lot of random tasks to unlock explorers / home city. What is the point? The different explorers is one of the things that was supposed to be an USP of this game, and yet that is locked unless you again waste hours doing tasks that does not interest you. 

Third, the experience point system of the home city is bugged, and there are no tutorials to tell you how it works. I noticed that my home city seems to gain experience randomly, and for some home cities, there are ZERO experience points gain no matter what I do (skirmish, challenge, story, etc.). So again, you will be wasting hours trying to figure out what is wrong and how to fix it, when really all you want to do is to play a game.

This is a very badly made game. There are so many alternatives that I think are way better than this game  (the classic red alert, star craft, WoW, Sanguo series). Do you really want to waste your money on this game?

You know this game was part of my child hood but me and a few friends who only play the game for causal have found a few glaring issues with this title. 
1. the unite path finding on the map is the worst we've seen yet of any RTS and that's saying a lot. When told to engage the enemy they will walk very slowly to attack the one soldier you selected then if they're range they'll move to attack the next one or two soldiers. If they're melee units they'll actually spread out and attack the crowd after they're first kill.
2. the power balancing in the game is pretty wack like I like how complex it is but there are clearly some broken units in the game. Some of which are DLC units. Now you could argue a few of them are late game units and thus shouldn't see play a lot but since we're causal our games tend to last about an hour thus making them more common to the point they're in just about every game.

Now on the flip side there are lots of diverse unites and cultures and tactics to mess around with but at the end it's just a bit clunky and needs more time to be polished out.

Units stuck everywhere, like villages, cliffs, graphics glithces like resources not disappearing or popping (trees), unit upgrades that disappear from the panel sudden and randomly, specially with the chinese, so I can't even play them, cards that don't do the effect they should, or even the OPPOSITE, like slowing your unit recruitment rate. Don't even dare to speak about any political decision about historical accuracy, when the base game isn't even FINISHED! We can have those lesser debates when the game doesn't have bugs, glitches, doesn't remove your progress, crashes, disconnects you and has really bad hotkey response, because I have to press the key several times  to make them work!

The original game is almost a masterpiece in terms of playability, with fictional campaigns, very few ones although, a little unbalanced factions (in DE happens a lot with new factions and politicians), and some core changes from old ones, which I found them a MUST have nowadays.

This DE, tho, makes a lot of things right. Like more politicians, more revolutions, card balance, unit balance, new maps and old maps balances, 2 new factions and a huge player base. Is it worth it? It's just a flat out improvement on the original AOEIII, with game balance, more content (DLC still being released btw monkaS) and graphics slightly de-jankified. AOEIII is as a whole and by my judgement probably the fourth best of the 6 part Age of Empires series, just edging out AOE1 and handily beating AOE Online. 

This game has some very innovative, fresh ideas for it's time - from destructo physics buildings (I think aoe4 doesn't even go into as much detail as this game but don't quote me) to the round map and home cities mechanic, really brought some fresh stuff to the RTS genre. Unfortunately it probably changed too much and didn't quite pull it all off so we're left with a *pretty good* but not stellar (in my book) aoe game. Kinda similar to Total War: Empire in that respect.

Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition,

Overall, I had so much fun with this one, very good game. Story is a bit childish at first, but Asian Dynasties tied the campaign nicely.

+ New mechanics, card system, home town, game is much more fluid than previous installments, UI upgrade
+ Artillery and it's audio effects, naval combat
+ You can build anywhere and there is no longer need to bring back resources to the town center
+ Game feels easier, and not so mind taxing, less town micromanagement
+ The Asian Dynasties had a nice story and atmosphere

- Audio problems, missing cutscene lines
- Childish story in first two sets of campaign
- FPS drops and minor bugs

9/10, I liked this game very much

I have not experienced any of the issues other users have reported. This is just the first time I've been able to play Age 3 multiplayer, as for some reason I could never use the old multiplayer even with two different copies of the game. 

After seeing a lot of reviews complaining about changing names/other things. Changing the names of the ages makes sense - if you are playing a native american tribe, having a Discovery and Colonial age are misnomers. Besides, these names barely show up anywhere and do not matter in the slightest. I can't speak to single player changes as the single player was never really relevant.

Another strange complaint are the dlc factions - the definitive edition includes all DLC originally developed from the original game. This is not just a lazy upscale of the original either, they redid many of the assets and continuously update the balance. The DLC factions have all been developed specifically for the DE, and never existed in the original release. It seems bizarre to complain about expansions and active support for a game as old as this.

Despite "AOEIII" having always been my personal favorite of the series, for some reason, I remained skeptical of this "improved" version for very a long time. But now, that I have finally had the chance to delve into it, I am happy to see that it has got a similar kind of "Definitive Edition" care to that of its older brother "AOEII", including various graphical and QoL improvements, extended multiplayer support as well as new DLC updates. Unfortunately, the singleplayer campaigns are still far from great. To be fair, none of the "AOE" games tried extremely hard to be historically accurate, but I always found the fantasy-adjacent stories and soap opera-level dialogue of the campaigns in this one to be quite abysmal. The newly added "Historical Battles", on the other hand, are simply amazing and even on par with the mastery of "AOEII" scenario and map design. If the devs can keep up the support at close to current levels, then this game still has a very bright future ahead.

RANT UPDATE:

Thanks guys for the comments. I want to keep the thread alive for people and developers to see. I do not want my review to be taken in a bad manner. As an old Age of Empires player and mainly playing RTS genre, i want to support this game. I want to see this game succeed.  

This is a 15+ year old game. The COMMUNITY has kept the game alive. There is no reason for the developers to not listen to the COMMUNITY's feedback. The initial idea of the Ensemble Studios developers was to make a game that was fun. They understood the importance of historical accuracy, however, they also understood the importance of keeping the game entertaining for the players. 

See Ensemble Studios interview: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n40YwG20QH8  

If there is a way to revert back the sounds, physics and textures of the units, buildings, oceans, please do so. Even if its just an option that could be turned on an off.  

In addition, dont forget the casual players that do not care for 1 vs 1 games, elo or rank matches. Even if its hard to believe, there are players out there that just want to have long, relaxing matches with friends, relatives and even play against AI. Comp stomp? anyone? 

If I forgot something, please feel free to add. 

I will update as I continue to play the game.

Most "definitive edition" of current videogames are nothing but a re-skinned hd version of their previous counterpart but not this one. It's a much improved game than his old 2005 self with more balanced civilizations, maps, general fixes and quality of life improvements. The game has been constantly update almost monthly, adding events, challenges and/or other fixes.

There are over 100 maps, 20+ civilizations, each one with their strengths and weaknesses, different gamemodes with different goals and playstyles like deathmatch, treaty, and tycoon, that are designed to satisfy all types of players.

While this game is more oriented towards multiplayer it does not forget about who likes to play mostly singleplayer.  Aside the classic skirmish there are several historical maps (special maps with unique objectives and mechanics) and 3 campaign to complete. You may also like the co-op if you want to play with friends and you're not into competition. The game is also mod friendly.

You do not need to buy any of the DLCs to enjoy the game, and unlike most modern videogames, it's not "create a problem, sell the solution" type of monetization. DLC simply add more content and no, the added civilizations are not "pay-to-win".

Most of the negative reviews are rather outdated as they refer mostly at the launch state which was mediocre as the game was clearly published in an unfinished state and sufferring of lag spikes and random crashes. After almost 2 years of fixing bugs, improving performance, adding content, most of these problems are solved and I can't think of something significantly bad to say about the game.

Whatever you are an RTS enthusiast, a chad typing GG after a loss, a virgin complaining after one, a kid at his first RTS, a history nerd, a long time AoE fan, a no-life-gamer looking to grind the ladder, a casual just wanting to have fun with his friends,  this game have something for you.

Warning. This version of AoE III is poorly optimized and runs with stutters in games with anything over 3 players. 
It has been doing this since launch, hence my reluctance to believe the developers will ever get this game up to par with stable framerate and eliminating freezes. 
I would strongly recommend getting the older version of the game, which runs way better than this even with dozens of mods, which puts this game within the cathegory of a poorly made moneygrab by their studios.

Let me preface this by saying I love Age 3 and I think this is a good remaster. As a history major and lover of especially war history, I can appreciate some historical accuracy, and changing the Native American nations was something I was perfectly happy with. However, at the same time, the team behind the remaster has chosen to rename the Colonial Age to the Commerce Age and the Plantation building to the Estate. These changes were completely unnecessary and do more to take away from historical accuracy than add to it. Multiple mechanics revolve around the very real colonial period in world history. Chattel Slavery and the Plantation economy were evil, but they were also a driving force behind colonial efforts and the Plantation's purpose as a cash producing farm is a perfect adaptation. Colonialism and its long reaching effects are a hot topic in our current political landscape, but to change these very real concepts while celebrating historical accuracy is dare I say, hypocritical.

Update: 7/19/22 After playing many more hours of the game and enjoying the new content for it, I have decided to change my review to a positive one. On reflection my nitpicks with changes were just that, nitpicks. I have enjoyed this remaster for many hours and will continue to put hours into it as the devs release new content. I am leaving up my original review for transparency but the game is absolutely worth getting.

[h1]An often overlooked gem of the series[/h1]
If you're new to Age of Empires III, there has never been a better time to try it out than with the current state of the Definitive Edition. If you played and liked the original, you will like even more the Definitive Edition.

[b]Why should you read this review?[/b] I have over 3000h in the original game and I participated actively in the beta of the Definitive Edition to help shape it. I have over 1000h in Age of Empires 2, including 500h in AoE2 DE. I will try to highlight the key aspects of the game to help you make an informed decision on whether it is worth or not for you to buy.

[h1]For those new to the game but familiar with previous iterations of the franchise (for example AoE2).[/h1] The best recommendation that I can give you is to try this game with a fresh mind. This is NOT AoE2, and this is a good thing! AoE3 is much more dynamic and fast paced than AoE2 and, particularly 1v1 and 2v2 games, the lenght of the games is typically shorter and relies much less on unit spam than AoE2. Few cavalry units raiding enemy villagers can have a much more lasting impact in the game as villagers are more expensive and take longer to train than in AoE2. Military units train in batches (usually of 5), which translates into important timings and power spikes that can turn the tide of a battle if properly played. This aspect is very satisfying as, even if you're on the losing side, there is a chance that you might be able to turn the game around and win. If you're on the winning side, you know you have to pay attention and you can't just go AFK since the game can still be lost. A quick 1v1 game typically will last less than 10min, with the fastest rushes being able to win (if properly executed) at around 7-8min. Even if the game is very even, it will usually be resolved before the 40min mark. For me, this is a very positive aspect when comparing it to AoE2 (where games tend to last much longer and can drag for longer than an hour). The sense of improvement and gratification for winning comes faster here so it is a good option if you like to play more than a single game and you do not have 2h or more to spare at a time.

[h1]For those new to the game and the Age of Empires franchise.[/h1] The game comes with basic tutorial that will help you both if you're familiar and unfamiliar with the RTS genre. Additionally, the Art of War tutorials will help you learn the basics of economy and military of Age of Empires III and get you ready for the real deal: multiplayer matches (that's where the fun lies, at least for me). However, if you are more of a singleplayer type of player, do not worry! You have the original 3 campaigns remastered + historic battle scenarios + infinite amount of singleplayer games that you can play vs the improved AI.

[h1]For those who played the original AoE III and with or without its expansions.[/h1] Please do yourself a favor and buy the definitive edition. Practically every single aspect of the game has been improved. So many bugs and exploits that are still present today on the Steam version of Age of Empires 3: The Asian Dynasties have been fixed. You don't see cheating anymore, as it is practically impossible to pull off (never say impossible, who knows but I have not heard of any). Civilization balance has never been better. There are tons of new maps and several new civilizations that add freshness to the game. Graphics? Fully remastered to 4K. UI? You get 3 different layouts that you can choose from to suit your needs (Legacy, AoE2 style, and Definitive). Multiplayer? There are so many more players right now and the lobby system is robust so it's much easier to get a game started.

There's things I like and things I really DON'T like. It takes a bit of getting use to since they've changed the UI and menus around, but I like that it takes up less space on the screen so you can see more of the game. Gameplay seems smoother and feels fresh and updated. You can zoom in further and see more detail on the soldiers and buildings which is also cool! There's a setting in the menu that allows you to zoom out more than normal as well but it's still in the "beta stage" and gives me an fps drop when I use it. Looks like they've also got some cool DLC you can get which includes more maps and civilizations to play. The graphics in the gameplay are a bit better overall and it adds some new life to it, although a couple maps were kinda dark for me and I haven't found a brightness setting thus far. The opening cinematic however is definitely more cartoonish than in the original 2007 version, and the characters in it look clunkier. Also If you pay attention you'll see they've changed the "destined to conquer" line to "destined for adventure" which brings me to my next and biggest complaint. They've gone woke. I don't mind adventure but this game is about conquering and fighting other players. Hell they've gone so woke that they've basically tried to censor colonialism... in a game that's literally about the Colonial Ages. They've changed the "Colonial Age" to the "Commerce Age", they've changed the name of Plantations to "Estates" and the only reference I remember seeing to a Colonial/colony thus far is a treasure guardian that was named "Oppressive Colonial".     -_-     I also heard they removed a mission or two from the campaigns because they were "offensive" somehow, and in the Native Civs you can no longer tame a treasure guardian which was one of my favorite features about them and it's disappointing... and those are just a few of the things I've noticed so far. The wokeism alone earned this a thumbs down because I've seen so much of it ruining things nowadays. I bought the game a 2nd time though because the gameplay itself is still pretty fun and I will continue to play the definitive edition, as my 2007 version keeps crashing on me. However, If you decide to try it yourself I highly recommend waiting for a sale.

This game seems slightly polarising, but while I do understand the criticisms, I still think this is an excellent remaster/revival of what was a fairly underappreciated entry into the series.

The pros:
[list]
[*] The new civilizations are excellent editions and really shake up how the game can be played. Not only are the civs pretty distinct from each other, but their strengths vary massively. Adds a really interesting set of possible strategies both for those playing the civs, and those playing against them
[*] The game looks fantastic. The original AoE III looked great for the time and it's aged well, but this one has polished and bloomed up the textures without making them look cartoony. Animations are solid, textures look good, and it feels like the sort of game that will age very well.
[*] They've done a great job with the UI. While you can't completely recreate the original's standard UI, you get a few options and can still get pretty close in terms of layout.
[*] The new decks have a done a great job for balancing the game right out of the gate. While I'm mainly single-player, I can see this change being hugely beneficial for multiplayer fans who are either new to this game, or just quite inexperienced. Also, a lot of changes to the civs have done a lot to streamline certain aspects (take, for instance, the ability for the British to be able to upgrade pikemen and longbowmen to Imperial without needing a special card)
[*] More and weirder maps. Just good fun, no downside here.
[/list]

The cons:
[list]
[*] I can see the look of the game turning people off. While the Aoe II remaster felt like a better done original, this one feels more like a new art style and concept for textures and it's definitely a slightly different feel and appearance to what we had before. 
[*]The new deck system does take a lot of fun out of single-player, since there isn't really any progression anymore. You still level-up, but you don't really get anything for it.
[*] If you want all of the new civs, this game is very expensive, not far off AoE IV. I'd recommend buying on-sale, otherwise I'm not sure I could justify it if you already own the original game.
[/list]

There are some things I wouldn't have changed, but overall it's a really solid revamp of what I think is a very underrated game. Strategies are more varied and out-of-the-box, some of the new maps give lots of opportunities in multiplayer team scenarios, and the game does just look and sound fantastic. If it's on sale, absolutely get it if you loved the original, or any of the other AoE games.

A long-standing favourite and the DE is a step-up from the original game.  By adding new maps, factions and cards the DE version has brought new life to the game without changing the fundamentals that made it such a success in the first place.

However,  some of the new factions are over-powered and combined with the new more aggressive and intuitive AI the game is becoming much more difficult.  Satisfying when you win but much more challenging, to the point that I consider the AI is getting too to be tough to be an enjoyable way to spend my time.

I understand the AI needed to be enhanced but the latest mod is too extreme.  I'll be a less frequent player from now on.

This is a remaster of a previous game, and for the most part the gameplay is the same. I've only played the first 2 missions of the campaign (more on this in a bit), and skirmish plays much like the original. So I'll keep this review focused on the remaster.

Some things got renamed, most notably, "Plantations" became "Estates". Aside from the indigenous civilizations which I haven't played yet, this is a cosmetic change. You build it, it does what the old building did, Bob's your uncle. The "Cowboys and Indians" feel of the old Warchiefs expansion was, I felt, one of its weaknesses, but then, it expanded on a fictional story, so I dismissed it. If this remaster portrayed the indigenous cultures of the time more accurately, I think that's a win.

In the original, if you played skirmish mode, you had to earn your cards. In this remake, they just give you everything, and the only place you earn cards is in the campaign. I think it would've been a lot better if you had the full deck in multiplayer, but you were forced to earn the cards in single-player skirmish. I just feel there was better challenge in having to face your opponents with the best card set you could come up with from an incomplete deck. Perhaps they didn't have time to set up the card level requirements for all the new civilizations because that would mean months of balancing and playtesting.

Speaking of new civilizations, you get all the civs from the original plus expansions, plus some others available as DLC, like a United States civilization that isn't a revolution offshoot of the British. That's right, you can play all 5 ages of badass freedom without being stuck with militia, crappy gatling guns, and maybe rockets if you remembered to build factories, for a small price. You can play Mexico, Italy (Naples), Ethiopia, Malta, and more. Initially I didn't agree with making these paid DLC, but then, I did pay good money for both expansions when they were released, so eh, whatever. There's new variations on old gameplay-- the US civ adds states rather than politicians as you age up, each of which add unique cards. This is incredibly powerful, and yet, you need to have a steady supply of experience to really take advantage of it.

I don't know if there's a US Civil War scenario or anything like the Napoleonic or Crimean Wars or the Boshin War in Japan, but if modding is a thing, these are a few things an enterprising modder can come up with.

My main gripe with this game is, its copy protection apparently doesn't like SteamOS or Proton and locked me out of the game during the campaign until I restarted. This is completely vanilla, nothing but DLCs, so good job, Microsoft, you've demonstrated yet again why locking software down only hurts the honest users.

Also, the Japanese civ uses the original non-native voice actors. I'd hoped they used the voice audio from the Japanese version which was far better, but alas, I have to listen to barely-fluent Japanese with a heavy accent.

The perennial bridesmaid of the AOE series, Age 3 stands out with it's slightly unusual timeframe and a bunch of weird mechanics for an RTS that make it a unique and fun experience for folks who are into the genre, while also being a bit more relaxed and welcoming to new players to the genre.

If AOE 2 is the perfect example of a well executed, classic RTS experience, AOE 3 tries to differenciate itself. Units use damage multipliers instead of static damage bonuses against their counters (and sometimes deal less damage in general against units they're bad against, such as Crossbowmen doing less damage to Cavalry that counter them), villagers instantly depositing what they gather into your stockpile instead of needing drop off points like lumber camps - a big change that incentivizes the player to go out and hog the map early instead of just focusing on your base's immediate surroundings, since going out to hunt animals is much better than farming food. A separate interface that lets you ship over units, resource and upgrades from your home country, which greatly affects your strategy and playstyle - for example, you can ship over extra units to help in a rush or to defend yourself, or ship wood to build a bunch of buildings quickly, or send over upgrades to make certain units stronger - there's a ton of variety and unorthodox choices for you to try, which also goes a long way to make civilizations stand out and be unique amongst themselves (for instance, the Dutch make their villagers with Coin, not Food. Spanish ship stuff super fast, Maltese can work better next to defensive buildings). Some civilizations are really good at shipping over units and be aggressive, while others have more economy-focused cards to choose from. Aging up is spicy too, as when you age up, you choose what bonus you want to go with your aging up, such as units, buildings or resources.

I love the game, and I think it deserves to be credited as a great spin on RTS fundamentals. I also believe it's quite a lot easier to play and get into than AOE 2, for such reasons as villagers not needing drop offs, units generally being tankier and more forgiving to use and shipments compensating for whatever problem you're facing at a given situation.

I played Age of Empires III a lot, but I'm always a little skeptical of updated/renewed versions of games. Like, why buy another copy of what I already have? But I'm happy to report that my fears were unfounded. AOEIIIDE is an amazing game. I love the updates they made to the gameplay and graphics, I love that they took the time to work on their depictions of the Native American civs and actually included the groups they were representing (this was what made me buy the game initially), and I love the new civs they keep adding. The Americans and (now quickly) the Italians are some of my favorites to play as in skirmishes, but it's so cool how different some of the other new ones are, like the Ethiopians, Hausa, and Mexicans. Every time I play I have fun, which is truly the most important measure of all.

another problem is the fact the renaming of ages and names of troops and buildings. the time period had plantations yes plantations not estates. this was a time of historical colonialism sorry that is just a fact  of life. the devs trying to erase that is dangerous and backward thinking. you can be sorry for the past but still respect history and portray it the way it happened not what you feel is the better option that is sad... there was the bad and the good and the bad again in the 1700s and before, but that is what this game pis set in so pay homage and respect the time period. i understand you want to pay better homage to the local tribes in this game or better representations, but they were not always the victims when in the story missions you have to basically be forced to act like the Indians are just the saints and white man evil is such an embarrassment. both sides sinned its a part of life and we are all humans. so instead of sucking off people and making sure its a PG remaster of the OG age 3 2007 version and allow what made age 3 so good and just doing what they did with age 2 remaster, they decided to make backwards progress. by far the most waste of money. i was so excited at first this was the game that defined my passions of history and learning why certain historical events happened. i am glad i am educated enough to know this is not doing an good service to anyone and its a real shame. do not waste your time. if you are a real fan of age 3 you will not like it. 

In the end, i wish i had a refund this game is a pile of crap. go play the original age 3 there is no age 3 remaster never heard of it.

Edit: The game has improved and I enjoy it now, but I will stay true to what i said already and still say The PC culture is still annoying and the game is a massive memory dump. If they just did not change so much of the OG game i would finally give this a thumbs up but nope. it still feels like a different game of its own and that is not a bad thing but it is not homage to the original age 3

I have played thousands of hours of AOE 1, 2, 3 including AOE 2 competitive. I am only mentioning this to put in some context about my background with this game and where I am coming from. 

[b]TLDR: Horrible UI, terrible AI, single player got gutted, I am disappointed, 2007 version is better than this version(except in some aspects of graphics)[/b]

[h2]Positive[/h2]
* The cinematic graphics and the particle physics are the biggest improvement. How a burning building falls or how a burning ship sinks looks pretty good.
* 2 new civs (AOE 2 DE offered so much more though)
[b] And that's about it. [/b]

[h2]Negative[/h2]
* There is no more progression in single player. I miss seeing the xp numbers when I kill a unit or destroy a building. I liked the way you could unlock different cards slowly. They could have made a progression system for single player and everything unlocked in multiplayer. Also, I do not think this game will ever become as big as aoe 2 in the multiplayer space for many different reasons. The strength of this game was the single player progression and they gutted it.
* The UI is terrible. I played two games in Himalayas and Deccan(About 75 minutes); it strained my eyes. And I am used to playing 6-7 hours of back to back competitive aoe 2 games. Everything seemed a bit darker, dull and it was hard to discern some colors. It's harder to discern treasures and treasure guardians compared to the 2007 game. The way score is shown is obstructive- it blocks too much of the screen if there are 8 players. Also, it doesn't crosses of the name of a player if they resign.
* The AI still stays in the island and doesn't know what to do
* There are a lot of other pet peeves of mine(e.g. Colonial age -> Commerce Age, native american gold mining and treasure guardian conversion etc)

<rant>This game had a lot of potential. But it seems like this game doesn't know what it wants to be. It doesn't have the cache of civilizations or the  game balance(Good luck fighting against a frigate or iron clad with some war canoe) and dynamics that aoe 2 have to have a vibrant multiplayer; yet it wants to cater to that space and gutted the progression. It got some home cities to give you a sense of customization; yet in reality it's laughable in 2020. The AI tries to be taunting or encouraging like Sid Meir's Civilizations, but has a very limited amount of response. By trying to be so many things, this game fails to have its own unique identity and by not excelling at any single aspect it lacks the element that would attract players to have a 3rd, 4th or nth game. I was so excited to play this game. But after playing for only 20 minutes, I started to miss the 2007 version. At this point, I doubt that I will even cross 20 hours in this game.</rant>

This is the best RTS of the Age series.  People got scared of the initial deck-building system upon its original release because they were not used to it from Age II - but honestly it adds a ton of depth and strategy in a good way.  This is a faster-paced game then Age II but I think it deviates in the best ways possible.  It is also a lot more polished than Age IV in my opinion, and has improved a lot in the bugs/quality of life department from the DE release a couple years ago.  Age III is a complicated but rewarding game and deserves to be played by more of the fanbase.  Highly recommended for anyone who likes RTS.  My only quibble is that I wish the system for hosting games in lobby was improved a bit and I miss the old ranking system from the legacy game.

As someone who grew up on AoE2, and then later got interested in competitive RTS play, I feel that AoE3 is not really an eSports-viable title and the civs are probably a little too unbalanced (lookin' at you, America) to be a great competitive game...

But AoE3 is REALLY freaking fun.

I love the card system, which effectively allows you to customize your playstyle and build to the kinds of things you enjoy in a game. I especially enjoy that you can have different decks that specialize you in different ways. So if for example you're playing a team game in the pocket, you can build KILLER econ. If you're on an edge defending, you can build for a turtle style, or hyperfocus one of your military units.

I love that each civilization feels unique with multiple unique units, and different core mechanics for basic things like villager construction or age advancement. This is a major draw for me, actually, over AoE2, where most of the civs have a sort of subtractive design (there's the big tech tree that everyone shares and each civ is restricted to only certain parts of it; their flavor is defined entirely by civ bonuses and their single unique unit/tech). The only sameyness I felt in AoE3 was between the different European civs.

I love the experience system and how controlling trade routes is really important. It gives an important objective and a reason to keep moving out on the map to expand and defend.

I love that there's only three primary resources instead of four. Stone always felt a bit extraneous in AoE2.

I love the DE's options to change up the UI, and the other quality-of-life features.

TL;DR: AoE3 is a ton of fun as a casual customizable RTS, and it plays best in that spirit, I think!

They make a ton of great changes but there are a HEAVY amount of crashes happening right now. I've crashed 4 times in 1 day already in both multiplayer and single player games. 

While they have added tons of new maps and scenarios it's no fun if my top of the line computer can't run it without the game randomly crashing, which is a shame because I like the new civilizations and content. I like that they added up to 4 teams as an option, I like that they allowed multiples of the same civ in single player skirmish mode and I loved that you can change the colors of civilizations to whatever you want through the accessibility section of the options menu. A great game is under all of this but until the game stays stable and doesn't crash it's not worth it. Unless you are really impatient I recommend you wait for a couple of months, the game is good but it is NOT in a playable state.

Personally my fav of the AoE series (maybe excluding AoM). The campaign though isnt as fun as the faction campaigns of AoE 2 were, but the historical battles still a nice variation, especially since you now can play them in coop if you want.
Gameplay wise id say its a bit less eco-micro heavy than the predecessor and offers great faction to faction variety, especially for civilisations of different "add-ons" or faction DLCs, but also the "standart" european faction have quite big play differences.
I can see how the unlocked cards in the DE can be a bit detromental to players in their gameplay progression experience, but personally I think it allows for a better mp experience, and less requirements for grinding, especially if you want to try arround with the factions as also the cards vary quite a bit how you would play a faction, so having them unlock them especially on the higher levels was quite a hassle back than, if you need like 20 hours per faction to unlock its potential.
Additionally you get a quite regular update service, though on longer games you can still experience some Network instability.

Generally id say its a worthwhile RTS game, which is a bit more accessable than AoE 2 and offers great gameplay variety, but also competetive optimization options.

this used to be a negative review, but with the amount of care and love they've poured into this game after release, i think it's worth an updated review for my favourite RTS of all time. i want to amend all my critiques of the game i listed when this game first came out by dissecting the original review, so i will highlight my new comments:

don't get me wrong, i absolutely loved the original AOE3, one of my earliest PC gaming memories was begging for the asian dynasties DLC when i was 8 years old, but this remaster seems to do more things wrong than right and tarnishes some of my memories of the original

pros:

-new factions are interesting [especially now that there's 3 (soon to be 4) new DLC packs, adding a total of 8 new factions not in the original game]
-graphics are a nice upgrade [somehow even better with photo mode added]
-integration with xbox live is pretty nice
-price is cheaper than the original
-having all cards from the beginning for multiplayer [can see as to why hardcore players hate this]
-some historical accuracy changes are cool, such as the updating of flags and name changes to things such as a plantation, the sioux and iroquois, even if it is kind of lazily implemented in some areas

cons:

-campaign is totally broken, don't expect to be able to complete it without using some cheats as cutscenes freeze, units will get stuck in terrain making them unusable and some mission objectives don't actually work, forcing you to advance to the next level using commands [very rarely get these issues now]
-too many crashes when doing basic things in skirmish, such as using samurai to attack arsenals which has crashed me 3 times [happy to report you can use your samurai to destroy as many arsenals as you want!]
-having all cards unlocked makes single-player pointless, as you have no end goal and no budget decks to use, good for multiplayer as i stated earlier since it eliminates grinding and allows you to be more strategic with friends, but makes single-player skirmishes pretty one-sided
-changing the names of the first two ages, this change is so stupid to me as they're trying to erase an age of colonialism in a game about colonialism
-straight up changing the warchief abilities for the native american factions, alongside changing their method of collecting coin, i understand they want to promote historical accuracy, but this changes the actual gameplay of the game which i dislike quite a lot
-the graphics are nice as described earlier, but they're way too blurry and this is apparent in cutscenes or if you zoom really close in, not the 4k graphics we were promised
-the total rearrangement of the UI was completely unneeded and the fact we can't revert it to exactly as it was in the original AOE3 adds further insult to injury [should still be an option to rearrange but it's much, much better in hindsight]

overall, i still love this game regardless of how unfaithful to the original and buggy of a remaster this is, but i'd really wait until the bugs and glitches are ironed out a bit more before you purchase it, i really hoped i could give this the most glowing review possible but until some major changes are made, i just can't recommend anyone buy this in its current state. some good updates have made the game more stable but most of the listed issues still persist, such as units being stuck in buildings and general multiplayer instability

AoE III: DE is a remaster of the 2005 Age of Empires III. As a RTS game, it brings some unique features such as build limits and the “home city” concept. The gameplay is rather mediocre. Killing units isn’t as satisfying as slaughtering Zerglings in StarCraft II. Overall, the game feels slow compared to more modern RTS games. The game comes with nine campaigns as well as multiple missions based on historical battles.

I’m giving it a thumbs up for the vast amount of SP content included with the game. Get the game if you’re looking for a RTS that covers the Age of Discovery. It’s also commendable for featuring India and various Native American cultures. Don’t get the game if you’re looking for the best gameplay or MP experience.
love it! blast to my past!

As a long-standing fan of the Age of Empires Series I couldn't wait to see the Definitive Edition. And I wasn't disappointed. With a much needed graphical overhaul and better cut-scenes the game delivers what it has been generally advertised as: a remaster. Fans of the older title will find that certain features have been completely removed (the old ESO framework), balanced (it is no longer necessary to grind the City Cards thus making the game more friendly towards the casual players), re-branded (the European term Iroquois has been changed to the native  Haudenosaunee and the more broad term Sioux to the more specific Lakota; the gold-producing building for the Europeans has been changed from Plantation to Estate and the Age of Colonialism to the Age of Commerce) or introduced for the first time (colour change, more Revolutionary States, the addition of the Swedes and the Inca)

Regarding the re-branding there have been many comments and reviews already but I still feel that a small mention should be made. The fact that the old Plantations are now called Estates is still correct (if not more), historically speaking since the landowners would have referred to them as such. Secondly, the fact that it was Colonialism and now it is Commerce is a way of shedding the old Victorian view (much of which the whole Western World has about this period). Everybody is free to disagree but making a choice based only on these two aspects I believe is a mistake.

All in all it is a title which is well-worth the money due to the enhanced graphics, high quality sound, and even if you play only the campaign it will be sufficient to justify the purchase. Since they've also added the US, Mexican and African Civilisations the game has also received more variety.

Add events such as Thanks Giving event. (As done in AOE2DE)

Update: I'm changing this review to a positive one (find original negative review further down) because the support by FE for this game, despite it's relative low player numbers, has been extraordinary. They still release new DLC's as well as patches regularly and have also fixed most of the bugs. Hence, I'd definitely recommend the game now if you like RTS games. Nevertheless, it's a shame the game got released so unfinished. But this seems to be common practice nowadays...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

[b]TLDR[/b]: The game got released too early and at the time of writing is a buggy mess. Wait till they have fixed everything.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

[b]Full review[/b]:

Looks like Forgotten Empires learned nothing from their previous releases (AoE 1 + 2 DE). Both were buggy and unfinished at release. While AoE 2 could be saved since it's been pretty popular all along, AoE 1 pretty much died due to still remaining problems up until today (poor performance, horrible pathfinding).

For AoE 3 DE they do the same mistakes again. The release feels rushed since the game is a buggy mess and some features are completely missing. I participated in the closed beta (April), in the MP stress test (September) as well as in the preview event (October), reported many bugs and missing features and so did a lot of other people. To my surprise, many bugs reported in the closed beta (April) were still there in the MP stress test (September). A lot of requested features during the MP stress test are still missing today. 

Here are a number of issues currently ingame:

[list]
[*] Poor [b]optimization for widescreens[/b]: The main menu looks weird and unfinished. All the cut scenes are 16:9. The home cities were not adjusted to widescreens and you will find big bars on both sides when you enter the city. 
[*] The new cities can't be [b]customized[/b]. Though I really do not care about this, this is just another sign of "Oh shit, we're running out of time!"
[*] The [b]multiplayer menu[/b] is not very intuitive. When in lobby browser, you won't find a "create lobby" button. Rather you will have to go back and click somewhere else.
[*] No [b]unlocks in MP[/b]: This really lowers the longtime motivation. At least in AoE2 DE, you can unlock profile pictures. Also take notes from SC2.
[*] Obvious [b]balance issues[/b], some which are new (new civs), some are old and been known since 2007: French cuirassiers.
[*] The [b]AI[/b] is dumb as a bucket of water. The campaign is a joke, even on hardest difficulty.
[*] You don't really notice when somebody [b]resigns[/b] because the sound it plays is really low and sounds rather trivial.
[*] [b]Ship destruction physics[/b] got pretty much completely removed
[*] Units get [b]stuck[/b] on high terrain and in buildings
[*] Poor [b]performance[/b], never over 60 FPS. Though it's usually well above 30 and not as horrible as AoE 1 and 2 were at release (or still are).
[*] Blunt and boring [b]achievements[/b]. Why do I care about achievements? Because they add a certain replayability and challenge to the game.
[*] [b]Unnecessary changes[/b] no player asked for: renaming some natives and ages.
[*] No [b]new campaigns[/b] for the new civs. Again this feels like the devs rushed the game or just didn't care enough to add some.
[/list]

And these are the only issues I come up with right now. As you can see the list is long and goes on and on. Most of these issues, like the resign sound, are easily fixable in a matter of days/weeks. Now you see why I think this game should've been delayed.

Of course there are also a lot of positive aspects like the graphics, the UI, historical battles and an almost lag-free MP (at least in beta). Too bad the game overall still feels like a beta.

AoE III. My childhood. I was so excited when the Definitive Edition was announced. But in the current state of the game, it's inferior to the original.

I don't understand the change of Native American civilizations. The Iroquois were supposed to represent the Iroquois confederation, and I see nothing offensive in using a name people can *actually* somewhat pronounce. You put so much effort into making native civilizations historically accurate, despite the fact that NONE of the European civilizations are historically accurate. You have Napoleon fighting Ivan the Terrible for crying out loud. But it doesn't matter now does it, since Europeans aren't minorities. 

Now to actual gameplay. 
I've only played a couple of games I must admit, but I can only pinpoint a few negatives. 

The AI: It's acting very... weirdly. In Age II it was building houses very close to my town center for no apparent reason, also sending settlers to resources very close to my base. It didn't built any trading posts and it didn't seem to build up as much. Multiple smaller raids, all easy to kill off, something very different from what I'm used with classic AoE. It's armies also seem to protect their villagers a lot more, which is good I guess?

The UI: Oh God. It's a mess. I appreciate trying to simplify it somewhat, but the classic UI is a nightmare to use. all sort of extra buttons, the health bar is WAY too small, and other frustrating tiny things. I appreciate the further zoom though. 

Gameplay and balancing: I've only played European civs, and everything mostly feels the same. One thing I am greatly saddened by is the elimination of the home city XP system. It was a very fun thing to grind in SP, bit unfair in the MP but I hope they'll adjust this soon. One bug I experienced is that after advancing to Age IV, my town center disappeared. I have no clue why, it didn't get deleted, still showed on the minimap, and received shipments there, but I could not select it.

Graphics: They're better. Can't complain. Except Lizzie. What have you done to my poor Lizzie, she looks like some crappy devianart character.

Overall I am disappointed. I hope the devs will listen to the community and fix some critical issues.

[h1]TL;DR: If you are a fan of AOE = Do not buy! If you just like RTSs = [b]DO NOT BUY!![/b][/h1]

Absolutely terrible. Forget how gimmicky the card system is, even if you had amnesia and forgot the previous AOEs existed, as a basic RTS it fails: 
* Bounding boxes for unis don't correlate to models, so when you click on what you think unit A is, unit B responds
* Ships don't have stances, so you can't tell them to stay put in one place. They automatically chase anything. So to kill a ducking cow they go head first into an area full of castles or towers. Smart -_-
* Keyboard shortcuts missing or inconsistent: some are lower case in the HUD. Did you ever notice that l and i are very similar? This is why they SHOULD ALWAYS BE UPPERCASE (just to make sure you know the difference...)
* Some actions cannot be queued and some can, very arbitrary.
