As a huge fan of the Age of Empires franchise since I was a kid, a franchise which I got to know thanks to Age II, I must say it took me until the release of the Definitive Edition to actually get into Age of Empires III. What's more, I didn't even really get into the game until two months ago (that'd be, February 2022). The reason for that is quite simple: AoE III changed a lot of things from the "original" experience I liked from the first two games, and thus, it was kinda hard getting used to it. However, after putting a little over a hundred hours, I must say I enjoyed the game.

So, what is Age of Empires III? Well, while I said it changes things from the previous games, at its core, it's still an Age of Empires game, that is, a RTS set during a specific historical period, which allows you to play as several different civilizations from the era. In this case, the game followed the historical progression of the franchise: the first game focused on Ancient History, the second game was centered on the Middle Ages and early colonialism, and this game covers a timeframe going from early colonialism to the industrial revolution; I'd say it's just shy of falling into World War I territory. Honestly, I'd say it's kinda a shame that for Age of Empires IV they decided to go back to the Medieval period of history; while it's certainly one of my favourite historical periods, I'd have loved to see and Age IV focusing on the World Wars. Anyway, I digress, back to the review!

The core gameplay in this game is shaken up quite a bit. While you still gather resources, advance in age gaining access to more powerful buildings and units and such, a brand new mechanic is the shipment system. Since you play as a colonial power, you get access to shipments from your home country; these work as cards you can activate during the game, which provide different bonuses, give you a couple of units upon their arrival, or other benefits. Before playing a game, you can build "decks" from the different shipment cards you have available. Once in game, you earn experience for stuff like constructing certain buildings or killing enemy units, and this, in turn, grants you shipments. A really interesting mechanic, as the shipments can help you turn the tide of battle if you send them at the right time.

Another big change is that, in this game, there's five different ages instead of four, with the first age, the aptly named Exploration Age, being focused in exploration. Whenever you start a game, you get an explorer unit alongside your starting villagers. What differentiates this explorer from the starting scout you'd get in a game like Age of Empires II, is that it's more of a "hero" unit, with regenerating health (while idle) and special abilities. This explorer is a really important unit, as, scattered around the map, there are several treasures that can provide you extra resources or other bonuses. The explorer himself cannot die, if his health ever reaches zero, they fall to the ground and slowly start regenerating their HP; you can send an unit to revive them, or pay a ransom to recover them.

Other gameplay changes include the fact that different regions get different mechanics, and even civs from the same region might have their differences. What I mean with this is that, for example, European powers would be the ones that most closely resemble classic AoE games in their gameplay: villagers gather resources, you age up through the town center when getting enough resources, and so on. Meanwhile, Native American civs, while playing somewhat similar to the European powers, get a special "Community Plaza" building that, when being worked on by villagers, provides different bonuses to training time, combat strenght, and so on. Finally, we have the Asian powers, which don't age up in the "traditional" way, rather, you have to build wonders in order to age up (in a sense, this is similar to how aging up works in Age of Empires IV, at least during the beta). As for the DLC civs, I'll talk about them in their respective reviews.

Damn, I've written a lot, and I've only talked about gameplay! Haven't even mentioned stuff like graphics and such. Well, I did say it had plenty of changes in regards to gameplay. So, when it comes to graphics, I must say I haven't played the original, so I can't really say how they compare, but personally, I liked the way the game looks. However, I will recognize that, at times, the amount of details makes it hard to see the units in the map.

Something I was forgetting to mention was the singleplayer content, which is what interests me the most (I barely touched MP). In this regard, I must say I was slightly disappointed to learn that the campaigns were fictional stories set during the period represented in the game. The very first campaign has many fantastical elements, and while it's a fun campaign, something you'd expect from a swashbuckler film, having more historical stuff would've been nice. Of course, it seems that during the game's "original run", so to speak, the devs must've realized this. While the second campaign, from the Warchiefs expansion, seemed to tone down the fantasy elements, the final campaign, The Asian Dynasties, took a more historical approach (though with some big creative liberties in some parts). Luckily enough, by the time they made the Definitive Edition, the devs were nice enough to add a couple of Historical Battles, and they're a nice way to learn a few things from the period. Also, while they're described as "Co-Op Historical Battles", they can still be played solo. And once you're done with the campaign, you can go to Skirmish mode, or even play MP if that's what you like.

Phew, honestly, I'm surprised this review has gone on to be so long. I honestly didn't know what to write when I started it, and now I feel there's a lot of stuff that I'm forgetting. Like mentioning the soundtrack, for example, which is great. Or the customization options, as the Home City of whichever civ you last used in Skirmish mode gets displayed on the main menu. Anyway, I must say that, after my 100+ hours in this game, I enjoyed it, so I can recommend it for any RTS fan out there.

I love the original and the 2nd one to death but not needing resource drop off points was one of the biggest improvements to this series.  More focus on tactics and battle and less on economy.  This isn't to say you can ignore economy, build orders and resources are definitely important but less so than previously.

I think they did a fantastic job at the remaster and adding in new civs.  That being said, some of the new civs are way to gimicky and complex.  I play to relax as the older I get the slower I get.  For me, the USA and other civs have too much RNG for what you may get and the build orders are so strict that it isn't fun, at least for me.  If that's your thing, then this is right up your alley.  

Overall, RTS these days are often drowned out due to the Gen Z desire for the next Call of Duty 800,000 or Battlefield 9,000,000.  It's refreshing to see a company target their older gamers a well as new ones trying to get into the RTS field.  This is about as modern as it gets for a classic game.  Give it a shot, you won't regret it.

I bought this after my disc drive stopped working, so I actually have around 1000 hours in this game.

I can't recommend this version of the game for one single reason. The new devs got blackout drunk, beat each other in the head with bats, then decided to do some programming while drunk and concussed. It's the only explanation for why they completely ruined the one thing that made this game different to other RTS games.

The Shipment system. Playing Skirmish maps to level up Cities and unlock better Cards made Skimish maps have a point to them. It meant that playing Skirmish meant something. For some reason the devs decided to insert their heads into their rears and scrapped that. This version of the game has all cards unlocked right away. There's no point in leveling up your city because you don't need to unlock Cards. Now it's just another generic RTS like all the others.

They should have left the Card system alone. At the very least it should be an option to toggle on/off in the Settings. I played this game a LOT. I got every civilisation up to at least lv 50, then got a new computer and lost the progress and did it again. I haven't bothered with it this time because there's no point. I played the Campaigns, tested the new Civilisations and new maps, then lost interest.
Great RTS and better than most!

This game is spectacularly fun - I am so happy that there has been a renewed interest in this old game and my oh my has it gotten pretty.
Since its original release this game has received a ton of quality of life fixes that really help the game function on a micro/macro level. The display of gather rates, the ability to zoom out super far, and updated hotkeys really help this game fly.
There is a decent amount of DLC content for this game as well! Though I think its a bit over-priced. That being said, each additional civilization on top of the base game's Asian, Native American, and European civs are all quite fun and play pretty differently from each other.

Although game is entertaining, the multiplayer is kind of unfriendly... 

Good thing I just play single-player. Gone through a bunch of skirmish games and wanted to see what tactics human opponents would use and so I wanted to try multiplayer at least once before I had to uninstall it for another game. However, never got a game going even against CPU opponents because I was new to multiplayer. Going to uninstall now (so I can install something else, not because of the multiplayer issue) so you can see how many hours I had into the game at this point. 

So, ok for single-player, but not really for multiplayer unless you're hardcore.

Been a fan of Age of Empires 1 and 2 since the starting days of my gaming. Bought 3rd version on Steam after so many years (and also to support the series... bought all the Age of Empires games). However, I can see now why the original third version didn't got as popular as the second. This game doesn't really feels like Age of "Empires" game. This is set in the gunpowder era, rather than the medieval period, which I don't enjoy as much as swords and bows. The card system and the Home City mechanism is just an overheard to manage, specially since we have to level up each Home City separately. I'm still playing teh campaigns of this game though. The graphics of this game are extremely amazing. We can also zoom in and admire the detailed graphics, which is my most favorite aspect of this game. I often find myself zooming in and taking screenshots of various locations in the maps.

Okay, but has some problems.

Note: I play almost only multiplayer skirmish against bots (with friends).


- Pathing is bad especially for groups of ships and big groups of military units
- Multiplayer games have at least 30% chance that one of the players has a game crash (the good thing is that AoE creates a savegame which you can load and rehost the game. But loading this 10MB file takes 5 minutes, WHAT THE HELL?)
- bad support for hosting games without AoE network (you can host a game in your local network, but they prevent you to connect to a different network (e.g. public IP), There is no options to connect by IP.
- bad performance optimization for higher unit counts like 5 players at near max unit count (my system: Ryzen 5900x and RX 6900 XT)


In the beginning, all those possibilities like the card system fell overwhelming (and some of the cards are really badly explained), but after some games and some research, this actually allows you to adjust your cards to fit your playstyle.

The multiple different nations are interesting and the different maps are cool.

Loved the old 3. I like 4 but my wife thinks its too much like 2. They're still working out the kinks but with the better graphics and new civs we're both happy for the new definitive edition.

All cards are unlocked at the beginning of the game. I'm a solo player with no interest in playing in the online community. Biggest change imo is that there's no point to upgrading your home city and unlocking new cards. 

In the original game, when all nations started at level 1, it made sense that the starter cards weren't the best. As your home nation leveled up, you can unlock cards that show progress, similiar to how nations progressed through time. Would love to play all the new civs added to the game with these mechanics, but it's not to be.

If you're a solo player that wants progression when you're playing, DON'T BUY THIS GAME.

EDIT: Online players are brigading how nice it is for all the cards to be unlocked. Good for you. IMO the cards SHOULD be unlocked if you're playing online, just not for solo play.

Fun game to play all around and great multiplayer experience

[h1] The Good [/h1]

Age of Empires III DE is a classic real-time strategy and that is just great. The idea of getting experience in order to get shipments from hometown is an idea I loved first time I played the game and still enjoy it. The campaign is also enjoyable and even interested me enough to finish it, which is more than I could say about campaigns in previous installments. Overall I would say that AoE III DE has everything a good RTS game should have.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

Age of Empires III DE has much to offer while also lacking some features from previous installments which would enhance the game experience in my opinion. When I focus on what is missing, first it is setting [b]maximum population limit[/b] for the game, but I see that the limit (200-220) is necessary because the game is [b]poorly optimized and would not handle higher numbers.[/b] 

Another thing I'm missing is possibility to set difficulty for each AI separately. There are quite bug jumps between moderate, hard and hardest difficulties so it would be nice to have an option to mix them. And the most annoying missing feature is a possibility to play LAN locally - [b]now you have to play LAN games on online servers[/b] even though me and my wife, whom I play with, sit next to each other and because of this the game sometimes goes out of sync or just lags because of connectivity problems. 

Last thing I'm missing is from the original game (not DE) - it is an option to get experience for each civilization and unlock new home shipment possibilities for you. Now you start with everything unlocked which makes sense for competitive online playing, but they took away the possibility of making a progress in the skirmish game, and it was one of the things I loved in the original. 

[h1] Summary [/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]

✪ [i]Hometown shipments[/i] 
✪ [i]Explorers[/i] - adding Heroes to the game works good
✪ [i]Enjoyable campaigns[/i] 
✪ [i]Great graphics[/i] 
✪ [i]Easy to learn, hard to master[/i] 
✪ [i]Quick paced game[/i] 
✪ [i]New well-arranged UI [/i] 

[b]Cons[/b]

✪ [i]Bad optimization[/i] 
✪ [i]Population limit[/i] in skirmish is unchangeable
✪ [i]Removed hometown progress [/i] from the game
✪ [i]Online servers even for LAN [/i]  
✪ [i]Poor AI difficulty scaling[/i] 
✪ [i]Unbalanced civilizations[/i] 

[b]7.5/10[/b] 

Simply put, the game is great, but could be even better. 

If you want to play competitive modes (against other players) I would recommend you to just go and play age of empires II, which is much more adjusted to these purposes. But if you like to play solo or with friends against AI there are not many good modern RTSs to choose from and this one would be great fit for you.

Definitely have mixed feelings about this game, but I love AOE 3 so much I have to give it the thumbs up. I'll start with the good things about this game: The multiplayer matchmaking, and the updated graphics are the biggest pluses to me. Back in the day on ESO, getting a multiplayer game started was such a pain because everyone would look at your rank and you'd be too high or too low ranked and you'd get kicked from the lobby, but now that there's a working matchmaker I can actually play the game again. Another big change I love is that you no longer have to grind out homecity levels to get all the good cards, you get access to all the cards for every civ. Finally I like the addition of new civs. I played the asian dynasties expansion for a long time so I was used to all the civs and having some new ones to mess with was nice, and I hear there might be more getting added. 

Now onto some of the bad stuff. While I love the addition of the matchmaking, it is pretty buggy. There are times where the queue timer will go for like 10 seconds and then just kick me out of the queue for no reason and I have to restart my game to fix it. Another thumbs down for me is the awkward changes made to the game to cover up the concept of colonialism and westward expansion even though that's what the whole timeline of the game is centered around. Another complaint I have is navigating the menus. I've had the game bug out on me when I try to rename my homecity or my explorer, I've had the game take me from level 2 of the blood campaign to the India campaign for no reason. So like most games nowa days its pretty unpolished which is depressing. 

So in summary it's fine. It's an improvement from the og AOE 3 in several areas and it is nice to see this game being played again my more people eventhough it does sicken me in principal to buy a game I already own again. If you loved aoe 3 or any of the expansions go ahead and try this (ideally when it's on sale). Just don't expect as much love, or special attention to be given to this game like its aoe 2 de counterpart.

Back around when this game (or the pack that included both expansions) came out, I was sorely disappointed. It wasn't Age of Empires 2-2, and that made me sad and confused. Everything was moving so fast, and there was too much different stuff for each civilization, and shipments/home cities touched me in a weird place.

Now, it feels like everything makes sense. I love that it gets going faster than a match of Age of Empires 2. I love how most civilizations actually feel different from each other, barring some of the European civilizations. I adore the concept of the home city, essentially a building that sends upgrades without ever being at risk while using a resource gained from doing basic tasks. I've discovered that I may like Age of Empires 3 even better than I once liked 2, and the Definitive Edition has made everything even better.

There are still some issues I have, of course. Age of Empires 2 has a very mature scenario modding community that Age of Empires 3 never seemed to get, and the base campaigns in Age of Empires 3 aren't as replayable in my eyes. And while post-release DLC has added some amazing civilizations (like the Hausa and Mexicans), we've only gotten a few post-release Historical Battles (1-scenario campaigns) for solo players. Luckily, I love how Skirmish matches feel in this game, but the campaigns could be expanded on a bit, even if via modding.

Overall, Age of Empires 3 may feel a little weird to people who have played the other games. There are no gather points, training can be done in batches, home cities ship units and upgrades, you can collect treasures... the list goes on. But if you can get into the fast-paced exploration and building and conquest, it can be very fun. ([strike]Please come play the game and get invested in modding it. There's so much untapped potential in these game systems.[/strike])

If you want to try an RTS game that gets going fast and has some (apparently unique) mechanics, give this version of Age of Empires 3 a try. If you get hooked, there's even DLC civilizations to try out now, with the potential for at least one more on the way. Let's keep exploring this new world together!

Age of Empires III: Definitive Edition (aka AoE3:DE) is a real-time strategy video game, and in my opinion one of the better ones out there, maybe even the best. I'll go trough various elements of the game design, and other features such as a story campaign, historical battles and such. I admit that I haven't finished any of the story campaigns or historical battles, but I feel that majority of its playerbase didn't too. I might be wrong, but I'll make one thing clear straight away: you don't play this game for its story.

Right, let's start of by describing the gameplay. Gameplay-wise it's your standard RTS game, but I'll elaborate it anyways: you recruit villagers to gather resources and build your base, and you train your military units to defend your base and attack the enemy base (standard "skirmish" match). It may sound simple, but truth be told that it's way more complex than that, at least in this game. You have to collect resources to make more villagers to gather even more resources as well as to 
 build your base, on top of that you have to recruit your military units in order to defend against enemy, or to destroy them. It may sound simple, but the trick is that your very playstyle depends on the faction you pick. Oh yes, there are factions. A lot of them. I don't know exactly how many, add some from DLCs, but you have a generous selection when it comes to factions, and thus the playstyle you need to master to be proficient and formidable opponent.

Difficulty wise, there are two options: you eighter play skirmishes (and a couple of other game modes against CPU) and you pick a difficulty there, or you decide to go to online ranked match making, or to a server browser, only to lose four matches in a row, and then by miracle you manage to overrun your opponent who has even less of an idea what he's doing. I don't mean to scare you away, but playing against other players is rather competitive, especially ranked (at least I got that impression). So yeah, playing against players is damn difficult, but don't worry about it: considering you're reading this review, you have access to internet, and therefore to Youtube and Google, which translates to capability to search for tutorials and guides how to get basics down, as well as some guides about playing different nations. That, combined by your unbreakable willpower to get out there and try and win against other players will make you a better player. Well, maybe not over night, but after some time, you'll be micro and macro your army and economy like a pro.

Graphics in this game are OK, nothing special. Since this is Definitive Edition, there are some fancy features included compared to the good 'ol AoE3 from 2005 (how time flies). You do need a somewhat decent rig to run this game, though. There are some neat nature and environment details here and there, should you have some spare time in a match to pay attention to.

As for the lenght of a game, it really depends what you define as a "game". A skirmish match? From 5 mins to extreme couple of hours (my record is around 90 or so mins in 2v2 skirmish online).For the game itself? I guess you could say infinite, or at least while there's a steady player base playing this game. This game is a masterpiece, almost, and I think lots of people will play AoE3:DE regardless of AoE4 being out for some time now. So, lenght of AoE3:DE is basically as long as you make it. You can play it 10 mins and never touch it again, or you could develop a crippling addiction and competitiveness and rack up 1000 hours in a month (it's not technically possible, don't bother lol).

As for the replay value, like I said: infinite times. It's like Battlefield, you win/lose a match, and hop into another one. 

*Please note I'm mostly reffering to the online aspect of the game, because that's why you decided to try this game out... Right?*

SFX and OST in this game is above average, slightly below brilliant in my opinion. The main theme is recognised immediately, and the rest of the OST is fitting. You won't really remember the rest of the OST, but it doesn't matter, since it's there to amplify the already amazing game experience.

I should touch on the story a bit more, but like I mentioned before: I haven't finished any of the campaigns. To be honest, I don't think most RTS's are a good platform for a story. It doesn't mean you can't have a good story, but if the good story is what you're after, there are lots of other games that do that brilliantly.

Aaaaand last bit about censorship and localisation. Nothing worth censoring, at least the way I see it. I think game design shouldn't differ no matter in what region you are, which means everyone gets the same gameplay experience. Yaaaaay. Though there were some language options, but nothing too much. Could be extended in my opinion. You wouldn't even need another voice actiong, since all unit voice lines are spoken in the unit native language (Brits speak English, Germans speak German, French speak Baguette ect.).

Of course, if you're lazy and decided to skip all this effort I put into the review, here's an extra short review: 

Buy it. It's a great game. Sure, there are some minor bugs and problems (looking at you, pathfinding), but that aside it's a really nice experience, which is even better if played with friends. Wish they sold friends on the steam market, though. Not for me, I have friends, but for those that don't... Well, I hope you make some soon.

This rendition of AOE 3 has brought in some new civilizations but unfortunately these civilizations dont have a campaign. Instead there are 1 shot 'historic battles' which are not as interesting as the original story mode campaigns.

The biggest fault I find in the game is despite the devs claiming major improvements to the game, AOE III never gave me stutters or crashes (on a high end gaming pc) and the pathing algorithm for troop movement is abysmal with your troops in a group 
1. Splitting up to take a different path which is clearly a dead end and then getting stuck and later backtracking or staying there till you manually backtrack them
2. Doing random shifting around during combat as it suddenly tries to get in formation. Why would you mess with the original combat logic? (The classic in formation during movement and break formation and rush the enemy as soon as combat begins)
3.While moving your troops/fleet, sometimes some ships move ahead of others and when you target someone, suddenly they shuffle to get in formation. Wtf?

The pathing is so horrible that I've had several moments when I'm exclaiming 'Wtf are you doing??!!' that make me want to break the game if it were a CD (you really dont want troops just running around in the middle of a fight getting hit but not shooting back). It is something you would encounter rarely or not at all in the original game, so unless you want to get the new civilizations or its on sale, I would recommend going for the original AOE 3 by Microsoft.

Updated review, since I bought the game again some months later after refunding it and I'm not feeling as upset as on release.

This game is a remaster, so I expected some nicer visuals and sounds, along with much needed QoL improvements. I bought the premise that it "took a lot of work" from the dev team, and was hoping for an all-around better version of the original AoE 3.
While we did get updated graphs + sounds, and [i]some[/i] QoL improvements, the product itself is not amazing.

First, the positives:
[list]
[*]This is, mostly, your standard Age of Empires III experience. If you liked the originals, you will most likely like this one as well.
[*]The multiplayer has recieved a much needed revamp, and I didn't experience any problems with it aside from very long loading times.
[*]There is new content being added, even if it's paid DLC. I didn't buy any of them, but new content is always good news.
[*]The unit group selection limit was increased from 50 units to 95. No clue why not 100, but it's a good improvement.
[*]Some historical innaccuracies and potentialy offensive portrayals were corrected, mainly concerning the nations from the Warchiefs expansion. Some may argue that this is pointless, but I guess making less people upset is a nice move.
[*]All of the shipments are now unlocked and are readily avaliable to be used, removing the need to either modify save files or grind for them.
[*]Achievements for this game now exist. It's a nice feature, I guess?
[*]Finally, this product is cheaper than the original game. This is weird to say the least, but it [i]is[/i] a better deal nowadays.
[/list]

Now, the negatives.
[list]
[*]While the graphic update is nice, it absolutely does not justify the ridiculously increased specs this game demands, especially the storage required.
[*]Second, if I'm paying for a remaster, I should not recieve a product that is inferior to the original in [i]any[/i] way. This game manages to have objectively worse AI for units regarding the attack move order and general pathfinding. This leads to some weird moments, such as when villagers will finish cutting a tree and will forget that they had a task, and proceed to just stand there doing nothing, even if they should be perfectly capable of continue doing their jobs, as they did in the originals.
[*]Third, this game lags A LOT when there are lots of units on the screen, like 50+ units.
While the originals did lag a bit in this situation, the framerate here goes from ~60 to astonishing [i]five[/i]. It's quite the awful experience to train a massive army to just to see a slideshow of a battle.
[/list]

Conclusion:
I made this negative review as a way to express how frustrated I am, both as a fan and as a customer, because the new flaws of the game were never acknowledged or patched. It feels like the devs don't care, and it hurts.
The game itself, however, is mostly fine. Is it the definitive experience it promises? No. But if you just want the experience of playing it, and aren't as nitpicky as I am, go for it.

Just coming off of finishing the campaign and I gotta say... 

Love this game, I really do. With 100+ hours on the OG version on Steam (not counting the probably 500+ I have on the original disced versions) It's a different take on AOE that while perhaps not everyone's cup of tea, is refreshing. And unlike AOE4 actually offers something *different*.

Innovation and Iteration done right. *however*...

While the gameplay is on point and I enjoy the mechanics of the game and whatever have you, there are a few game breaking issues. I've had a couple crashes while playing, more than I've ever had on the OG versions. More than I've had on any version of AOE2... pathing could be a bit better but it's nowhere near as bad as AOE1... but it definantly feels a lot less micro intensive, which for some might be a good thing... as it's much harder to dodge shots (if not impossible) and you can't micro out of the way of archer fire like you can in AOE2.

So that's the gameplay, which all in all is solid... but now comes... *sigh*... the campaign...

My god, the Campaign... what did they do to you? Let me preface this by saying I am aboriginal, so I think I can speak here...
- Changing how the Iroquois to haudenosaunee: Didn't really bother me, a little jarring when certain words are outright omitted from cut-scenes and it interrupts the flow of dialog but whatever, it's not that big a deal and they are technically correct.
- Changing how aboriginal civs play (Except the Aztecs and Inca?): Sure, fine, I can see what was attempted with the Asian Civs and some of the newer ones. I've no issue with altering how some civs play to get in that sweet sweet asymmetrical gameplay, but don't BS me that it's for anything else.

The biggest issue with a lot of the politically correct changes however, most heavily affect the story, and yeah, I know, it's an RTS, you generally don't play RTS games for their stories. But c'mon, I at LEAST would appreciate a cohesive narrative, given that the campaign is more character driven than any other AOE campaign has been... such changes are... (Minor Spoilers ahead)
- Why did they just straight up remove Nonakee's name from the game? Like... John Black never says it... despite their romance being a key part of his character... idk, It just feels weird that it's barely brought up.
- The Entirety of the Shadow Act, from The Warchiefs, it was completely rewritten... poorly, I might add. Mind you the original wasn't amazing, but it changed the Sioux that you originally fought into generic "bandits"... I don't understand why this change was made given that the focus of the campaign in the original was about Red Cloud's War, which was a real event and instead glosses it over and seems to generally handwave a lot of things that fly in the face of their given reasons for making all the changes to the first nations civs to begin with. Idk... when I heard the line "Sioux is what our enemies call us" from Chayton during the 2nd (or 3rd?) Level I actually laughed aloud... now whenever someone asks me what types of First Nation I am, I respond with that (And Cree)... 

Otherwise the campaign was great up until that point... nothing has really changed in the Asian campaigns either though, given that they're more focused on historical events like AOE2 and 1's campaigns. It's just that last act which is poorly written.

So with all that said, great game, the mechanical and name changes they've made aren't as irritating as most claim (personally) and if you love a good RTS, you should be able to ignore them... and if you're new, you won't even notice them. It's just the old guard who will, but I don't see that as enough of a reason to skip this one... maybe just that last act of The Warchief's campaign... but hey, maybe you'll find something in it that I didn't.

the pros: the game looks really good, the remaster plays very smooth. i hadn't any bugs, glitches or crashes. thumbs up for that. the campaigns story is a bit mediocre but also plays very good at some points. it changes from building an base and attack to exploring caves etc. it is not always the same layout. the audio is also a big plus, its not the same english voice actors you hear in some games but the characters talk in their native language. i really like that.

the cons: the ai is utterly retarded in this game, not only your own but also the enemies one. if you have some "more" units in your squad, the units begin to brainfreeze and cant leave the squad because they get stuck in between each other, sometimes they simply wont move out of the way and die because of that. painful to watch it, especially when you have to move seperate units away so they get through. units just stand around and get hit until you get everyone to shoot at the same target, thats just sad because the second game got it better. the campaign is seperated into 2 difficulties: super family friendly easy mode and almost impossible hardcore massacre mode. some missions play on medium difficulty like they were designed for 6 year olds, in some missions you are getting obliterated like you are playing call of duty world at war on veteran mode. i really dont understand why choosing an concept like this was an good idea by the devs. i had to restart some missions like 5 times because i got owned like france got  owned in 1940 by germany

conclusion: game looks very good but plays mediocre for me because of all the said cons

"Definitive Edition", right.
So let me recap a few things that I noticed here and here :
- the unit cap for a selection is still 50 units, like in the base game. That never got fixed. Consider that some endgame cards spawn 24 units at once, you're forced to have several groups if you have any decent army,
- the maps are still small, and your options during map generation are hilariously limited. What you see on the thumbnail when picking a map isn't a sample, it's the map you'll actually get, so exploration is less interesting. That, too, was in the base AoE3 and never got fixed,
- the different factions are extremely unbalanced. Whether or not it's a big issue depends from your point of view,
- despite not owning any DLC, I still get to play against Ethiopean. Their voices lines are butchered and horribly loud, while old units are a lot less loud,
- the home city are just plain unfair : the factions that were in vanilla AoE3 get a degree of cosmetic customization, while Aztecs and Incans don't get any customization, and the American-Indians only get 4 people standing awkwardly around a campfire and avoiding eye contact,
- the maps are still too damn small,
- the fog of war needs some desaturation to make it more obvious if it's present or not,
- and finally, upon starting the game for the first time, you get a pop window basically saying that the developpers are super-not racist at all and did their best to accurately represent the different people portrayed in the game. Which, again, is a matter of opinion, but I see it as virtue-signalling, since, as I said earlier, Amerindians factions have underwhelming assets, and the Ethiopean explorer is loud when he croaks under my gatlings.

Overall, a very underwhelming "Definitive Edition", with very little skill showed on AoE2DE. The games does little to fix its vanilla counterpart's issues. Its only redeeming grace is that it finally has the game in a single package, compared to AoE3 Steam that forced you to pick between the different expansions.


EDIT : and since the last patch, I can't even play it anymore. Good job.
EDIT AGAIN : I can play again, and the mesoamerican factions got some city personalization. AND, the devs have added a "big map" option which makes the game really enjoyable, so I changed my recommendation to positive.
EDIT AGAIN, AGAIN : Holy cow, they also upped the unit selection cap. It's definitely a positive review now.

I'm a single player gamer. I thoroughly enjoyed the first campaign even moreso than when I finished it back in 2005. Solid story, good pacing, well thought-out missions and long enough to make it feel like you got your money's worth.  And the game has enough unique features to make it feel different to the other Age of Empires games. Highly recommended for single player strategy fans!

I'm off to play the other campaigns.

Edit: Finished the Fire and Shadow campaigns. A plug in to the original story. Similar in terms of dynamics. More of the same but not in a bad way.

Edit: Finished the Asian Dynasties campaigns: A breath of fresh air with completely new civilisations. Recommended.

Edit: Busy with the historical battles. I love them. Every civilisation is unique and well crafted (although I can't comment on multiplayer balance because I don't play multiplayer). I just wish there were more historical battles.

Final Edit: Done with the historical battles. Some good variance and its nice to be able to try out different civilisations. It felt like there is space for more scenarios. I would love a DLC which adds 15-20 odd historical battles for the standard civilisations and then an additional handful of historical battles for each of the DLC civilisations. There are so many real life historical battles to recreate. 

Overall, AOE3 is a LOT better than I remember it being. I've been playing RTS games since Dune 2 and I there hasn't been one that I've enjoyed as much as Aoe3 in recent memory.

Last side note: After finishing all the campaigns and the historical battles on hard, I only mustered up 10 achievements in total.

It lags in single-player. Let me repeat that; This 16 year old game with a fresh coat of paint lags my 5 year old computer on medium graphics. There is 0 excuse for there to be such a performance issue that the game is stuttering.

Edit: After playing this more, I've come to an unsettling realization: every positive review of this game is a bot or a payed promotion. because the game is WORSE than I thought. The performance problems are related to a memory issue so old I haven't seen it since custom Warcraft 3 maps. And this "definitive edition" somehow BROKE the AI. Good ole' Ivan the Terrible is going outside to a corner store or something, because his full stack army is just sitting in his base, not doing anything. Yet despite not participating anymore, AI Ivan has the highest score in the game by a wide margin, which I wouldn't care about if it didn't mean he was going to steal 500 xp from me in the post-game.

Edit 2: Lets add FURTHER to the condemnation of this POS, there's an event ongoing at the time of this review. One of the TEDIOUS objectives is to revolt 3 times. This wouldn't be bad if not for two things. The first is that if you exit the game before completing the challenge, you lose your progress, so you NEED to play 3 games in a row. This leads into problem two, the memory issue I mentioned kicks in after one to two games, meaning to get this achievement, you have to ENDURE an awful stuttery game. This is beyond trash.

This game is worse than the far superior Age of Kings (aka Age of Empires II - a better option that is also available as a Definitive Edition) in so many ways, it's hard to know where to start. A few quick hits, which gives you an idea of what you will find in AoEIII, but which also serves as a counterpoint/comparison to AoK:
-the campaigns in AoEIII aren't that good: the overall stories and the writing are cringe-worthy, and it feels like someone's elementary school writing project -- not only are the stories not good, but they feel out of place for the period that the game tries to set itself in, but fails for being way too all over the place. Also, for a game called 'Age of Empires', it's rather boring to follow the members of a Metis family while they try to establish a railroad (even fighting against the US while doing so) or prospecting gold. I mean, what? There is no sense of historical scale to what you are doing. The 'retelling' or the US War of Independence is so fantasical that it takes away from any stakes. Worse thing is that the suckiness of the story isn't remedied by good scenarios with good gameplay, even on moderate most missions (that I bothered actually playing) felt like a cakewalk, and could be done with the starting troops+a few card deliveries from the home city (playing at moderate difficulty, the middle of the three difficulty options).
-The gameplay more broadly just isn't that fun, my opinion is that it's just full of gimmicks that don't gel too well together, and a few differences and distinctions that fail to coalesce into anything resembling actual strategic depth. For some reason I can't quite put my finger on, even though the developers have gone out of their way to make every civilization be a bit different, they end up feeling all too similar.

My strong recommendation is to pass on this game. Age of Kings is a much better game. As it is written, I have spent 24 hours on this as of writing this. Comparatively, I have about 240 hours on Age of Kings, most of which I've played over the last couple months. Regardless, AoE3 keeps making me want to play Age of Kings more. (Also, in those 24 hours, I've earned nearly 80% of current achieves, and I could already be at 100% if I had the African Kingdoms DLC. After my 240 hours, I am 100% on Age of Kings, and while they weren't all very difficult they do feel earned and I had fun every step of the way. I can't say the same with AoE3.)

Note:  This game is not worth it unless you purchase it about $15 or less.  This is coming from a fan of the Age of Empires series who owns all of the games.  I will note the positives and negatives below.

Positives:
1.  Good Graphics (it is a 4k graphics game, so this is a no duh thing."
2.  The campaign and battle maps look nice, so some effort was given to make things look rather interesting vs boring.
3.  You can win with a variety of unit types and options within each civilization.  
4.  No 1 civilization completely dominates battles
5.  The game makers have finally given the option to allow you to select which in-match cards you can deploy from the beginning.  Aka, the grinding has been removed.  
6.  The game makers are starting to allow people to modify non-original civilization's home cities (it took them long enough)
7.  They are finally adding more civilizations into the game, and are giving people a limited time to earn them with achievable tasks.  (Thank you game makers!)
8. They are allowing customers to start buying individual civilizations without having to buy ones that the gamer does not want to play as.  (Thank you game makers!)
9.  There are finally larger map sizes.

Negatives:
1.  The campaigns and many of the "historical" battles are rather boring so far as the story plot is concerned.  (The Asian campaigns were the closest to having the thrill of the Age of Empires 1-2 fun, but it was still lacking in detail.  Check out the Chinese campaign and use the cheat to see the whole map if you want to see what I am talking about)
2.  The game makers forgot that they were making an Age of Empires game when they did the "historical" battles and the campaigns.  Apparently they thought that they were making a World of Warcraft mod given the fact that you did not start with the ability to create a base or start with a base at the start of the game.  
3.  The 200 unit cap is ridiculously low given the fact that the Age of Empires 1-2 Definitive Editions have a 500 unit cap, and to this day, the game makers still have not added the ability to have 500 units.
4.  Defensive structure caps.  Age of Empires 1-2 did not have a limit on how many defensive towers or castles that it had.  This game should not either.  This is a major downgrade in tactical options.
5.  Name changes to Civilizations, units, and structures.  I understand the desire to not accidentally offend anyone, but seriously.  Let the player determine if they want that name change or if they can keep it how it was before.  The Iriquois Confederacy is a whole lot easier to say and remember than whatever the hell the game makers replaced it with.  If people want you to censor the game to make it more politically correct, have it be a paid mod, not something that is shoved down everyone's throats from the get go.  It annoys long time players who frequently are the ones who are encouraging their friends to buy your game.
6.  There is a limit of 4 teams in team play.  Age of Empires 1-2 can have up to 8
7.  Challenge completion data is not shared between computers.  Example.  I was 52% complete with the United States Challenge on 1 computer.  Due to the Xbox Live not syncing the completion data, it stubbornly showed that I was only 42% complete on a different computer.
8. Black washing characters and icons in European/American or Latin civilizations.

Note to the game makers.  People who buy a game with the ability to create a base, want to be able to create a base or expand an already existing base on EVERY SINGLE MAP AND MISSION!  If we wanted to play World of Warcraft or a game similar to it, we would be playing that game and not buying or playing yours!!!!  So STOP adding maps or missions that do not have the ability to make or use a base!!!!

Note 2 for game makers.  Stop trying to race change units and icons.  I know you are doing this for PC reasons or "diversity inclusiveness."  The CORRECT way to do this is to add new factions with the minority groups you believe should be there.  The INCORRECT way to is to blackwash non-black factions in order to force inclusivity.  If you continue this, I will not purchase any more of your expansion packs for this game, or any other games or expansion packs for the other game series that you are working on.  I will not support the corruption of history by YOUR racist bigotry against European, Latin, and Asian populations.  I will also apply this stance towards other games made by your parent corporation.  Remember, computer games and video games are NOT necessary for one to enjoy life, and you are NOT the only game makers out there.  When you start shoving your politics into your games, you will permanently lose customers.  

This game does have its fair share of flaws.  It is well worth buying it on sale if you can ignore the anti-European, Latin, and Asian undertones of some of the newer subtle updates they are adding to the game.

The game itself is great, it plays almost identically to CC. I loved CC and got this the moment I got my new computer that could actually run it (and run it really well, I've played plenty of more demanding games with no problems). The gameplay itself is actually really good, using good unit comp to obliterate your enemy never gets old and being able to outboom is always fun. However, with DE I've had so many frustrations that I didn't nearly have with CC. 

The problem is that it arguably has more issues, both performance and in balancing. I have had significantly more disconnects, out of syncs and random resigns here than in CC. I have had posts about it on the official forums, people say they are looking into it and nothing. I reported back in June that you can't use shift commands properly on hunts when you're using more than 8 vills and it still hasn't been fixed. And now that the Mexico civ is here there is plenty of broken bullshit to go around. Who thought that a 7.5 min fast industrial is balanced? Like really, when most civs can only do a 6-6.5 min fast fortress? The new civs are so overloaded with mechanics and features, meanwhile old civs like Russia and the Aztecs are still boring to play, with the Inca doing everything the Aztecs do but better. Meaning, apart from meme strats (like invis coyote runners) there's no reason to play Aztecs when Incas are flat out better. Not only that, but they got rid of key things from CC, such as a working ranked system to let you know who was and wasn't good (Stars + chevrons don't count) as well as a lag indicator in the pre game lobby.

Further to that, the playerbase is just really low and the community mentally impaired. Going in at seemingly any point the lobbies will mostly be filled the following:
-People who don't name their lobbies with any name (sticking to their username + game) then just randomly kick you
-High level players team stacking against low level players then kicking when you complain
-AFK lobby hosts. 
-People who pick really weird lobby settings but don't say it in the title so you load in and you have to instaquit. 
-Teammates who never communicate and refuse to listen to any helpful advice. Had a ranked team game where my Japan ally didn't shrine boom, didn't FF, didn't rush and sent cav against the enemy's musk rush.
That and it's hard to just get a good high level game going, there simply aren't enough people playing to get a high enough playerbase where you can actually get tested, it's all 90% noobs who can't use shift commands or don't even know a simple build order.

I won't really bother going into the woke shit that they introduced with this release, since it doesn't really impact gameplay. I just find it interesting that they made censors that barely even work, censored the work colonialsm from the game and tried to be more accurate for the American civs, meanwhile the game still has key issues that haven't resolved and several civs in the game are hilariously historically inaccurate.

tldr, the game itself is actually really fun, since they just copied the fundamentals from CC, but they've introduced so many issues and bugs with this DE release that it's just painful to play

Age of Empires 3 may never reach the fame of its predecessor, but it is undeniable that it is an excellent strategy game with many unique mechanics that will make each game different.

Possibly the greatest attraction is how each civilization has something that makes them unique, the card system that thank god this Definitive Edition eliminates the need to grind to unlock them and how fun is the combat.

From the point of view of someone who plays casually, this is the most fun "Age of" to play against the CPU and with friends, and the main campaign, even if it isn't as enjoyable as the one on Age of Mythologies, is super fun to complete.

Specifically speaking of this definitive version, the new civilizations and general changes are very welcome to refresh the experience of the game. Possibly the most controversial are the changes to certain names that can be felt as historical revisionism, which makes feel that there is a certain inconsistency since everything that is not related to the United States has a lot of errors and inaccuracies.

Leaving that aside, if you want to enjoy a game casually, this is the Age of Empires that I recommend the most. If you prefer something more competitive-focused, maybe you better play Age of Empires II: DE or IV.

As someone who never stopped playing the 2007 version since it came out, I must say this is a gem dear to my heart. It's clear we have a passionate and dedicated team behind it who keeps pushing new contents and updates and keeping the game alive. It doesn't just feel and play 90% like the original, it does it better. It looks a lot better, for sure, and has more factions in the core game (Incas and Swedes). Its Ages of Empires!!!

My all time favorite RTS, back in 4k.

The differences are almost entirely for the better, so if you don't have AoE3 yet (or play it a lot), I strongly recommend the upgrade to DE.

My favorite part is that I don't have to grind to unlock cards anymore: leveling up your home city is purely about cosmetics. Only thing on my wishlist: I wish I could import my levels from my old save that I've been working on since 2005 (including in the 2007 edition), so that I could unlock the cosmetics I used to have unlocked, lol.

Is this remake flawed? God yea, but it generally recaptures what I loved so much about age of empires 3. 

Addressing some things people dislike:

[b] The Name Changes [/b]
Honestly, I personally do not care about the name changes as much as others. Does it seem pointless? Yea lol. Does it actually change the game that my colonial militia are now called revolutionary militia? No lol. 

Now sure I suppose it can be fair to be a bit annoyed at these name changes, but I personally think some of these reactions to them to be a bit over-exaggerated? It's hardly like these changes were a secret either, so if you hate them so much, why buy the product to begin with lol.


[b] Minor change [/b]
Some people are fairly upset over some minor changes such as all cards being unlocked at once & the new ranking system. I think both of these complaints are a bit daft considering the aoe3 community, that still played the game, like me, actually had been asking for this for ages. Having to unlock cards created a very inequal playing field amongst players in multiplayer, making it unbalanced as hell. As for the ranking system, this one takes more into account what you actually do during games, and doesnt arbitrarily throw you down 30 ranks because you lost 5 games in a row because half of your team DCed due to the peer to peer connection.

As it stands, both of these changes are pretty good as it allows aoe3 to have a better competitive element than the old one.

[b] The lag [/b]
Okay this is a negative I can get behind. Although I have yet to experience crashing, occassionally (typically once per game for me) you will have a period where your frames just tank. This really can hurt games like this where you really do have to be aware of your surroundings and manage alot at once. This game does need a lot more optimising, with this being said, the game is still very much playable. I'm running a middle-end PC made 7 years ago and I generally can play this fine.
----
[b]  THE GOOD! [/b]
[b]  Graphics [/b]
Honestly, I like them. Some people say they look cartoony and "like a mobile game" (because non-hyper realistic is apparently automatically a mobile game) but honestly the keey the old style alive and make the game just feel a lot more lively. Age of Empires 3's visuals were never really the selling-point, but this graphical overhaul just seems to be appealing and true to the original.

[b] Politicians  [/b]
When you age up in age of empires 3, you must select a politician that'll grant you certain things (be it units, resources, buffs and more). Originally there were only 3, and usually you'd only ever go with the quatermaster/400 wood politician, but now with the politician rework, there are a lot more viable options. This adds A LOT more strategy to the game, whilst still keeping true to old game mechanics.

[b] The new additions [/b]
There are new additions to the game that are just generally kind of cool, like the Swedes & Incans. Two entirely new civilisations to play with! Both do need some minor balancing updates, but other than that, they're pretty neato to have.

Oh yea, the historical battles have a lot of potentially considering age of empires 3 covers a rather large time period, so holy crap, imagine what we could potentially have! Be it napoleonic war, history battles, the plains of Abraham battle, and more! 

---
[b]  TLDR [/b]

Graphics cool

New stuff cool

Balancing needed

A lot of optimising needed

I really recommend this game to anyone with an itch for a quality historical game with deep mechanics and fast strategic gameplay. The factions are incredibly diverse and I really think something can be found for any taste.


First things first - this game is now completely fixed and has been for some time now. There are no game breaking bugs anymore (or for me no noticeable bugs, which in a strategy game with hundreds of diverse units is remarkable) and devs are regularly shipping out updates to new and existing factions, balance updates, completely new mechanics (yesterday Skull Knight - elite Aztec unit - got spin to win ability) and making this game better than ever before. It's also beautiful with grand orchestral music and has a growing community of single- and multiplayer-minded people. I really recommend trying if you like strategy games.


WARNING - This game is DEEP and if you want to play multiplayer you will have to learn most factions mechanics' and decks of cards they can use, because ATM there are 17 completely unique factions with different playstyles and decks of cards, which represent different historical units (like Longbowmen for Brits), buildings (Dojo for Japs) and technologies (Solingel Steel for Germany) or cultural aspects (Spanish Gold for, you guessed it, Spain): 

- Original 8 (European) factions have similar units (with every single one having quite a few unique units and upgrades that completely change the existing ones) but insanely different mechanics (compared to AOE2), which show already in how the factions play (Dutch want to build banks so they can buy their villagers with coin and go for the late game, while Ottomans produce villagers for free, but have to focus their resources into their unique church, which buffs villagers and their production and so you can focus on early game, then again Spanish seem "vanilla", but then you realize how they use fast shipments of cards to boost any unit they have and go for a different strategy every game, of which some can make this faction quite hard to play and fun as farts).
Then they all have about 15 different revolution civilizations, which again completely change how the original faction plays. Then they all have their unique decks (some of the cards shared) which offer like 5-20 playstyles for each civilization and allow you to customize your civilization as you want (you can go for strong cavalry raids with Germans, or just go for heavy infantry and horse wagons to go crushing). Then you spice that up with powerful but costly mercenary units which you can hire from all over the world (Ports love going for Egyptian Mamelukes, so they don't have to invest in their own cav because of their already expensive and quality roster, while Russians can go for Ninjas in the late game to sneak in and destroy enemy artilery, Ports or Brits just hire theaters from where they can hire Ronin for cheap). Then you can mix all that with about 20 different minor tribes which you can befriend on every wonderful map (Brits love Cherokee, which they can hire for cheap in the second age to cover their lack of skirmishers). Yeah. This is the basic stuff.

- Then there are 2 original expansions which add 3 civilizations each. Warchiefs adds 3 Mesoamerican civilizations with completely unique roster and playstyle each. Aztecs like to use their priests for rituals that spawn warriors or boost different aspects of their civilization, then build a powerful roster of pure infantry like Eagle runner knights or fast coyote runners for every different occasion. They excel in the late game, when their infantry is upgraded, but even in early game a well placed skull knight can kill a whole unit of enemies.
Haudenosaunee (Iroquis) are the most difficult civilization to play IMO and sport a diverse roster of cavalry, warriors, siege equipment and powerful stealthy gunpowder infantry and cannons, which all mix in weird defensive playstyle with aggressive pushes when you go and hire a few allies.
Lakota just forego defense all together and can't even build defenses (exept with a dew cards from their deck (or allies' help), but they use a crazy powerful roster of some of the most powerful cavalry like musket riders, bow riders, axe riders and Tokala soldiers (the best shock cavalry in game) for raiding and really micro-intensive playstyle.
All these factions also employ animals and beasts to gain early economic advantage, or just make jaguars instead of cavalry and go to town (literally). Their warchiefs are also able to convert human treasure guardians for early raiding and even more treasures.

- The Asian Dynasties was the second original DLC, which added 3 Asian factions, which are even more diverse, but may be a little less difficult to play. They all have incredibly unique rosters, but focus on more defensive gameplay with wonders they can build to get awesome boosts throughout the game. They all start with the best explorers (monks) and just get through early game through many different abilities they eploy. Japanese focus on exploration in the early game, then transition into powerful military. They usually focus on one of samurai, ashigaru musketeer, or yumi bowmen for core of their forces, then mix in fast cavalry, long range arrow cannons, elite daimyo or their own powerful mercenaries like ninjas, ronin, monks or mongolian cavalry archers. Indians focus on powerful fortresses, then go for camels for raiding, powerful infantry for skirmishing, or just go all in on like 7 different elephant units and just build from there. Chinese are the most unique in that they don't build single units, but overwhelm the enemy with armies of less powerful, but also quite cheap units, which they combine with their incredible rocket artillery, flamethrowers, monks or a roster of armored or fast raiding cavalry. Then all three factions employ their European allies in consulate to trade their unique resource - export - for economical, technological or military gains.

- The Definitive Edition factions are Inca and Sweden, which build on the original European and Mesoamerican factions. Inca build heavy fortresses and use REALLY fast and numerous infantry and tactics like poisonous arrows to clash with the enemy. Their most unique ability is a kancha house, which is a building that produces food, so they can be more turtle-y and then just explode out when they build their army up - or raid you with stealthy runners. They also can have stealthy jungle castles. Their power is economics and they are one of the best late game civilizations. Then Sweden is a weird and micro intensive European power, which uses tiny hobit grass houses to absorb resources around, which gives them incredible mid-game where they can spawn resources like blueberries, mines, trees, elk... to fuel their strategies like elite carolean infantry, raiding heavy hand cavalry, pretty beefed-up cannons or one of the best mercenary strategies around.

- The new USA faction is the most complicated of all and is unique in that their basic roster of units is pretty glass-cannon, not even that strong, but then they use immigrants to populate their town and borrow bonuses from other European factions (like Dutch bank, powerful German settler wagons, free Chinese trading posts...) and hire units from all over the world like Magyar Hussars, Brit grenadiers, French Dragoons, German Uhlans OR focus on boosting their own units into the sky with powerful upgrades. They also use completely unique age up mechanics, which see them invite a federal state into the UNITED states, who then again also bring unique cards and improvements with them, some of which other factions can get in their decks, but USA is a sweet mix of all of that. They can also go for all out cowboy strategy, which I find quite fun. Ohh, and they can buy Alaska, which comes with silver and polar bears and all. LOVE IT<3

I would like to take a moment to talk how great this game was and still is. When I was a child, my father and me used to play Age of Empires II and III together, in the CD form, now that technology is moving forward, and the fact we lost this game, we played it once again.
The game is a really realistic, not going to lie, simulation of perhaps the XVIII century, instead of your classical wololo and fighting a building using an iron sword, this game uses gunpowder for such duties, the most impressive thing for me is the cannon, the ragdolls and the destruction they do to a building, and speaking of which, this game uses something else, envoys, by leveling up you get to unlock more cards, (in their respective buildings, like the cathedral) which you will use to get more upgrades, buildings, and units for the cost of time (and gold if they are mercenaries). Now that the IV one is out, I'm a bit worried this game is going to be forgotten, but then again we are talking about Age of Empires.

[h1]      Safe recommendation for fans of the original Age of Empires III, but not without few caveats.[/h1]
[b]Newest and last entry in remastered trilogy of cult-classic real-time strategy games does not dissapoint and offers overall good experiece, but considering hopes and expectations left after treatment of Age of Empires II: Definitive Edition - leaves certain amount of unfulfillment. [/b]

   Considering the age of all the games in the 'Age of Empires' series, the climate and specificity of today's market, the fact of the existence of this refreshed version of the game is still a surprise (not as big as in the case of AoE I) and deserves praise - one for developers and the community, the second - for the publisher who gave the project the green light and continues to support the game after its premiere.
Unfortunately, as in the case of the two previous Definitive Editions, it was not without a handful of problems on the premiere, fortunately, as in the case of other titles, the development team remains in contact with the community from the first day and regularly releases updates, eliminating errors and adding finishing touches this game needs.

   I think it is important to realize the outset what type of release 'AoE III: DE' is - when it comes to modifying the engine core, range of changes and improvements to the game, by comparison it is roughly in the middle of the quality of the AoE II HD and DE release. Despite great, updated visuals deep down this is still roughly the same code as in 2005 version, and unfortunately you have to adjust your hopes accordingly when it comes to expectations to what was done here.
At the moment, after a few patches, the biggest problem is and will probably remain in some form,the performance in the context of the multiplayer mode, but also the solo skirmish mode while played with more players, and thus - units. Nevertheless - I am convinced that there is still room for action and in the upcoming updates devs will try to smooth the edges where possible. This applies to both optimization and netcode quality but also AI, which from time to time leaves something to be desired.

   With all the campaigns, a new historical mission mode and 'The Art of War' challenges completed, a lot of hours in skirmish mode and some multiplayer games - I can safely say that AoE III: DE is a solid remaster and during the my playtime I have not met any no major bugs, and even the mentioned optimization was not a problem 95% of the time.
Many concerned reviewers point to changes made to the content itself - generally 'DE' is same as the Complete Edition of the original release, however, the developers allowed themselves to make changes to some elements, which is always quite controversial. In my opinion, apart from a few questionable changes made to terminology, there is no reason to be too upset - most of the changes, even if not necessarily needed from the player's perspective, seem justified after exploring the motivation behind the developers. I certainly don't sense any bad intentions here. Anyway, these are all cosmetic elements (name of certain Indian nation, model of a building, flag pattern or era name etc.), not affecting the gameplay itself.

   All the rest of the potential stipulations are wishful issues, most of them rather unrealistic due to technical or budgetary constraints: map browsing system like in 'AoE II: DE', home city customization for factions that do not have it + more options where it was present, advanced inteface scaling options. And of course, completely new story content just like one for the Definitive Edition of the second game. However, looking at it realistically - both the size of the multiplayer community and sales that are unlikely to be close to AoE II:DE'- the chances for it are slim. Well, one can always dream.

   This is probably the last version of the game to ever be released. And although it is not a complete dream come true, it still offers a lot of fun, a lot of content and very nice visuals.
Worth recommending and fully worth its price regardless of previous experience with the game and considering all circumstances 'AoE III: DE' is a reason for celebration for fans of the series and the whole genre - especially in the current times, not easy for classic RTS games. 
I hope that the game will remain supported at least until the release of AoE IV - it's hard to imagine a fairer and more useful marketing tool than ongoing support for previous titles in the series. 

----------
[i]By the way, if possible, I highly recommend checking out the original Complete Edition from 2007. For people with weak/older machines, it will probably run as good if not better, but most of all it is worth getting acquainted with some mods that came out for it. A good place to start your search is Moddb or the 'Age of Empires Heaven' website. While the big mods are less numerous than ones for games like LotR: BfME2 or 'C&C: Generals', there are still enough to choose from.[/i]

I have been playing AoE since the very first way back in the day.  I've loved everyone of them, but my personal preference and favortie has been III.  I love the colonial age and while some people may be sensitive to the time period due its savagery(and unfortunately some terms have been changed from the original becouase of said sensitives), I have always felt that this series provided history in all its glory and horror.  I truly believe that to learn from history you have know the good and the bad or we are apt to make the same misakes!  

This game has a unique home city system that sets it apart from 1,2, and now 4.  and the card system while maybe overwhelming a first, offers a wide variety of combinations of how you play every country.  It offers a fun way to replay the game and adds fun times playing with friends trying to out do one another.  multiplayer is great after few patches which addressed load times and connection issues and has some fun modes of play to spice things up!  Of course the single player is classic and well done.

Lastly what most people who say they like others to this is cannons and how op they were was the reason they went back to 2 all the time.  While they are very strong there are ways to counter like in any game its up the player to figure it out or again youtube it!!   

No matter how to you play the game, I hope whoever reads this enjoys the content and its worth as much as i have!

Age of empires 3 changes a lot about the franchise. Things like ways to renew resources, which changed end game fights to be more strategic in terms of army tactics than map control. There is a new card (perk) system which is thankfully unlocked at the start in the DE, which is meant to give variation to each civilisation, although some cards are objectively better than others. The game is set a little bit more modern than I would have liked, being all civies end with firearms and cannons. One thing I'm not fond of, is many armies share the same unit types, sometimes they don't even reskin them. The game supports up to 7 AI (2-4 teams) in a skirmish, and runs smoothly even with massive armies on screen. The DE includes all DLC civies from the original game, and also has additional civies to purchase. All in all, its pretty decent, worth a go.

At review time I have played almost 13 hours. I have had around 16 crashes-to-desktop from all over the game:

Main menu. Multiplayer lobby search. Mid-match multiplayer. Mid-match singleplayer. I have not tried the campaign but other players have reported that crashes often as well. So I'm not going to bother.

I find this mostly unacceptable. The game has been out for almost three weeks and none of the updates they claim have "fixed" the crashing issues have actually fixed them. I still crash just as often and in the same places. Elder Scrolls 4 Oblivion crashes less than this game does. How am I expected to have fun with the game if I can't play it?

This is aside from a ton of other bugs and issues I've come across that still have not been addressed. Units getting stuck in buildings. Armies ignoring attack orders. Missing UI elements on certain units. Memory leaks. Silly AI.

This game is also a GPU hog. I've never played a game that makes my GPU work as hard as this one does.

I love Age of Empires, and I love AOE III, but in it's current state this Definitive Edition is unstable and borderline unplayable. It has left me frustrated and disappointed many, many times already since release.

Edit: I wanted to give the game another shot after leaving it alone for a while, hoping that some of these problems would be addressed. I tried multiple single-player skirmish games, with each one crashing after 10 or so minutes with "ran out of memory" errors.

No other game has given me low memory errors. I have a Windows 10 PC with 16GB DDR4 RAM, and no other program or window running besides Steam, this game, and Discord. My setup is well above the recommended specs listed on the store page.

I guess I'll check back in in another year or so, but I'm not holding my breath.

Unfortunately, AoE3 (DE) is often dragged through the mud by the very loud and entrenched AoE II community. 
The game breaks with the known traditions and goes new ways, brings new approaches and a lot of refreshing variety, which may not always please die-hard AoE II fans.

But these loudmouths do this game and this worthy definitive edition an injustice.
You can feel that this game was developed with a lot of love and heart and soul.
Interesting character focused campaigns, hometown & deck mechanics, lots of maps, a great scenario editor, good graphics that look far better than AoE IV, and lots of very different civs that offer great variety make this game and this DE for me personally and for many others the best Age so far and brings back fond childhood memories.

Hopefully it will be supplied with content for a long time to come!

Original Review Below:
First off, I love this game. I thought the original was great and the updates to gameplay, graphics, and story are excellent. They made good work with graphics and kept the reality part of the game. In fact, they made an effort to change the stereotypes and improve on historical accuracy. Now, that may seem positive, especially for those like me that enjoy a plausible representation. However, they changed some of the mechanics that I loved (and surely many others love as well). Examples: The Sioux/Lakota don't mine stone (which makes sense) but also the explorer doesn't tame wild animals, which also makes sense but takes out the fun to play with a distinct troop. They took the rituals/dancing building which was a different and fun mechanic, which for me was disappointing. The voice should be better, but I also prefer the old one, they say they used native descendants to proper represent but how about "good acting"? ... In general, I think it took out a bit of fun, unique mechanics, and a few distinguishable aspects of some civilizations. Historically more accurate? yes. But there is a line between reality and entertainment. For me, in some regards, it got too much and took out a bit of the entertainment part.
Good game, worth a try.

Having played Age 3 since it originally came out in 2007 I can honestly say that this review is legitimate.

Pros

- Balance patches (The original version was severely impacted OP units; namely the French Gendarme and Russian Box formation);

- Unit Variety and Civ Diversity (Each Civ feels fresh and unique unlike the recycled ones in Age of Empires 4);

- DLC (Regular updates that bring new Civs, scenarios, maps and so much more);

- A Community that actually cares (Yes.. this is rare in modern games);

- Fantastic art style with incredibly detailed siege and naval animations (Just sit and admire the sheer size of them Warships)

Negatives

- High skill gap (beginners [mostly those writing negative comments by the looks of it] will struggle with the pace of matches, especially online)

- Large rosters and unique Civs = longer time needed to master each

- Removed references to historical elements (links to 'colonialism' namely) [However, I welcome the corrections to reflect more accurately the customs, traditions and practices of Aboriginal and First Nation peoples.

- Tit-for-Tat between the Age of Empires 2 and Age of Empires 3 Community (Yes.. Age 2 players do not like Age 3 and thus will sadly try to deter players joining by writing negative comparisons) [Both games are excellent in their own way]

Overall
