While nothing can compare with Age of Empires II, this Definitive Edition is definitely the best possible iteration of the game.

I think the most disappointing aspect of this game is its "Story Mode." While Age of Empires I and II plunged players into some of the greatest real world military campaigns of history (be it in Ancient Greece, Shang China, The 100 Years War, or the Muslim side of the Crusades), Age of Empires III elected for a fictional (and, frankly, absurd) plot revolving around fake characters only vaguely intersecting with real moments in history. Disappointingly, those stories are told in ways that vastly downplay the horrors of the Colonial Era, and frustratingly, the game is set during a historical moment ripe with incredible potential for campaigns (the consolidation of a German State, the 30 Years War, The Formation of the Aztec or Incan Empires, The Taiping Rebellion, The Meiji Restoration, Revolutions in France, Haiti, The United States, and Russia just to name a few, not to mention the most obvious choice for a storied campaign: Napoleon!).

Leaving that aside however, the game itself looks and plays great; Civ Balance has been tweaked, (more) historically accurate representations of Native and Indigenous Peoples of North America have been added, and the continent of Africa has finally been acknowledged in the latest DLC. Must play!

Like so many others I was wary of playing AoE III: Definitive Edition. The early reviews were not good and the (ahem) politics surrounding some of the changes were more than a little off putting. Still, I went for it and was mildly entertained though I could see some of the bugs that others were reporting. 

I can now say with confidence that all the previous issues appear to be have corrected and that Definitive Edition is the game that we were all promised. From the improved graphics, to the DLC editions of the African civilizations, and new maps, the game has now exceeded my expectations. Ignore what so many other critics are saying and play it for yourself. As a fan who has fond memories of playing the original Age of Empires 2, this latest edition has equaled the enjoyment that I experienced with the older games.

The developers of this definitive edition took it upon themselves to change the names of civilizations, characters, and units/buildings to be more historically accurate and culturally sensitive towards Native Americans. I have no issue with this.

HOWEVER, after I began playing, I noticed something which is completely inaccurate. Black Germans, black Russians, and black Swedes. Are you kidding me?!

The Japanese and Chinese are entirely Asian. The African civs are entirely black. The Native Americans civs are entirely native, yet every European civilization is a mix of black and white characters. This is racist, anti-white woke garbage. Don't buy this game if you genuinely care about fair representation of the world's peoples...

I first got Age of Empires 3 for my birthday all the way back in 2007, or '08. Can't remember exactly. Anyway, it was a gift to me from my father, who had arrived late in the evening, a fair while after the little party my mother had thrown for me ended. It hadn't been wrapped, simply carried in a grocery bag. Looking back, I suspect he had quickly grabbed it on his way over, but that's alright. Because it was *perfect*. After all, I had been playing my father's copies of Age of Empires 1 and 2 for quite some time before that, and was quite the fan as one could guess. Of course, it turned out that the game was to powerful to run on either my or my father's computers, so I ended up having to wait what felt like an eternity to finally be able to play the game(though it was probably closer to a month). During that time, I constantly read through the manual that game with the game, pouring over every single detail. Until finally, the day(and more importantly, the new graphics card)arrived. So, we began the installation process, installing the game using the FOUR SEPARATE DISCS. I know, disgusting huh? Anyway, I finally got to play the game, and let's just say that if Steam were able to log my hours back then, I'd probably have a time played in the multiple thousands.

So, do a I recommend an upgraded, easily accessible, regularly updated version of that same game I played so long ago? Hell Fucking Yeah I do.

I've been playing AoE3 for 10+ years and definitely love to see the DE game.

What's great: new civs, maps, campaigns, and smarter AI enemies - they can quickly form a comprehensive army, and micro manage each individual soldier in the battlefield.

What's to be improved: the game looks to lag behind (even compared to the original AoE3 10y+ ago) on the optimization on basic operations. Units are much more likely to be unable to find a path; artillery doesn't deploy upon enemies; units make confusing moves e.g. chasing running away enemies instead of attacking nearby units. This, combined with smarter enemies, makes the game much harder for me personally. I didn't have such experience with the original AoE3.

I am really looking forward to seeing the developers to keep improving the basic gaming experience - being defeated not by smart enemy but by confusing unit behavior is disappointing. Anyway I am giving a thumbs up.

I've played AoE3 since release. Clearly I like the core game.

As for the Definitive Edition:

Pros:

-Improved graphics (that is handles larger resolutions and multiple monitors, the graphical elements are improved, and allows for better camera scrolling in and out.)

-there are a few more maps and some new catagories of maps

Cons:

- All cards are unlocked when you start a new home city (player) which means there isn't much to play for in terms of levels. It could have been easy enough to make this only a feature for multiplayer or just make it optional.

- There is a collection of maps labelled "Naval Maps" which only have strips of water, often a thin slice of coast on the side, which doesn't offer much opportunity for real naval battles. 

- Difficulty jumps are dramatic on the low end. Going from Standard to Moderate is like going from playing an AFK player to playing someone who is really aggressive by comparison.

In all I'd say the modest cost was worth it for an AoE2/AoE3 player, though I miss some things I mentioned, even with AoE4 coming around the corner.

I dislike the 'Sensitivity Policy' that this game has adopted - examples being changing Colonial Age name to Commerce Age; Plantation to Estate and going as far as changing campaign missions where you fight Natives to fighting Bandits and Outlaws instead. This is not as intrusive as some players portray it though, and honestly doesn't make a major difference.

That being said, this is a good remaster and pretty much a direct upgrade over original. The visual boost is self explanatory, albeit some changes I disliked - mainly the increased contrast and saturation.

A welcome change was improvements to UI (cleaner and with higher resolution), AI (first thing I noticed is that AI now uses 'hit-and-run' tactics with ranged cavalry) and Skirmish settings (ability to have more than 2 teams, for example). And of course there's tons of small flavor and details that enrich the immersion.

I enjoyed the original and honestly I enjoy this one even more.

A more-than-decent, though not quite perfect, remake of a classic RTS game I loved as a child. Looks great, plays very well and comes with a few nice improvements or other changes that make for a more comfortable experience. Campaign has many shining moments, and the Skirmish mode is what I found the most fun: playing as, with and against an array of pre-modern colonial and indigenous powers vying for control of the Americas, Africa and Asia. Yeah, the name changes were dumb, but thankfully there is a mod for that. Would definitely recommend for 18th- and 19th-Century military history buffs who also like strategy games.

[b]Do I recommend this game?

Short answer: [h1]YES![/h1]
Long answer:[/b]

[h1]The Age of Exploration[/h1] (also called the Age of Discovery) began in the 1400s and continued through the 1600s. It was a period of time when the European nations began exploring the world. They discovered new routes to India, much of the Far East, and the Americas. The Age of Exploration took place at the same time as the Renaissance. 

[h1]Why explore?[/h1]
Outfitting an expedition could be expensive and risky. Many ships never returned. So why did the Europeans want to explore? The simple answer is money. Although, some individual explorers wanted to gain fame or experience adventure, the main purpose of an expedition was to make money.

[h1]How did expeditions make money?[/h1]
Expeditions made money primarily by discovering new trade routes for their nations. When the Ottoman Empire captured Constantinople in 1453, many existing trade routes to India and China were shut down. These trade routes were very valuable as they brought in expensive products such as spices and silk. New expeditions tried to discover oceangoing routes to India and the Far East. Some expeditions became rich by discovering gold and silver, such as the expeditions of the Spanish to the Americas. They also found new land where colonies could be established and crops such as sugar, cotton, and tobacco could be grown.  

[h1]Henry the Navigator[/h1]
The Age of Exploration began in the nation of Portugal under the leadership of Henry the Navigator. Henry sent out ships to map and explore the west coast of Africa. They went further south than any previous European expedition and mapped much of western Africa for the Portuguese. In 1488, Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Dias was the first European to sail around the southern tip of Africa and into the Indian Ocean.

[h1]Christopher Columbus[/h1]
Soon the Spanish wanted to find a trade route to the Far East. Explorer Christopher Columbus thought that he could sail west, across the Atlantic Ocean, to China. He could not get the Portuguese to fund his expedition, so he went to the Spanish. Spanish monarchs Isabella and Ferdinand agreed to pay for Columbus' trip. In 1492 Columbus discovered the New World of the Americas.

[h1]Portugal and Spain[/h1]
Portugal and Spain became the early leaders in the Age of Exploration. Through the Treaty of Tordesillas the two countries agreed to divide up the New World. Spain got most of the Americas while Portugal got Brazil, India, and Asia.  Spain sent over conquistadors to explore the Americas and to conquer the peoples there. Hernan Cortes conquered the Aztec Empire in Mexico and Francisco Pizarro conquered the Inca Empire in Peru. They made Spain rich with the gold and silver they found in the Americas.Portugal sent out Vasco da Gama who found a trade route around the southern tip of Africa and to India. They also explored much of the Far East and were the first Europeans to establish a trading colony in China at Macau.

[h1]Colonies[/h1]
Other countries such as Great Britain and the Netherlands established colonies in the New World. Eventually Great Britain would surpass all of the European nations in terms of the size of their world wide empire including the thirteen colonies in the Americas that later became the United States.

[h1]Geography[/h1]
The Age of Exploration was one of the most important times in the history of world geography. A significant portion of the unknown world was mapped during this short period. Also, many advances were made in navigation and mapping which helped future explorers and travelers...



..and this is just the first of many ages depicted in this masterpiece of a game.
